nodes.name: AB
nodes.description: air bridge. --

nodes.name: ABCS
nodes.description: antimonide-based compound semiconductor. An extremely low voltage technology for very low power LNAs.

nodes.name: AC
nodes.description: alternating current. What SoCal Edison supplies between roaming blackouts.

nodes.name: ACC
nodes.description: adaptive cruise control. The "car radar" we were all promised ten years ago would be on all new cars.

nodes.name: ACI
nodes.description: adjacent channel interference. --

nodes.name: ACLR
nodes.description: adjacent channel leakage ratio. --

nodes.name: ACPR
nodes.description: adjacent channel power ratio. A measurement of power amplifier linearity.

nodes.name: ACWG
nodes.description: asymmetrical coplanar waveguide. --

nodes.name: ADC
nodes.description: analog to digital converter. --

nodes.name: ADS
nodes.description: Advanced Design System. Agilient's microwave design tool.

nodes.name: ADT
nodes.description: automatic detection and tracking. A radar term.

nodes.name: AESA
nodes.description: active electronically-steered array. The holy grail of antennas, but not even the federal government can afford one, so where does that leave the rest of us?

nodes.name: AGC
nodes.description: automatic gain control. Circuitry that actively adjusts the gain of an amplifier to maintain a constant gain output power over temperature, frequency, or input power conditions.

nodes.name: ALD
nodes.description: atomic layer deposition. A method of precisely depositing material.

nodes.name: ALN
nodes.description: Aluminum nitride. A ceramic substrate that has good heat-sinking properties.

nodes.name: AM
nodes.description: amplitude modulation. The simplest way to put a baseband signal onto a carrier signal.

nodes.name: AM/PM
nodes.description: amplitude modulation to phase modulation. A form of distortion.

nodes.name: AMPS
nodes.description: Advanced mobile phone system. Analog cell phone standard.

nodes.name: ANA
nodes.description: automated network analyzer. Used to measure S-parameters of a network.

nodes.name: AOA
nodes.description: angle of arrival. A term associated with antennas.

nodes.name: APC-7
nodes.description: Amphenol precision connector, 7 millimeter. Trademarked name for a sexless connector system.

nodes.name: APDP
nodes.description: anti-parallel diode pair. Often used in a sub-harmonic mixer.

nodes.name: APS
nodes.description: antenna positioning system. --

nodes.name: ARRL
nodes.description: American Radio Relay League. The organization that supports ham radio.

nodes.name: ASIC
nodes.description: application-specific semiconductor. The most expensive (and elegant) means of providing logic for your modules.

nodes.name: ASK
nodes.description: amplitude-shift keying. --

nodes.name: ATE
nodes.description: automated test equipment. What you will need when your circuit enters production

nodes.name: ATR
nodes.description: anti transmit-receive cells. --

nodes.name: AUT
nodes.description: antenna under test. --

nodes.name: AWG
nodes.description: American wire gauge. A standard for copper wire diameter.

nodes.name: AWGN
nodes.description: additive white Gaussian noise. --

nodes.name: BAUD
nodes.description: symbol rate. Note that "baud rate" is like saying "symbol rate rate" which doesn't make any sense, does it? Thanks, Mike!

nodes.name: BAW
nodes.description: bulk acoustic wave. Similar to surface acoustic wave technology.

nodes.name: BB
nodes.description: baseband. --

nodes.name: BER
nodes.description: bit error rate. The number of errors over a given period of time expressed as a percentage.

nodes.name: BF
nodes.description: beamformer. --

nodes.name: BFN
nodes.description: beam-forming network. A system of power combiners and phase shifters that is used to steer an array.

nodes.name: BICMOS
nodes.description: bipolar complementary metal-oxide semiconductor. The RF devices that are used in SiGe.

nodes.name: BIT
nodes.description: built-in test. Refers to output signals that are generated by a piece of hardware whose only function is to help you determine if your hardware is working.

nodes.name: BITE
nodes.description: built-in test equipment. See above. Alternately, a verb, as in reality BITEs.

nodes.name: BJT
nodes.description: bipolar junction transistor. A good old-fashioned semiconductor device recently made useful into the lower microwave frequencies.

nodes.name: BLUETOOTH
nodes.description: Bluetooth. A wireless networking convention named after a dead Danish king

nodes.name: BNC
nodes.description: bayonet N-type connector. A type of RF connector from the dark ages (useful only to UHF frequencies).

nodes.name: BOM
nodes.description: bill of materials. The whole ball of wax required to assemble all of your widgets.

nodes.name: BPF
nodes.description: band-pass filter. A two-port network that rejects signals outside of a certain frequency band.

nodes.name: BPSK
nodes.description: binary phase-shift keying. Thanks to Adam for the correction!

nodes.name: BS
nodes.description: base station. Also, bravo sierra...

nodes.name: BSD
nodes.description: Blind spot detection. An application of automotive radar

nodes.name: BSOM
nodes.description: beats the (stuffing) out of me. Who busted the scope probe? BSOM!

nodes.name: BW
nodes.description: bandwidth. --

nodes.name: BWO
nodes.description: backward wave oscillator. --

nodes.name: C
nodes.description: the speed of light. 186,000 mile per second, speed limit of the universe.

nodes.name: C/N
nodes.description: carrier-to-noise (ratio). --

nodes.name: CAD
nodes.description: computer-aided design. Examples: software such as Eagleware and AutoCAD.

nodes.name: CAE
nodes.description: computer-aided engineering. The union of CAD, CAM and CAT.

nodes.name: CAM
nodes.description: computer-aided manufacturing. Examples: automated pick and place, automated wirebonder.

nodes.name: CAT
nodes.description: computer-aided test. Examples: automated network analyzer, phase noise analyzer.

nodes.name: CATV
nodes.description: community access television. "The cable".

nodes.name: CB
nodes.description: Common base. A transistor amplifier configuration

nodes.name: CBCPW
nodes.description: conductor-backed coplanar waveguide. What you get when you add a ground plane under the substrate below CPW. Basically a mixed-mode microstrip/CPW transmission line. Also called grounded coplanar waveguide (GCPW).

nodes.name: CCA
nodes.description: circuit card assembly. A printed wiring board with mounted components.

nodes.name: CCDF
nodes.description: complementary cumultative distribution function. A CCDF curve displays the relative power levels of a signal versus probability based on how much time the signal spends at or above a given power level.

nodes.name: CCW
nodes.description: counterclockwise. Circulators can be CW or CCW

nodes.name: CDMA
nodes.description: code division multiple access. We aren't wireless guys, so we have no idea!

nodes.name: CDPD
nodes.description: cellular digital packet data. A wireless standard.

nodes.name: CE
nodes.description: Common emitter. A transistor amplifier configuration

nodes.name: CEM
nodes.description: computational electromagnetics. --

nodes.name: CF
nodes.description: calibration factor. Data that is needed to correct the response of a power head over frequency.

nodes.name: CFA
nodes.description: crossed-field amplifier. --

nodes.name: CLA
nodes.description: Common-leg amplifier. Often used in T/R modules to reduce cost.

nodes.name: CMB
nodes.description: Cosmic Microwave Background. The cosmic microwave background (CMB) is electromagnetic radiation left over from an early stage of the universe filling all space.

nodes.name: CMOS
nodes.description: complementary metal oxide semiconductor. A technology for making integrated circuits.

nodes.name: CMR
nodes.description: Connector miniature rectantangular. A type of waveguide flange.

nodes.name: CNC
nodes.description: computer numerically controlled. An automated way to machine parts.

nodes.name: CNR, OR C/N
nodes.description: carrier-to-noise ratio. --

nodes.name: COB
nodes.description: chip on board. packaging technique, also known as "glob-top"

nodes.name: COE
nodes.description: center of excellence. What they rename a division of the company, before the PSB.

nodes.name: COTS
nodes.description: commercial off-the-shelf. --

nodes.name: CP
nodes.description: circularly polarized. --

nodes.name: CPA
nodes.description: CPA. Cylindrical phased arrays

nodes.name: CPR
nodes.description: connector pressurized rectangular. A type of waveguide flange.

nodes.name: CPRF
nodes.description: connector pressurized rectangular flat. A type of waveguide flange.

nodes.name: CPRG
nodes.description: connector pressurized rectangular grooved. A type of waveguide flange.

nodes.name: CPS
nodes.description: co-planar stripline. Thanks, Manuel!

nodes.name: CPW
nodes.description: coplanar waveguide. A TEM transmission line media popular for extremely high-frequency (>75 GHz) circuits.

nodes.name: CSO
nodes.description: composite second order (distortion). --

nodes.name: CSP
nodes.description: chip-scale package. A method of protecting a microcircuit without an expensive hermetic enclosure.

nodes.name: CSRR
nodes.description: complimentary split ring resonator. A technique used to realize metamaterials.

nodes.name: CT
nodes.description: curve tracer. --

nodes.name: CTB
nodes.description: composite triple beat (distortion). --

nodes.name: CTE
nodes.description: Coefficient of thermal expansion (also called TCE). An approximate measure of how a solid expands or contracts over temperature.

nodes.name: CVD
nodes.description: chemical-vapor deposition. As in MOCVD, PECVD and VPCVD.

nodes.name: CW
nodes.description: continuous wave or clockwise. A continuous wave signal of a single frequency that is on continuously as opposed to pulsed.

nodes.name: DAC
nodes.description: digital to analog converter. --

nodes.name: DAD
nodes.description: not an acronym. The guy who used to fill your gas tank while you were in college studying to be a microwave big shot. Don't wait until father's day to call him.

nodes.name: DAMPS
nodes.description: digital advanced mobile phone system. --

nodes.name: DANL
nodes.description: Displayed Average Noise Level. From Electronic Design (Erik Diez, Agilent Technologies, Mar 22, 2012): "DANL is another term for a spectrum analyzer’s noise floor given a particular bandwidth and represents its best-case sensitivity. It is impossible to measure input signals below this

nodes.name: DB
nodes.description: decibel. Refers to relative RF power levels on a logarithmic scale. Used to express any ratio logarithmically. "I love you 1 dB more than yesterday" means a 20 percent increase.

nodes.name: DBC
nodes.description: dB below carrier. Measurement of how much less power a signal at one frequency has with respect to the signal at the carrier frequency.

nodes.name: DBM
nodes.description: decibel relative to one milliwatt. Log scale that refers to absolute RF power levels. For example, 0 dBm refers to 1 mW, 30 dBm refers to 1 Watt.

nodes.name: DBM
nodes.description: double balanced mixer. One of many cases of acronym reuse!

nodes.name: DBP
nodes.description: dB Petre. Measurement of how much power a signal has at one frequency with respect to the legendary Edward Petre.  Power levels may be lower when Ed does not carry his cellphone when making phase noise measurements.

nodes.name: DBS
nodes.description: direct broadcast satellite. The thing out in space that transmits all of those cartoons to your kids. The link between the satellite and your house is done with microwave signals.

nodes.name: DC
nodes.description: direct current. What Edison incorrectly thought you'd use in your home.

nodes.name: DCS
nodes.description: digital communication system. Analog cell phone standard.

nodes.name: DCXO
nodes.description: digitally-compensated crystal oscillator. --

nodes.name: DDC
nodes.description: digital down converter. Thanks to Josh!

nodes.name: DECT
nodes.description: digital enhanced cordless telephone. Digital cordless phone standard.

nodes.name: DF
nodes.description: dissipation factor. The reciprocal of quality factor (Q) for a capacitor.

nodes.name: DFW
nodes.description: dielectrically-filled waveguide. See substrate-integrated waveguide (SIW)

nodes.name: DHBT
nodes.description: double-heterojunction bipolar transistor. --

nodes.name: DLVA
nodes.description: detector log video amplifier. --

nodes.name: DOE
nodes.description: design of experiments. A more impressive way of saying, "I tried a lot of sh*t, and this seems to work the best, now pass the donuts"

nodes.name: DPDT
nodes.description: double-pole, double throw. A pair of SPDT switches that are ganged together (thanks, Micah!)

nodes.name: DPLL
nodes.description: digital phase-locked loop. --

nodes.name: DPQSK
nodes.description: differential quadrature phase shift keying. --

nodes.name: DRC
nodes.description: design rule checking. Software that verifies that you didn't do something really stupid in your layout.

nodes.name: DRO
nodes.description: dielectric resonator oscillator. --

nodes.name: DSA
nodes.description: digital step attenuator. --

nodes.name: DSB
nodes.description: double sideband. A receiver or downconverter that uses both sidebands.

nodes.name: DSBSC
nodes.description: double sideband carrier suppression. --

nodes.name: DSP
nodes.description: digital signal processor. What the nerds do with your IF output signal.

nodes.name: DSR
nodes.description: double-selective recess. A highly-repeatable way to make pHEMT gates.

nodes.name: DSS
nodes.description: digital satellite system. --

nodes.name: DTUPC
nodes.description: design to unit production cost. Here is an article on DTUPC that dates to 1973, written by the US Army.

nodes.name: DUT
nodes.description: device under test. That thing you just blew up out in the lab.

nodes.name: E-OK
nodes.description: electronically OK. The web site http://www.e-okkids.com claims to have registered this trademark as "environmentally and ecologically good" (EEG?), so don't blame us if you are attacked by three talking dinosaurs if you use it improperly...

nodes.name: EBG
nodes.description: electronic bandgap. A form of meta-material.

nodes.name: ECAD
nodes.description: Electronic CAD. Tools used by designers (as opposed to TCAD, used by technology developers)

nodes.name: ECL
nodes.description: emitter coupled logic. --

nodes.name: ECM
nodes.description: electronic countermeasures. Also ECCM for counter-counter measures.

nodes.name: ED
nodes.description: electro-deposition. In this context, placing metal through the use of electrolysis (not something you take Viagra for).

nodes.name: EDA
nodes.description: Electronic design automation. The new term for "CAD"

nodes.name: EDM
nodes.description: electronic discharge machining. A way to make very accurate metal parts.

nodes.name: EER
nodes.description: envelope elimination and restoration. A supply modulation technique for improving efficiency.

nodes.name: EHF
nodes.description: extra-high frequency. --

nodes.name: EIA
nodes.description: electronics industry association. A trade association that represents all areas of the electronics industry.

nodes.name: EIC
nodes.description: Electronics Industries Alliance. A trade association that represents all areas of the electronics industry.

nodes.name: EIKA
nodes.description: Extended interaction klystron amplifier. A microwave tube that can provide 1000 watts at millimeterwave frequencies.

nodes.name: EIRP
nodes.description: effective isotropic radiated power. --

nodes.name: EM
nodes.description: electromagnetic. What Maxwell figured out.

nodes.name: EMC
nodes.description: electromagnetic compatibility. --

nodes.name: EMI
nodes.description: electromagnetic interference. What you get if you don't pay attention to EMC requirements.

nodes.name: EMP
nodes.description: electromagnetic pulse. The reason your car won't run during a nuclear attack on your neighborhood.

nodes.name: ENR
nodes.description: excess noise ratio. A rating for noise sources.

nodes.name: ERP
nodes.description: effective radiated power. --

nodes.name: ESA
nodes.description: electronically-steered array. Similar to AESA, without all the amplifiers at each phase center.

nodes.name: ESD
nodes.description: electrostatic discharge. Phantom force that blows up hardware if you don't wear a strap.

nodes.name: ESL
nodes.description: electronic system level. Refers to software environments for system analysis.

nodes.name: ESR
nodes.description: equivalent series resistance. The resistive loss of a capacitor.

nodes.name: ESS
nodes.description: environmental stress screening. --

nodes.name: ET
nodes.description: envelope tracking. A supply modulation technique for improving efficiency.

nodes.name: ETC
nodes.description: electronic toll-collecting. --

nodes.name: ETSI
nodes.description: European Telecommunications Standards Institute. --

nodes.name: EUT
nodes.description: end user terminal. --

nodes.name: EVM
nodes.description: error vector magnitude. --

nodes.name: EW
nodes.description: electronic warfare. --

nodes.name: F
nodes.description: Fahrenheit or Farad. Temperature scale named after a dead Deutsche guy (not a Dutch guy, thanks Laurens!), or a unit of capacitance named after a dead Brit who is a member of our Microwave Hall of Fame!

nodes.name: FB
nodes.description: feedback. --

nodes.name: FBMC
nodes.description: filter bank multi carrier. --

nodes.name: FCC
nodes.description: Federal Communications Commission. --

nodes.name: FDD
nodes.description: frequency division duplex. --

nodes.name: FDMA
nodes.description: frequency division multiple access. --

nodes.name: FDSOI
nodes.description: fully depleted silicon-on-insulator. A method of isolating silicon circuits from silicon body of an integrated circuit.

nodes.name: FDTD
nodes.description: finite difference time domain. A computational electromagnetics approach for solving realistic EM problems, popularized by Prof. Allen Taflove of Northwestern University.

nodes.name: FEA
nodes.description: finite element analysis. Used in simulating electromagnetic fields.

nodes.name: FER
nodes.description: Front end receiver OR frame error rate, depending on the context.. A semiconductor device.

nodes.name: FET
nodes.description: field-effect transistor. A semiconductor device.

nodes.name: FF
nodes.description: femto-farad. A unit of capacitance, 10E-15 farads.

nodes.name: FF
nodes.description: Far field. A type of antenna measurement

nodes.name: FFS
nodes.description: final frontside. MMIC wafers often have DC data measured prior to flipping the wafer for backside processing.

nodes.name: FFT
nodes.description: fast Fourier transform. The Fourier transform is what allows you to go between frequency and time domains.

nodes.name: FGCPW
nodes.description: finite groundplane coplanar waveguide. Coplanar waveguide, with narrow ground strips. Not the same thing as CBCPW!

nodes.name: FIR
nodes.description: finite impulse response (filter). --

nodes.name: FIT
nodes.description: finite integration technique. --

nodes.name: FM
nodes.description: frequency modulation. Transferring information by varying the carrier frequency. The broadcast radio band with "no static at all".

nodes.name: FMAX
nodes.description: maximum frequency. The maximum frequency at which you can get power gain from a transistor.

nodes.name: FMCW
nodes.description: frequency modulated continuous wave. A type of radar waveform.

nodes.name: FMIN
nodes.description: minimum noise figure of a device. Used in low noise amplifier design.

nodes.name: FOD
nodes.description: foreign object/debris. Unwanted stuff that accidentally finds its way into hardware during manufacturing.  Food, tools, ty-wraps... things that could cause a disaster after delivery to your customer.

nodes.name: FP
nodes.description: Field plate. Used in GaN HEMTs to reduce peak electric field in channel

nodes.name: FR-4
nodes.description: fire-retardant 4. A glass-resin PWB material.

nodes.name: FS
nodes.description: field strength. Magnitude of an electromagnetic field.

nodes.name: FSK
nodes.description: frequency shift keying. --

nodes.name: FSR
nodes.description: full sheet resonance. A method for measuring dielectric constant of a circuit board.

nodes.name: FSS
nodes.description: frequency-selective surface. A substrate with a metal pattern that passes energy at one frequency but blocks it at another.

nodes.name: FT
nodes.description: feet. Unit of length used by Yankees.

nodes.name: FT
nodes.description: transition frequency. The frequency at which the gain of a transistor is 0dB.

nodes.name: FTP
nodes.description: file transfer protocol. --

nodes.name: FUBAR
nodes.description: f***ed up beyond all repair. One of the two excellent acronyms that are the legacy of the greatest generation (see snafu)

nodes.name: G
nodes.description: gravity unit. Measurement of how hard a part will be accelerated.

nodes.name: GA
nodes.description: available gain. Computed from S-parameters of a two-port network.

nodes.name: GAAS
nodes.description: gallium arsenide. III-IV compound that is a staple of the microwave IC world.

nodes.name: GAN
nodes.description: gallium nitride. An immature wide-bandgap III-V semiconductor technology that may offer a 10 dB increase in output power for the same size GaAs device.

nodes.name: GBS
nodes.description: Giga-bits per second. A unit of data rate

nodes.name: GCPW
nodes.description: grounded coplanar waveguide. What you get when you add a ground plane under the substrate below CPW. Basically a mixed-mode microstrip/CPW transmission line. Also called conductor-backed coplanar waveguide (CBCPW).

nodes.name: GEO
nodes.description: geostationary earth orbit. A position in near-space at which a satellite remains in the same position relative to the earth below.

nodes.name: GHZ
nodes.description: gigahertz. 1,000,000,000 cycles per second. Currently, the clock speed of a fairly inexpensive personal computer.

nodes.name: GL
nodes.description: grating lobe. See phased arrays.

nodes.name: GMAX
nodes.description: maximum gain. The theoretical gain of an amplifier when it is conjugately matched.

nodes.name: GOPT
nodes.description: gamma optimum. One of three noise parameters for a device, refers to the generator impedance required for minimum noise figure. Used in noise figure calculations, along with RN and NFmin.

nodes.name: GPIB
nodes.description: general purpose interface bus. --

nodes.name: GPO
nodes.description: Gilbert push-on. A trademarked family of RF connectors, now owned by Corning.

nodes.name: GPS
nodes.description: global positioning system, ground-plane spacing. What terrorists will use to position their first nuclear bomb, or a key dimension in stripline.

nodes.name: GR
nodes.description: ground. A potential of zero volts, usually with respect to the chassis.

nodes.name: gs 2
nodes.description: general studies 2. qualifying in nature

nodes.name: GSG
nodes.description: gorund signal ground. The normal configuration for co-planar RF probes.

nodes.name: GSM
nodes.description: global system for mobile communications. Digital cell phone standard.

nodes.name: GSO
nodes.description: geo-synchronous orbit. --

nodes.name: H
nodes.description: Henry. A unit of inductance, named after a dead American, Joseph Henry.

nodes.name: H-POL
nodes.description: horizontal polarization. --

nodes.name: HAST
nodes.description: highly-accelerated life test. The "pressure cooker" of qual tests!

nodes.name: HB
nodes.description: harmonic balance. A method of analyzing circuits with non-linear behavior.

nodes.name: HBT
nodes.description: hetero-junction bi-polar transistor. A good competitor to pHEMT, and requires only one power supply polarity.

nodes.name: HDPE
nodes.description: high density poly-ethelene. Also known as PEHD in countries such as France, HDPE is number 2 in the recycling categories. Chances are your milk jug is made of it. It is also a useful dielectric, with DK of 2.3 and DF of 0.003.

nodes.name: HEMT
nodes.description: high electron mobility transistor. Developed in the 1990s, provides better microwave performance compared to MESFETs.

nodes.name: HEPA
nodes.description: high efficiency particulate air (filter). The type of filters used to filter out particles down to 0.3 micron in a clean room.

nodes.name: HEXFET
nodes.description: hexagonal field-effect transistor. A trademark of International Rectifier for their MOSFET line.

nodes.name: HFET
nodes.description: heterostructure field-effect transistor. --

nodes.name: HFSS
nodes.description: High-Frequency Structural Simulator. Ansoft's 3D EM simulation tool.

nodes.name: HPA
nodes.description: high-power amplifier. --

nodes.name: HPBW
nodes.description: half-power beamwidth. Used to describe an antenna pattern.

nodes.name: HPF
nodes.description: high pass filter. A two-port network that rejects signals below a certain frequency band.

nodes.name: HPIB
nodes.description: Hewlett Packard instrument bus. Too late to rename it "Agilent instrument bus"

nodes.name: HPIN
nodes.description: horizontal PIN diode. --

nodes.name: HPM
nodes.description: high-power microwave. Generally refers to a source module that is a combination of a solid-state driver circuit and a TWT.

nodes.name: HSM
nodes.description: high-side mixing. Refers to the condition that the LO frequency is above the RF frequency.

nodes.name: HTCC
nodes.description: high-temperature co-fired ceramic. A method of fabricating circuit traces embedded in ceramic.

nodes.name: HTS
nodes.description: high-temperature superconductor. --

nodes.name: HZ
nodes.description: Hertz. Unit of cycles-per-second, named after a dead German. Not to be confused with the dead Austrian who started that rental car company.

nodes.name: I/O
nodes.description: input/output. --

nodes.name: I/Q
nodes.description: in-phase/quadrature. As in "I/Q modulator", not the intelligence quotient of your colleagues.

nodes.name: IC
nodes.description: integrated circuit. --

nodes.name: ICD
nodes.description: interconnect diagram. A type of block diagram.

nodes.name: ICP
nodes.description: Insane Clown Posse. A musical group that you don't want your daughter to be a groupy for? actually, a great way to etch via holes in GaAs substrates.

nodes.name: ID
nodes.description: inside diameter. The inside dimension of a cylinder.

nodes.name: IDS
nodes.description: drain-source current. The channel current in an FET.

nodes.name: IDSS
nodes.description: saturated drain source current. Logical people think this should be abbreviated"SDSC"

nodes.name: IEC
nodes.description: International Electrotechnical Commission. A standards organization.

nodes.name: IEEE
nodes.description: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. The subgroup MTT-S hosts an annual gathering of all things microwaves, publishes a lot of excellent but often hard-to-read microwave-related papers, and is helping to review some of our MW101 articles.

nodes.name: IF
nodes.description: intermediate frequency. The output frequency of a down converter.

nodes.name: IIP2, IIP3
nodes.description: input third order intercept point. The intercept points, referenced to input.

nodes.name: IIP3
nodes.description: input third order intercept point. Same as ITOI.

nodes.name: IL
nodes.description: insertion loss. --

nodes.name: ILFD
nodes.description: injection locked frequency divider. --

nodes.name: IM
nodes.description: intermodulation. --

nodes.name: IMAX
nodes.description: maximum current for a FET. Maximum FET channel current, typically measured at +0.5 volts VGS and +1 volt VDS.

nodes.name: IMD
nodes.description: intermodulation distortion. Often refers to "TOI".

nodes.name: IMN
nodes.description: input matching network, inter-stage matching network. --

nodes.name: IMP
nodes.description: intermodulation products. --

nodes.name: IMPATT
nodes.description: impact avalanche and transit time. A nearly forgotten diode technology that offered great promise for supplying high power at millimeter wavelengths.

nodes.name: IMR
nodes.description: intermodulation ratio. The difference in magnitude of observed during two-tone IMD measurements.

nodes.name: INP
nodes.description: indium phosphide. A III-V compound semiconductor suitable for frequencies up to and beyond 100 GHz.

nodes.name: IP
nodes.description: intellectual property. What you try to protect with a patent.

nodes.name: IP2
nodes.description: second order intercept point. --

nodes.name: IP3
nodes.description: third order intercept point. --

nodes.name: IRM
nodes.description: image reject mixer. A mixer that removes the image frequency contribution from the IF.

nodes.name: ISM
nodes.description: Industrial scientific medical. Frequency band designation

nodes.name: ISV
nodes.description: individual source vias. The best possible grounding scheme for power FETs, usually required 2-mil substrates.

nodes.name: ITAR
nodes.description: international traffic in arms regulations. A set of regulations in the United States that controls the export of data that is critical to military programs.

nodes.name: ITOI
nodes.description: input third order intercept. Same as IIP3.

nodes.name: JDC
nodes.description: Japan digital cellular. --

nodes.name: JEDEC
nodes.description: Joint Electron Device Engineering Council. Standards committee of the EIC.

nodes.name: $K
nodes.description: kilo-bucks. What nerdly NASA engineers replaced the gangster-inspired term "Gs" with.

nodes.name: K
nodes.description: Rollett's stability factor. Predicts the possibility that an active device such as an amplifier will oscillate. K >1 implies unconditional stability.

nodes.name: K
nodes.description: the wave number. --

nodes.name: KGD
nodes.description: known-good die. Pretested integrated circuits.

nodes.name: KHZ
nodes.description: kilohertz. 1000 cycles per second.

nodes.name: LAN
nodes.description: local area network. --

nodes.name: LCA
nodes.description: Lane change assist. An application of automotive radar

nodes.name: LCC
nodes.description: leadless chip carrier. A type of package.

nodes.name: LCP
nodes.description: liquid crystal polymer. A type of low-cost soft substrate.

nodes.name: LDMOS
nodes.description: laterally diffused metal oxide semiconductor. Power amp technology, pioneered by Freescale.

nodes.name: LEC
nodes.description: liquid-encapsulated Czochralski. The most popular method of growing single-crystal GaAs material.

nodes.name: LHCP
nodes.description: left-hand circularly polarized. --

nodes.name: LMDS
nodes.description: local multipoint distribution system. --

nodes.name: LNA
nodes.description: low noise amplifier. A low noise amplifier has good noise figure, but limited power handling. Used in a receiver.

nodes.name: LNB
nodes.description: low noise block. Downconverter module consisting of a low noise amplifier and a mixer. Often used to describe the first section of a receiver.

nodes.name: LO
nodes.description: local oscillator. The signal used to drive a mixer to change the carrier frequency. Pronounced "ell-oh", if you say "low" people will immediately think you are a buyer and not an engineer.

nodes.name: LORAN
nodes.description: long range navigation. Actually, this is more like a portmanteau than an acronym. Invented by Alfred Lee Loomis.

nodes.name: LOS
nodes.description: line-of-sight. --

nodes.name: LPF
nodes.description: low-pass filter. A two-port network that rejects signals above a certain frequency band.

nodes.name: LRL
nodes.description: line-reflect-line. A type of network measurement calibration.

nodes.name: LRM
nodes.description: line-reflect-match. A type of network measurement calibration.

nodes.name: LS
nodes.description: large signal. Range in which stuff acts non-linear.

nodes.name: LSB
nodes.description: least significant bit. In a three-bit phase shifter, the 45 degree bit.

nodes.name: LSG
nodes.description: large signal gain. The gain characteristic of a nonlinear device near its saturation point.

nodes.name: LSM
nodes.description: low side mixing. Refers to the condition that the LO frequency is below the RF frequency.

nodes.name: LTCC
nodes.description: low-temperature co-fired ceramic. A versatile but expensive multi-layer ceramic substrate technology.

nodes.name: LTE
nodes.description: Long term evolution. A wireless communication standard.

nodes.name: LVS
nodes.description: layout versus schematic. A software means of checking that your MMIC circuit will work on the first iteration.

nodes.name: MAGRAM
nodes.description: magnetic radar absorbing material. Used in radar cross-section reduction.

nodes.name: MAX
nodes.description: maximum. Opposite of min.

nodes.name: MBE
nodes.description: molecular-beam epitaxy. Method of growing semiconductor layers onto a substrate.

nodes.name: MCM
nodes.description: multi-chip module. Refers to a method of fabricating a microwave circuit using directly-bonded integrated circuit chips.

nodes.name: MCM
nodes.description: multi-carrier modulation. A method of transmitting data by splitting it into multiple signals.

nodes.name: MDS
nodes.description: multi-point distribution system, minimum detectable signal. A received signal that is maybe 3 dB higher than the noise level.

nodes.name: MEMS
nodes.description: microelectromechanical system. A microwave career killer.

nodes.name: MEO
nodes.description: medium earth orbit. --

nodes.name: MESFET
nodes.description: metal/semiconductor field effect transistor. A three-terminal semiconductor device in which a Schottky-metal gate is used to control electron flow between source and drain contacts.

nodes.name: MHEMT
nodes.description: metamorphic high electron mobility transistor. A relatively new GaAs semiconductor technology for millimeterwave applications.

nodes.name: MHZ
nodes.description: megahertz. 1,000,000 cycles per second.

nodes.name: MIC
nodes.description: microwave integrated circuit. An assembly of ceramic substrates and wirebonded components, also called a "hybrid".

nodes.name: MIL-TFD
nodes.description: make it like the f***ing drawing!!!. Nuff said.

nodes.name: MIM
nodes.description: metal-insulator-metal. A type of capacitor on an integrated circuit.

nodes.name: MIMO
nodes.description: multiple input multiple output. A radio architecture for maximizing capacity

nodes.name: MIN
nodes.description: minimum. Opposite of max.

nodes.name: MISFET
nodes.description: metal-insulator-semiconductor field effect transistor. A type of FET that uses a thin layer of insulating GaAs above the channel to isolate the gate. Not used often, but noted for huge voltage/power handling capability.

nodes.name: MISO
nodes.description: multiple input single output. --

nodes.name: MLB
nodes.description: multi-layer board. --

nodes.name: MLC
nodes.description: multi-layer capacitor. Usually used as a surface mount capacitor.

nodes.name: MLP
nodes.description: micro leadframe package. One of many package styles.

nodes.name: MMDS
nodes.description: multichannel multiport distribution system. --

nodes.name: MMIC
nodes.description: monolithic microwave integrated circuit. A single chip containing a microwave circuit.

nodes.name: MMW
nodes.description: millimeter-wave. Frequencies between 30 and 300 GHz.

nodes.name: MOCVD
nodes.description: metallorganic chemical vapor deposition. One of many ways to grow semiconductor films onto a substrate.

nodes.name: MOM
nodes.description: method of moments. The theory behind the EM analysis in Momentum.

nodes.name: MOS
nodes.description: metal-oxide semiconductor. A type of capacitor.

nodes.name: MOSFET
nodes.description: metal/oxide/semiconductor field-effect transistor. A three-terminal semiconductor device which usually is limited to UHF band.

nodes.name: MOVPE
nodes.description: metallorganic vapor-phase epitaxy. One of many ways to grow semiconductor films onto a substrate.

nodes.name: MPA
nodes.description: Medium power amplifier. Little sister of a power amplifier

nodes.name: MPAC
nodes.description: multi-probe anechoic chamber. --

nodes.name: MPM
nodes.description: microwave power module. What tube guys call the solid-state preamplifier.

nodes.name: MRAD, MR
nodes.description: milliradian. Unit of angle for pretty small stuff.

nodes.name: MS
nodes.description: millisecond. 1/1000 of a second. Time really does fly at this rate.

nodes.name: MS
nodes.description: microstrip. --

nodes.name: MS
nodes.description: milli-Siemens. 1/1000 of a Seimen.

nodes.name: MSA
nodes.description: microstrip antenna. --

nodes.name: MSB
nodes.description: most-significant bit. In a three-bit phase shifter, the 180 degree bit.

nodes.name: MTBF
nodes.description: mean time between failure. A measure of reliability.

nodes.name: MTI
nodes.description: moving target indicator. --

nodes.name: MTTF
nodes.description: mean time to failure. A measure of reliability.

nodes.name: MV
nodes.description: millivolt. 1/1000 of a volt

nodes.name: MVED
nodes.description: microwave vacuum electronics device. --

nodes.name: MW
nodes.description: milliwatt. Unit of power, 1/1000 of a watt

nodes.name: MW
nodes.description: microwave. As opposed to "MMW" which is millimeter-wave.

nodes.name: NA
nodes.description: network analyzer. Test equipment used to measure S-parameters of a part. See also ANA.

nodes.name: NADC
nodes.description: North American digital cellular. --

nodes.name: NAMPS
nodes.description: narrow band advanced mobile phone service. Analog cell phone standard.

nodes.name: NDF
nodes.description: Normalized Determinant Function. --

nodes.name: NDT
nodes.description: non-destruct testing. Qual procedures that don't wreck your hardware.

nodes.name: NEXT
nodes.description: near end cross talk. --

nodes.name: NF
nodes.description: nano-Farad. A unit of capacitance, 10E-9 Farads.

nodes.name: NF
nodes.description: noise figure. A measurement of how much a component degrades the signal-to-noise ratio of a system.

nodes.name: NF
nodes.description: Near field. A type of antenna measurement https://www.microwaves101.com/encyclopedias/antenna-measurements

nodes.name: NFM
nodes.description: noise figure meter. Test equipment for measuring noise figure and sometimes gain.

nodes.name: NGT
nodes.description: not greater than. Sometimes used in specifications.

nodes.name: NH
nodes.description: nano-Henry. A unit of inductance, 10-9 Henries.

nodes.name: NIP
nodes.description: N-type/intrinsic/P-type. The opposite diode structure of PIN.

nodes.name: NL
nodes.description: nonlinear. --

nodes.name: NLT
nodes.description: not less than. Sometimes used in specifications.

nodes.name: NLT, NLTL
nodes.description: Nonlinear transmission line. Used in comb generators.

nodes.name: NPR
nodes.description: noise power ratio. Another measurement of power amplifier linearity.

nodes.name: NRE
nodes.description: non-recurring cost. This is how you recover the money you lose when you sell piece parts at a loss to force your competition out of business.

nodes.name: NTC
nodes.description: negative temperature coefficient. A thermistor with resistance value decreasing with temperature.

nodes.name: NTE
nodes.description: not to exceed. Sometimes used in specifications. What's the opposite of NTE? not to deceed???

nodes.name: OC
nodes.description: open circuit. Opposite of short circuit.

nodes.name: OCR
nodes.description: optical character recognition. Scan in a printed document and voilà, you have a zillion mispellings to correct. Ask Walter Rotman....

nodes.name: OCXO
nodes.description: oven controlled crystal oscillator. --

nodes.name: OD
nodes.description: outside diameter. The outside dimension of a cylinder.

nodes.name: OE
nodes.description: Oersteds. Unit of magnetic intensity, named after Hans Christian Oersted.

nodes.name: OF
nodes.description: Old fart. That old guy out in the lab that knows everything but has hairs growing out of his ears.

nodes.name: OFDM
nodes.description: orthagonal frequency division multiplexing. A method of sending multiple closely spaced carrier signals from a single transmitter.

nodes.name: OFHC
nodes.description: oxygen-free high-conductivity (copper). The ideal material for low loss waveguide.

nodes.name: OMN
nodes.description: output matching network. --

nodes.name: OMT
nodes.description: ortho-mode transducer. --

nodes.name: OQAM
nodes.description: offset quadrature amplitude modulation. --

nodes.name: OTA
nodes.description: over the air. --

nodes.name: OTOI
nodes.description: output third order intercept. --

nodes.name: P1DB
nodes.description: power at one-dB gain compression. --

nodes.name: P1DBIN
nodes.description: P1dB referenced to the input. --

nodes.name: P1DBOUT
nodes.description: P1dB referenced to the output. --

nodes.name: PA
nodes.description: power amp. An amplifier that is capable of applying some real heat to the load.

nodes.name: PAE
nodes.description: power-added efficiency. For a power amp, the ratio of output power divided by the sum of input RF and DC power.

nodes.name: PAM
nodes.description: pulse amplitude modulation. --

nodes.name: PAPR
nodes.description: peak to average power ratio. Ratio of the peak power (peak amplitude squared) to the average power (the square of the root mean square value).

nodes.name: PAR
nodes.description: peak average ratio. --

nodes.name: PC
nodes.description: personal computer, or politically correct. We don't care if you think that Microwaves101 is not PC, OK?

nodes.name: PCM
nodes.description: pulse code modulation, process control monitor. --

nodes.name: PCS
nodes.description: personal communications systems. Wireless stuff, thankfully, everybody's gotta have it.

nodes.name: PDK
nodes.description: process design kit. What TriQuint or IBM or other open fabs will provide when you design an IC into their foundries.

nodes.name: PDM
nodes.description: power distribution network. --

nodes.name: PDS
nodes.description: personal digital cellular. Digital cell phone standard.

nodes.name: PEC
nodes.description: perfect electrical conductor. See our page on EM fundamentals.

nodes.name: PECVD
nodes.description: plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition. Yet another way to apply films to a semiconductor wafer.

nodes.name: PESA
nodes.description: passive electronically steered antenna. Often uses MEMS phase shifter technology.

nodes.name: PF
nodes.description: pico-Farad. A unit of capacitance, 10E-12 Farads.

nodes.name: PH
nodes.description: pico-Henry. A unit of inductance, 10E-12 Henries.

nodes.name: PHEMT
nodes.description: pseudomorphic high electron mobility transistor. --

nodes.name: PHS
nodes.description: personal handy phone system. Digital cordless phone standard.

nodes.name: PIDOOMA
nodes.description: pulled it directly out of my a$$. A widely accepted method for obtaining a speedy quotation or prediction.

nodes.name: PIN
nodes.description: P-type/intrinsic/N-type. A diode structure often used as an RF control component.

nodes.name: PIND
nodes.description: particle impact noise detection. A way to determine of you have any loose stuff inside your sealed-up module.

nodes.name: PLD
nodes.description: pulsed laser deposition. A laser is used to blast a plume of material that is transferred to a heated substrate.

nodes.name: PLL
nodes.description: phase locked loop. --

nodes.name: PMC
nodes.description: perfect magetic conductor. See our page on EM fundamentals.

nodes.name: PNA
nodes.description: programmable network analyzer. A PNA is a network analyzer that runs the Windows operating system instead of some proprietary interface written in embedded code. It's "programmable" in that you can install applications, network it like a PC, and use a thumb drive to get your data. Than

nodes.name: POS
nodes.description: piece of s###. Like in the following want ad: 1989 Hyundai, POS, $500 or best offer.

nodes.name: PPI
nodes.description: plan position indicator. --

nodes.name: PPM
nodes.description: parts per million. Used to express ratios that are often very much less than 1%

nodes.name: PR
nodes.description: photo-resist. The material that is used used to pattern printed circuits.

nodes.name: PRF
nodes.description: pulse repetition frequency. --

nodes.name: PSB
nodes.description: pink-slip blizzard. If you stay in microwave engineering long enough you will learn what this means...

nodes.name: PSD
nodes.description: phase sensitive detector, power spectral density. --

nodes.name: PSIA
nodes.description: pounds per square inch, absolute. This is pressure, relative to a vacuum.

nodes.name: PSIG
nodes.description: pounds per square inch, gauge. This is pressure, relative to room pressure.

nodes.name: PSK
nodes.description: phase shift keying. A method of transmitting data by modulating the phase of a signal.

nodes.name: PTC
nodes.description: positive temperature coefficient. A thermistor with resistance value increasing with temperature.

nodes.name: PTFE
nodes.description: poly tetra-flouro ethelene. A dielectric material invented in 1938 by Dr. Roy Plunkett at Dupont, used in most RF coax cables and many soft boards.

nodes.name: PTH
nodes.description: plated-through hole. --

nodes.name: PWB
nodes.description: printed wiring board. --

nodes.name: PWM
nodes.description: pulse-width modulation. --

nodes.name: Q
nodes.description: quality factor. A measure of the loss properties of a resonant structure.

nodes.name: QAM
nodes.description: Quadrature amplitude modulation. A form of RF modulation in communications systems

nodes.name: QFN
nodes.description: quad flat-pack no-lead. A type of package for surface mount. Because it has no leads it is nearly impossible to hand solder. "Quad" refers to the geometry where connections are made on all four sides of the package; a "DFN" (dual) has leads only on two opposite sides.

nodes.name: QPSK
nodes.description: quadrature phase shift keying. Also called 4-QAM, this is a method of modulating 2 bits of data at a time to indicate one of four possible states (or symbols), thus doubling the amount of data that can be transmitted over a given bandwidth.

nodes.name: R&D
nodes.description: Research and development. Alternatively, remorse and disappointment.

nodes.name: RAD
nodes.description: radian. Unit of angle. There are 2pi radians in 360 degrees. Rad can also mean bad to a young engineer, which of course means good.

nodes.name: RADAR
nodes.description: radio detection and ranging. --

nodes.name: RBW
nodes.description: resolution bandwidth. An oscilloscope term.

nodes.name: RC
nodes.description: resistance x capacitance. Generally a time constant,

nodes.name: RCS
nodes.description: radar cross-section. --

nodes.name: RCTA
nodes.description: Rear cross traffic alert. An application of automotive radar

nodes.name: RDL
nodes.description: re-distribition layer. Used in RFICs and PWBs to move input/outputs to different positions

nodes.name: RETMA
nodes.description: Radio Electronics Television Manufacturers Association. Defunct group that developed standardized component values that are still used today.

nodes.name: RF
nodes.description: radio frequency. As in "whats the frequency, Dan Rather?"

nodes.name: RFIC
nodes.description: radio frequency integrated circuit. The silicon cousin of MMIC.

nodes.name: RFID
nodes.description: radio frequency identification. What Walmart uses to track inventory.

nodes.name: RHCP
nodes.description: right-hand circularly polarized. Circular polarization is often used in communications systems.

nodes.name: RIE
nodes.description: reactive ion etching. A method of dry etching.

nodes.name: RKE
nodes.description: remote keyless entry. RF device that opens your car door.

nodes.name: RL
nodes.description: return loss. Magnitude of S11 in decibels.

nodes.name: RMS
nodes.description: root-mean-square. Often used to evaluate phase and amplitude errors over many states.

nodes.name: RN
nodes.description: noise resistance. --

nodes.name: ROM
nodes.description: READ ONLY MEMORY. --

nodes.name: RPN
nodes.description: residual phase noise. --

nodes.name: RSS
nodes.description: root-sum-square. Used in evaluating the composite error of many contributors, as opposed to worst-case.

nodes.name: RTA
nodes.description: rapid thermal annealing. --

nodes.name: RTD
nodes.description: resonant tunneling diode, resistor temperature device or detector. One is a new semiconductor used in MMW, the other is like an expensive thermistor

nodes.name: RTOL
nodes.description: room temperature operating life. A reliability test that takes a very long time!

nodes.name: RX
nodes.description: receive. An abbreviation sometimes used for receive.

nodes.name: S
nodes.description: Seimens. A unit of electrical conductance named after German Ernst Werner von Siemens (thanks for the correction, Dr. Bill!)

nodes.name: S-PARAMETERS
nodes.description: scattering matrix parameters. The most commonly used descriptors of a microwave n-port network. See also our page on SNP (S-parameters for n-port networks).

nodes.name: SAG
nodes.description: self-aligned gate. --

nodes.name: SAR
nodes.description: synthetic aperture radar. --

nodes.name: SAS
nodes.description: suspended air stripline. --

nodes.name: SATCOM
nodes.description: satellite communications. Not an acronym, satcom is a portmanteau.

nodes.name: SAW
nodes.description: surface acoustic wave. A phenomenon where electrical energy is converted to a physical displacement on the surface of a solid, similar to a sound wave.

nodes.name: SC
nodes.description: short circuit. Opposite of open circuit.

nodes.name: SDR
nodes.description: software-defined radio. --

nodes.name: SEM
nodes.description: scanning electron microscope. A great toy for seeing stuff smaller than a wavelength of light (<~1 micron).

nodes.name: SFDR
nodes.description: spurious-free dynamic range. A measure of the range of amplitudes that a receiver can process.

nodes.name: SHM
nodes.description: Sub-harmonic mixer. A mixer that internally multiplies the LO signal, usually 2X

nodes.name: SI
nodes.description: semi-insulating. As in a GaAs wafer that has no semiconductor grown on it.

nodes.name: SIC
nodes.description: silicon carbide. One of the possible wafers for growing gallium nitride devices (others include silicon, sapphire, and diamond).

nodes.name: SIGE
nodes.description: silicon germanium. The great white hope of major silicon IC manufacturers for microwave devices (notably IBM).

nodes.name: SILC
nodes.description: stress induced leakage current. --

nodes.name: SINAD
nodes.description: signal plus noise plus distortion, to noise plus distortion ratio. This is a new one on us!

nodes.name: SIR
nodes.description: signal to interference ratio. --

nodes.name: SIT
nodes.description: static induction transistor. A new microwave semiconductor device with a buried gate.

nodes.name: SIW
nodes.description: substrate integrated waveguide. A way to make dielectrically-loaded transmission lines on a single-layer substrate.

nodes.name: SLC
nodes.description: single-layer cap. Capacitor usually used in chip-and-wire construction, has excellent microwave properties.

nodes.name: SMA
nodes.description: subminiature type A. A ubiquitous microwave connector.

nodes.name: SMD
nodes.description: surface mount device. As opposed to a "through-hole" device.

nodes.name: SMMIC
nodes.description: sub-millimeterwave MMIC. A MMIC component that performs above 300 GHz.

nodes.name: SMT
nodes.description: surface mount technology. When parts are soldered to the top surface of a board, without leads soldering into through-holes. Generally, all microwave PWBs use SMT because it offers better impedance control.

nodes.name: SNA
nodes.description: scalar network analyzer. Used to measure return loss and gain, magnitude only.

nodes.name: SNAFU
nodes.description: situation normal, all f**ed up. One of two excellent acronyms that are the legacy of the greatest generation (see fubar).

nodes.name: SNF
nodes.description: Spherical near field. A type of antenna measurement

nodes.name: SNR
nodes.description: signal-to-noise ratio. --

nodes.name: SOA
nodes.description: safe operating area. The combination of voltage, current, and temperature where you don't blow up your expensive power transistor.

nodes.name: SOD
nodes.description: source-over-drain. A layout option for multi-finger power FETs.

nodes.name: SOG
nodes.description: source-over-gate. A layout option for multi-finger power FETs.

nodes.name: SOI
nodes.description: second-order intercept. --

nodes.name: SOIC
nodes.description: small outline integrated circuit. A type of package

nodes.name: SOLT
nodes.description: short-open-load-through. A type of network measurement calibration.

nodes.name: SOT
nodes.description: small outline transistor. A type of package

nodes.name: SOTA
nodes.description: sate-of-the-art. Perhaps one of the most overused acronyms in engineering.

nodes.name: SOW
nodes.description: statement of work. In a contract, a list of the stuff you have to do to get paid.

nodes.name: SP3T
nodes.description: single-pole, three throw. A switch with one input and three outputs, or vice-versa.

nodes.name: SPC
nodes.description: statistical process control. --

nodes.name: SPDT
nodes.description: single-pole, double throw. A switch with one input and two outputs, or vice-versa.

nodes.name: SPI
nodes.description: Serial peripheral interface. Commonly used to send data from a controller to a peripheral

nodes.name: SPST
nodes.description: single-pole, single throw. The simplest possible switch.

nodes.name: SRF
nodes.description: Self-resonant frequency. A parameter that you need to specify when you order lumped element components.

nodes.name: SRR
nodes.description: split ring resonator. A technique used to realize metamaterials.

nodes.name: SS
nodes.description: small-signal. Low-enough power level where linear operation is assured.

nodes.name: SSB
nodes.description: single-sideband. A type of receiver or downconverter that eliminates one sideband.

nodes.name: SSG
nodes.description: small-signal gain. Output power divided by input power, at a signal level that does not compress the gain.

nodes.name: SSMA
nodes.description: sub-subminiature type A. A rarely used type of microwave connector.

nodes.name: SSPA
nodes.description: solid-state power amplifier. --

nodes.name: STALO
nodes.description: stable local oscillator. --

nodes.name: STAR
nodes.description: simultaneous transmit and receive. --

nodes.name: STC
nodes.description: sensitivity time control. Another way to say "gain control". Thanks to Frank!

nodes.name: STE
nodes.description: special test equipment. Dedicated test equipment for a high-value job.

nodes.name: SUV
nodes.description: small unit verification. --

nodes.name: SWAG
nodes.description: scientific wild-assed guess. Slightly more accurate than a WAG. Thanks to Doug!

nodes.name: SWAP
nodes.description: size, weight and power. --

nodes.name: SWAP-C
nodes.description: size, weight and power and cost. --

nodes.name: SWAPP
nodes.description: size, weight and PowerPoint. Yes, we made this up.

nodes.name: SWR
nodes.description: standing wave ratio. An arcane way of specifying impedance mismatches, dating back to the old days when the old guys used standing wave meters because they didn't have network analyzers. You'll still hear people talking about "2:1 VSWR over all phase angles" instead of 10dB r

nodes.name: TAB
nodes.description: tape automated bonding. --

nodes.name: TACS
nodes.description: total access communication system. Analog cell phone standard.

nodes.name: TC
nodes.description: temperature coefficient or thermo-compression or temperature cycle. A type of wirebond employing heat.

nodes.name: TCAD
nodes.description: Technology computer aided design. Tools used by technology developers (as opposed to circuit designers using ECAD)

nodes.name: TCC
nodes.description: temperature coefficient of capacitance. --

nodes.name: TCE
nodes.description: temperature coefficient of resistance (CTE is also used). An approximate measure of how a solid expands or contracts over temperature.

nodes.name: TCR
nodes.description: temperature coefficient of resistivity. An approximate measure of how a resistor varies over temperature.

nodes.name: TCXO
nodes.description: temperature-compensated crystal oscillator. --

nodes.name: TDD
nodes.description: time division duplex. --

nodes.name: TDMA
nodes.description: time division multiple access. --

nodes.name: TDU
nodes.description: time delay unit. A network that provides switchable path lengths for delaying a signal by a specified time.

nodes.name: TE
nodes.description: transverse electric. A type of waveform associated with waveguides, requires only one closed conductor.

nodes.name: TE
nodes.description: test equipment. --

nodes.name: TEM
nodes.description: transverse electromagnetic. A type of waveform that requires two conductors, such as coax or stripline.

nodes.name: TFC
nodes.description: thin-film capacitor. Capacitors that are formed using thin-film processes, often called MIM (metal-insulator-metal) caps.

nodes.name: TFMSL
nodes.description: thin-film microstrip line. This type of transmission line is often used on silicon RF devices. Because silicon is not a great insulator, a dielectric layer such as BCB is deposited, then metal is patterned on top to define circuitry.

nodes.name: TFN
nodes.description: thin-film network. A circuit that is processed on a substrate by depositing layers of metals (and sometimes insulators), using etching (and sometimes plating) operations to define features.

nodes.name: TFR
nodes.description: thin-film resistor. Resistors that are formed using thin-film techniques.

nodes.name: THZ
nodes.description: terahertz. The region of electro-magnetic spectrum between millimeterwaves and light; 1012 Hertz.

nodes.name: TIA
nodes.description: trans-impedance amplifier. --

nodes.name: TLA
nodes.description: three letter acronym. As in, FBI, EWR, WWW, DOS. Cheer up, there are only 17,576 possible TLAs!

nodes.name: TM
nodes.description: transverse magnetic. A type of waveform associated with waveguides, requires only one closed conductor.

nodes.name: TN
nodes.description: equivalent noise temperature. An alternate method of expressing noise figure, often used by scientists with thick glasses.

nodes.name: TNC
nodes.description: threaded Neill-Concelman. A connector developed a long time ago that you might find on older equipment.

nodes.name: TOI
nodes.description: third-order intercept. --

nodes.name: TPMS
nodes.description: tire pressure monitoring system. A future government mandate to protect fat stupid people from SUV rollovers

nodes.name: TR, T/R
nodes.description: transmit receive. A transmit receive element, module, or system.

nodes.name: TRF
nodes.description: tuned radio frequency (receiver). A radio architecture from the early 20th century. Mostly abandoned when the superhet was developed.

nodes.name: TRL
nodes.description: through reflect line. A type of network measurement calibration.

nodes.name: TS
nodes.description: thermo-sonic. A type of wirebond employing heat and sound waves.

nodes.name: TSA
nodes.description: tapered slot antenna. Also known as the Vivaldi antenna.

nodes.name: TSSOP
nodes.description: thin shrink small outline package. One of many package styles.

nodes.name: TTD
nodes.description: true time delay. A type of phase shifter employing switched lines that are multiple wavelengths long.

nodes.name: TTL
nodes.description: transistor-transistor logic. Old-school logic standard.

nodes.name: TVAC
nodes.description: thermal vacuum chamber. Used for simulating the conditions of space flight on electronics.

nodes.name: TVRO
nodes.description: television receive only. --

nodes.name: TWT
nodes.description: traveling wave tube. A form of microwave power amplifier. Provides tens of watts to several thousand watts, often with poor noise characteristics but high efficiency. Named after a guy named Wave who was on the road a lot.

nodes.name: TX
nodes.description: transmit. An abbreviation sometimes used for transmit.

nodes.name: UAV
nodes.description: unmanned air vehicle. This is the future the air force whether they want to admit it or not.

nodes.name: UCA
nodes.description: uniform circular array. One way to group antennas into an array.

nodes.name: UE
nodes.description: user equipment. As in, a phone in a mobile network. Or the Unknown Editor.

nodes.name: UGA
nodes.description: uniform grid array. Another way to group antennas into an array.

nodes.name: ULA
nodes.description: uniform linear array. Yet another way to group antennas into an array.

nodes.name: UUT
nodes.description: unit under test. See device under test.

nodes.name: UVF
nodes.description: unverified failure. A test failure that occurred once but won't repeat, so you can't determine its cause. In the satellite business, any hardware with a UVF can't be launched without approval from the Chief Engineer, Customer, and insurance company.

nodes.name: UWB
nodes.description: ultra wideband. several octaves.

nodes.name: V-POL
nodes.description: vertical polarization. --

nodes.name: VBR

nodes.name: VPO

nodes.name: System-level design
nodes.description: System-level design is the foundational phase of engineering where the entire functional architecture of a complex electronic or RF product is defined and partitioned into major subsystems. This process involves establishing top-level performance requirements, allocating critical budgets—such as power consumption, noise figure, link margin, and dynamic range—across the defined blocks (e.g., transceivers, processors, power management units). Key activities include defining standardized internal interfaces, managing system complexity, and executing crucial trade-off analyses (e.g., latency vs. throughput, cost vs. component linearity) to ensure that the integrated solution meets overall mission specifications and provides a verified, feasible blueprint for subsequent detailed component-level implementation.

nodes.name: Link Budget Analysis
nodes.description: Power balance across the communication path.

nodes.name: analysis
nodes.description: The systematic process of examining complex electrical systems, circuits, and electromagnetic wave propagation using mathematical models and fundamental engineering laws, including Kirchhoff's laws, Maxwell's equations, and network theory. In RF and high-speed electrical engineering, techniques such as S-parameter derivation, Fourier transformation, steady-state and transient response modeling, and impedance matching calculations are crucial for predicting system performance metrics like gain, bandwidth, noise figure, and stability. This predictive characterization is essential for validating system architecture, optimizing component selection, and ensuring compliance with established performance specifications across the frequency spectrum.

nodes.name: Dynamic Range and Linearity
nodes.description: System linearity and compression performance.

nodes.name: Noise Performance
nodes.description: Noise performance in RF systems quantifies the system's ability to receive and process weak signals relative to the inherent electrical noise. Key metrics include Noise Figure (NF), which measures the degradation of the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) caused by components, and system sensitivity, which dictates the minimum detectable signal power. Optimizing noise performance, particularly in the receiver front-end, is crucial for maximizing range, data rates, and overall link quality.

nodes.name: MIMO and Beamforming
nodes.description: MISSING

nodes.name: Simulation & Modeling
nodes.description: Simulation & Modeling Simulation and modeling involve using mathematical representations and specialized software tools, such as MATLAB, Keysight ADS, or Ansys HFSS, to predict and analyze the behavior of RF circuits, components, channels, and full communication systems before physical fabrication. This crucial phase allows engineers to rapidly optimize design parameters, assess the impact of non-linearities, estimate link budget performance, and validate complex signal processing algorithms, thereby accelerating development cycles and minimizing hardware prototyping costs.

nodes.name: ASK
nodes.description: Amplitude-shift keying (ASK) is a digital modulation technique that transmits digital data by changing the amplitude of a carrier wave. In its simplest form (binary ASK), a digital '1' is represented by a high-amplitude carrier wave, and a '0' is represented by the absence of a signal (zero amplitude). This method is often used in simple, low-cost applications like garage door openers and RFID tags.

nodes.name: QAM
nodes.description: QAM Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) is a high-order digital modulation scheme that simultaneously varies both the amplitude and the phase of the carrier signal, representing digital symbols as points on the complex I/Q plane. By combining both parameters, QAM systems (e.g., 16-QAM, 64-QAM) significantly increase spectral efficiency, allowing higher data rates, but this increased efficiency demands a higher signal-to-noise ratio and makes the system more sensitive to channel non-linearities and noise floor fluctuations.

nodes.name: OFDM
nodes.description: OFDM (Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiplexing) is a digital modulation technique that splits a high-speed data stream into many parallel, lower-speed sub-streams. Each sub-stream is transmitted on a different, equally spaced sub-carrier frequency. The sub-carriers are made 'orthogonal' so they overlap without interfering with each other, which makes the system highly resistant to frequency-selective fading and spectrally efficient.

nodes.name: NOMA
nodes.description: NOMA allows multiple users to share the same time/frequency resource block by employing power-domain multiplexing, where distinct power levels are assigned to different users based on their channel conditions. The receiver utilizes Successive Interference Cancellation (SIC) to decode the strongest signal first and then subtract it to decode weaker signals, significantly improving system throughput and spectral efficiency, particularly in scenarios with disparate channel gains.

nodes.name: Antenna Parameters
nodes.description: Antenna Parameters are quantitative metrics used to characterize the operational performance and suitability of an antenna for a specific communication link or system. Essential parameters include gain (directional power increase), directivity, radiation pattern (defining spatial energy distribution), efficiency, polarization, operating bandwidth, and impedance matching (quantified by S11 or VSWR).

nodes.name: Antenna Types
nodes.description: Antenna Types refers to the fundamental physical structures and architectures used to radiate electromagnetic energy, such as apertures, wires, microstrip patches, and arrays, where the specific type selected is optimized based on criteria like operating frequency, required physical size, environmental ruggedness, and desired directivity characteristics.

nodes.name: NF Measurments
nodes.description: Desensitization Desensitization is a receiver degradation where a strong, unwanted interfering signal drives the receiver's front-end (LNA or mixer) into non-linear operation, causing a significant rise in the effective noise floor and potentially generating intermodulation products, resulting in the masking or "desensing" of the weak desired signal.

nodes.name: Desensitization
nodes.description: Desensitization Desensitization is a receiver degradation where a strong, unwanted interfering signal drives the receiver's front-end (LNA or mixer) into non-linear operation, causing a significant rise in the effective noise floor and potentially generating intermodulation products, resulting in the masking or "desensing" of the weak desired signal.

nodes.name: cascaded effects
nodes.description: Cascaded effects describe how performance parameters, primarily gain, noise figure, and linearity (IP3), combine when multiple RF stages are connected in series. The Friis formulas govern these effects, showing that the overall system noise figure is heavily dominated by the noise and gain of the first stage, while the system's linearity (IP3) is often constrained by the lowest compression point occurring in subsequent high-gain stages.

nodes.name: Thermal Noise
nodes.description: Cascaded effects describe how performance parameters, primarily gain, noise figure, and linearity (IP3), combine when multiple RF stages are connected in series. The Friis formulas govern these effects, showing that the overall system noise figure is heavily dominated by the noise and gain of the first stage, while the system's linearity (IP3) is often constrained by the lowest compression point occurring in subsequent high-gain stages.

nodes.name: measurement
nodes.description: Measurement in RF engineering involves the precise characterization of components and system performance parameters, utilizing specialized instrumentation like VNAs, spectrum analyzers, and noise figure meters, to ensure designs meet specification and standards. Key parameters measured include gain, impedance matching (S-parameters), power output (P1dB), noise figure, and spectral purity (harmonics and spurious emissions), forming the basis for design verification and quality control.

nodes.name: Friis Formula
nodes.description: Measurement in RF engineering involves the precise characterization of components and system performance parameters, utilizing specialized instrumentation like VNAs, spectrum analyzers, and noise figure meters, to ensure designs meet specification and standards. Key parameters measured include gain, impedance matching (S-parameters), power output (P1dB), noise figure, and spectral purity (harmonics and spurious emissions), forming the basis for design verification and quality control.

nodes.name: RF Communications Fundamentals
nodes.description: Foundational concepts in RF communication systems.

nodes.name: Signal Types
nodes.description: Classification of analog and digital modulation schemes.

nodes.name: Frequency Spectrum
nodes.description: Organization and use of frequency bands.

nodes.name: Modulation and Demodulation Concepts
nodes.description: Signal synchronization and recovery principles.

nodes.name: RF Front-End Architecture
nodes.description: Signal chain from antenna to ADC/DAC.

nodes.name: Propagation and Channel Fundamentals
nodes.description: Mechanisms of RF signal transmission and fading.

nodes.name: Antenna Fundamentals
nodes.description: Antennas are reciprocal transducers that serve as the critical interface between a transmission line and free-space, efficiently radiating or capturing electromagnetic energy. They operate based on Maxwell's equations, accelerating electrical charges to produce propagating electromagnetic waves, characterized by specific radiation patterns, gain (measured in dBi or dBd), efficiency, and impedance matching. The fundamental operation depends on the physical dimensions, particularly in relation to the wavelength of the operating frequency, dictating characteristics like resonance and polarization (linear, circular, or elliptical) crucial for reliable wireless communication links.

nodes.name: RF System Design Parameters
nodes.description: RF system design is fundamentally governed by parameters such as Link Budget analysis, which calculates the total gain and loss from transmitter to receiver to ensure adequate Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) or Bit Error Rate (BER) for reliable communication. Key electrical specifications include transmit power (EIRP/ERP), receiver sensitivity (minimum detectable signal), noise figure (NF), and dynamic range, all of which directly impact the achievable communication distance and data rate. Other critical factors involve frequency allocation, channel bandwidth, antenna gain and pattern, and regulatory compliance (e.g., FCC, ETSI limits) concerning spurious emissions and maximum power output, defining the practical and legal boundaries of the system's performance.

nodes.name: Linearity and Interference Robustness
nodes.description: Intermodulation and blocking behavior.

nodes.name: Power Efficiency and Thermal Design
nodes.description: Efficiency optimization and thermal management.

nodes.name: Impedance Matching and Stability
nodes.description: Stability and impedance transformations.

nodes.name: Performance Metrics and Measurements
nodes.description: System performance quantification and testing.

nodes.name: Spectral Performance
nodes.description: Bandwidth and emissions characterization.

nodes.name: Receiver Performance
nodes.description: Receiver performance in RF systems quantifies a receiver's ability to successfully extract desired information from incoming RF signals, particularly in the presence of noise and interference. Key metrics include Sensitivity, which defines the minimum detectable signal power often limited by the receiver's intrinsic Noise Figure (NF); Selectivity, measured by adjacent channel rejection, which describes the ability to filter out signals close in frequency; and Linearity, assessed using the Third-Order Intercept Point (IP3) or Spurious-Free Dynamic Range (SFDR), which determines the receiver's resilience to strong interfering signals causing intermodulation distortion. High performance requires minimizing NF and maximizing both selectivity and dynamic range to ensure reliable signal reception across various operating conditions.

nodes.name: Bit-Level Metrics
nodes.description: Bit-Level Metrics Bit-level metrics focus on the accuracy and quality of the transmission medium at the most fundamental level, measuring how accurately individual bits or symbols are successfully transferred across a communications link. The primary metric is the Bit Error Rate (BER), which quantifies the ratio of incorrectly received bits to the total number of bits transmitted, often expressed as a power of ten (e.g., $10^{-6}$). Related metrics include the Symbol Error Rate (SER) and the required $E_b/N_0$ (Energy per bit to Noise power spectral density ratio), which is the minimum signal quality required at the receiver input to achieve a target BER.

nodes.name: System-Level Metrics
nodes.description: System-Level Metrics System-level metrics quantify the overall user experience and macroscopic performance of the entire communication system, incorporating the effects of protocols, network load, and processing delays, moving beyond simple physical layer errors. Key system metrics include throughput, measured in bits per second (e.g., Mbps or Gbps), which represents the effective data rate delivered to the application layer, and latency, which measures the total time delay incurred by data moving from source to destination. Other crucial measures are link availability, which is the percentage of time the system is operational, and spectral efficiency, which is the throughput normalized by occupied bandwidth (b/s/Hz).

nodes.name: Nonlinear Distortion Metrics
nodes.description: These quantitative measurements assess the spurious spectral components generated when an RF device, such as an amplifier, operates outside its linear region, causing spectral regrowth. The most common metrics include Harmonic Distortion (HD) and Total Harmonic Distortion (THD), which quantify integer multiples of the fundamental frequency. Crucially, Intermodulation Distortion (IMD) characterizes the mixing of multiple input signals, typically measured using the Second and Third Order Intercept Points (IP2 and IP3) to predict a system's dynamic range. Further system-level evaluation uses the 1 dB Compression Point (P1dB) to define the maximum linear output power capability, and Adjacent Channel Power Ratio (ACPR) to measure spectral power leakage into neighboring communication bands.

nodes.name: Time-Variant Metrics
nodes.description: Time-variant metrics are measurements or statistical characteristics quantifying systems or channels whose underlying properties are not constant over the observation interval, indicating a non-stationary or statistically non-ergodic process. In RF engineering, these typically describe the dynamic behavior of wireless links subject to movement and environmental changes, where the channel transfer function $H(t)$ is explicitly dependent on time. Key examples include the instantaneous Channel Impulse Response (CIR), Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) in a mobile environment, and fading envelope statistics. Accurate characterization requires time-domain analysis, predictive modeling, and adaptive signal processing techniques to track rapid fluctuations, often leveraging statistics like the autocorrelation function to determine the maximum rate of change, such as the Doppler spread.

nodes.name: RF Testing and Validation
nodes.description: Verification and measurement environments.

nodes.name: Test Equipment
nodes.description: These specialized instruments are critical tools for the characterization, verification, and troubleshooting of electrical circuits and RF systems, operating across both the time and frequency domains. Key equipment includes signal generators, which produce controlled test stimuli; oscilloscopes, which analyze signals in the time domain for timing and amplitude measurements; spectrum analyzers, which evaluate frequency content, noise, and modulation quality; and vector network analyzers (VNAs), which characterize component impedance, phase response, and scattering parameters (S-parameters). Other essential devices, such as power meters and frequency counters, ensure precise measurement of fundamental physical and electrical parameters, guaranteeing that circuits and systems meet rigorous design specifications and operational standards.

nodes.name: Test Environments
nodes.description: Test environments in RF communications are controlled settings designed to accurately characterize system performance, component behavior, and compliance with regulatory standards. Key environments include anechoic chambers, which simulate free-space conditions by absorbing reflections to measure antenna patterns and EIRP; reverberation chambers, which create a statistically uniform, multi-path field for immunity and shielding effectiveness testing; and open area test sites (OATS), which provide a large, low-reflection outdoor space primarily used for radiated emissions compliance testing. These environments manage electromagnetic interference and environmental factors like temperature and humidity to ensure reproducible and validated measurement results crucial for system design and certification.

nodes.name: Automation and Control
nodes.description: Automation and Control in RF testing involve using software defined instruments, scripting languages (like Python or MATLAB), and standardized interfaces (like GPIB or LAN) to execute complex measurement sequences without manual intervention. This dramatically increases test throughput, ensures repeatability, reduces human error, and facilitates remote operation and continuous monitoring of critical RF infrastructure or production lines.

nodes.name: Calibration and Verification
nodes.description: Instrument calibration and traceability.

nodes.name: OTA MIMO/mmWave Testing
nodes.description: Over-The-Air (OTA) testing is mandatory for characterizing Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) and millimeter-wave (mmWave) devices because traditional conductive testing fails to capture the spatial interactions and antenna array performance crucial at these frequencies.
