It is a critical metric for system design, calculated based on the available link margin, taking into account statistical propagation impairments such as rain fade, atmospheric absorption, multipath fading, and interference, often targeted at demanding levels like 99.999%.

nodes.name: AM-AM
nodes.description: AM-AM AM-AM (Amplitude Modulation to Amplitude Modulation conversion) describes a non-linear effect in RF power amplifiers where an increase in the input signal power causes a reduction in the amplifier's effective gain (gain compression), meaning the output amplitude is no longer linearly proportional to the input amplitude. This compression distorts the envelope of the modulated signal, introducing self-interference and spectral regrowth, which is especially detrimental to high-order QAM and OFDM systems.

nodes.name: AM-PM
nodes.description: AM-PM AM-PM (Amplitude Modulation to Phase Modulation conversion) is a non-linear distortion where changes in the amplitude of the input RF signal cause unintended corresponding shifts in the phase of the output signal. This effect is caused by the dependence of active device junction capacitances or transit times on the instantaneous input voltage, severely degrading the accuracy of phase-sensitive modulation schemes and resulting in high Error Vector Magnitude (EVM).

nodes.name: IMD
nodes.description: IMD Intermodulation Distortion (IMD) occurs when two or more distinct frequencies ($\text{f}_1, \text{f}_2$) pass through a non-linear device, resulting in the creation of spurious output frequencies that are linear combinations of the input frequencies ($m\text{f}_1 \pm n\text{f}_2$). Third-order intermodulation products ($\text{IM}_3$) are the most problematic because they fall close to the desired operational bandwidth, leading to unwanted spectral energy, receiver desensitization, and adjacent channel interference.

nodes.name: Group delay
nodes.description: Group delay Group delay is the measure of the time delay experienced by the modulation envelope (the group of frequencies surrounding the carrier) as it propagates through a device or channel, defined mathematically as the negative derivative of the phase shift with respect to angular frequency ($\tau_g = -d\phi/d\omega$). For distortionless transmission, the group delay must be constant across the signal bandwidth; any deviation indicates non-linear phase response.

nodes.name: envelope delay distortion
nodes.description: envelope delay distortion Envelope delay distortion is the condition where the group delay is not constant across the signal bandwidth, meaning different frequency components within the signal envelope experience different transmission times. This varying time delay causes the pulse shape to spread out or become distorted, leading to temporal smearing of symbols and resulting in intersymbol interference (ISI), particularly challenging in wideband high-speed data links.

nodes.name: Spectrum analyzer
nodes.description: Spectrum analyzer A spectrum analyzer is an electronic test instrument that measures and graphically displays the magnitude (power level) of an input signal as a function of frequency, effectively translating the signal into the frequency domain. It is fundamentally used to characterize spectral purity, measure occupied bandwidth, quantify harmonics and spurious emissions, and assess interference and noise floor levels in RF systems.

nodes.name: VNA
nodes.description: VNA A Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) is a specialized test instrument used to measure the S-parameters (scattering parameters) of passive and active RF components, quantifying how power is reflected, absorbed, and transmitted by a device under test (DUT). Crucially, the VNA measures both the magnitude and phase of these parameters, enabling precise characterization of impedance matching, phase linearity, gain, and return loss up to millimeter-wave frequencies.

nodes.name: generator
nodes.description: generator An RF signal generator, often a Vector Signal Generator (VSG), is an instrument used to produce highly controlled and precise electromagnetic waves, ranging from continuous wave (CW) tones to complex, digitally modulated waveforms (e.g., QAM, OFDM). These generated signals are essential for stimulating components, characterizing receiver sensitivity, testing link budgets, and validating demodulator performance in controlled laboratory environments.

nodes.name: oscilloscope
nodes.description: oscilloscope An oscilloscope is a primary time-domain measurement tool that visualizes voltage or current changes over time, displaying the waveform shape, amplitude, and temporal characteristics. In modern RF testing, high-bandwidth digital oscilloscopes are used for baseband signal analysis, timing analysis of digital interfaces, and, when paired with downconverters, for deep acquisition and analysis of modulated waveforms and transient RF events.

nodes.name: Anechoic
nodes.description: Anechoic The term anechoic describes a chamber or test environment that is deliberately designed to absorb electromagnetic energy, thus minimizing or eliminating reflections from walls, floor, and ceiling. Anechoic chambers simulate "free space" conditions, making them essential for accurate, repeatable Over-The-Air (OTA) measurements such as antenna radiation patterns, Effective Isotropic Radiated Power (EIRP), and radiated susceptibility testing.

nodes.name: conducted
nodes.description: conducted Conducted testing refers to the measurement of RF signals and characteristics that are contained and channeled through physical transmission media, such as coaxial cables, waveguides, or PCB traces, directly connecting the device under test (DUT) to the instrumentation. This method isolates component-level performance, allowing precise measurement of metrics like S-parameters, noise figure, and linearity without the complicating variables of the air interface.

nodes.name: OTA
nodes.description: OTA Over-The-Air (OTA) testing involves characterizing the performance of a complete wireless device by measuring its integrated radiated characteristics, including the combined efficiency of the antenna, RF front end, and system software. Critical OTA metrics include Total Radiated Power (TRP) and Total Isotropic Sensitivity (TIS), which quantify how well the device transmits and receives signals in a realistic spatial environment.

nodes.name: environmental
nodes.description: environmental Environmental testing in RF communication involves subjecting wireless equipment to controlled extremes of non-electrical stress factors, such as high/low temperature, humidity, vibration, or shock, while simultaneously monitoring RF performance metrics like output power or link quality. This process ensures the operational reliability and resilience of the equipment when deployed in harsh or real-world operating conditions outside of a climate-controlled lab.

nodes.name: SCPI
nodes.description: SCPI SCPI (Standard Commands for Programmable Instruments) is a common, ASCII-based language standard used for remotely controlling and automating test and measurement equipment via interfaces like GPIB, Ethernet, or USB. It provides a consistent, hierarchical command syntax, allowing engineers to write scripts that can configure instruments, initiate measurements, and retrieve data regardless of the specific vendor or model of the device.

nodes.name: PyVISA
nodes.description: PyVISA PyVISA is an open-source Python package that provides an easy-to-use, standardized interface for controlling various types of scientific and engineering instruments using the Virtual Instrument Software Architecture (VISA) framework. It abstracts the complexities of the underlying physical communication protocols (like GPIB, USBTMC, or Ethernet Sockets), enabling rapid development of automated testing sequences using Python scripting.

nodes.name: LabVIEW
nodes.description: LabVIEW LabVIEW (Laboratory Virtual Instrument Engineering Workbench) is a highly specialized graphical system design platform from NI (National Instruments) that uses a visual "block diagram" programming paradigm for data acquisition, instrument control, and measurement automation. It is widely utilized in RF testing due to its strong integration with PXI modular instrumentation and its ability to create complex, real-time user interfaces for test management and data analysis.

nodes.name: HIL
nodes.description: HIL Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) is a testing methodology where actual physical hardware, such as an RF transceiver or digital modem, is connected to a sophisticated simulator that replicates the real-world communication channel and environment in real time. This technique allows designers to validate the performance of the DUT under conditions—like complex fading, high interference, or specific mobility scenarios—that are too dangerous, expensive, or difficult to reproduce live.

nodes.name: Beamforming
nodes.description: Beamforming Beamforming is an advanced signal processing technique applied to antenna arrays where the phase and amplitude of signals transmitted or received by each element are weighted and combined to create a constructive interference pattern focused in a specific direction. This spatial filtering technique dramatically increases the effective radiated power (EIRP) towards the intended receiver while minimizing interference to others, central to achieving high spectral efficiency in MIMO and 5G/6G systems.

nodes.name: OTA chamber
nodes.description: OTA chamber An Over-The-Air (OTA) chamber is a specialized, usually anechoic, shielded enclosure designed to facilitate the measurement of the integrated radiated performance of wireless devices without physical connections. These chambers employ carefully calibrated antenna setups, precise positioners (turntables), and measurement equipment to characterize parameters such as Total Radiated Power (TRP), Total Isotropic Sensitivity (TIS), and 3D radiation patterns accurately.

nodes.name: channel sounding
nodes.description: channel sounding The process of measuring and characterizing the physical propagation environment between a transmitter and a receiver by transmitting known probe signals and analyzing the received signals. This provides essential data regarding the channel impulse response, power delay profile, path loss, delay spread, and Doppler shift, which are critical inputs for optimizing advanced communication techniques like adaptive equalization, pre-coding, and beamforming weights.

nodes.name: 3GPP
nodes.description: 3GPP The Third Generation Partnership Project is a global collaboration of standards organizations that develops specifications for globally applicable mobile broadband technologies, including GSM, UMTS, LTE, and 5G (New Radio). 3GPP is responsible for defining the core network architecture, radio access technology (RAN) interfaces, and complex protocol layer stacks necessary to ensure the interoperability and forward evolution of cellular systems worldwide.

nodes.name: IEEE
nodes.description: IEEE The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers is a global professional organization that develops standards across various technological domains, with its 802 committee being highly influential in RF communications. Key IEEE standards include the 802.11 family (Wi-Fi), 802.15 (WPAN/Bluetooth), and standards for Ethernet and wired networks, defining the physical and MAC layer operation of wireless local and metropolitan area networks.

nodes.name: FCC
nodes.description: FCC The U.S. Federal Communications Commission is the independent government agency that regulates interstate and international communications in the United States, including managing the allocation of the radio frequency spectrum. The FCC enforces strict rules regarding RF device certification, maximum power output limits, spurious emissions, and licensing requirements to prevent interference and promote efficient, orderly use of the public airwaves.

nodes.name: ETSI conformance
nodes.description: ETSI conformance Conformance refers to the demonstration that a wireless device or communication protocol adheres strictly to the mandatory technical standards and testing specifications established by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI). Achieving ETSI conformance is required for equipment intended to be deployed and legally operated within the European market, ensuring interoperability, quality of service, and adherence to regional regulatory frameworks.

nodes.name: Drive testing
nodes.description: Drive testing A methodology used to empirically assess the real-world performance, quality, and coverage of a mobile cellular network by collecting key metrics while driving through the service area using specialized monitoring equipment. Data collected typically includes received signal strength (RSRP), interference levels (SINR), throughput, handover success rates, and dropped call rates, which are then used for network optimization and planning.

nodes.name: spectrum scanning
nodes.description: spectrum scanning The process of systematically monitoring and analyzing radio frequency activity across a defined range of frequencies using a spectrum analyzer or specialized scanning receiver. This technique is crucial for identifying active transmitters, measuring spectral occupancy, locating sources of interference, verifying regulatory compliance of existing systems, and gathering intelligence about the radio environment.

nodes.name: MTBF
nodes.description: MTBF Mean Time Between Failures is a reliability metric representing the predicted average time expected to elapse between inherent failures of a system or component during normal operation. In critical RF infrastructure like base stations or satellite transponders, a high MTBF indicates hardware robustness and longevity, minimizing maintenance costs and ensuring consistent network uptime.

nodes.name: telemetry
nodes.description: telemetry The automated process of measuring physical or performance parameters at a remote source and transmitting that data, often via an RF link, back to a central receiving station for recording and analysis. Telemetry is essential for monitoring the operational status of satellites, remote weather stations, industrial IoT sensors, and distant communications infrastructure.

nodes.name: predictive maintenance
nodes.description: predictive maintenance A data-driven maintenance strategy utilizing continuous monitoring, sensor readings, and analytical algorithms (often leveraging telemetry data) to anticipate equipment failure before it occurs. For complex RF systems, this allows operators to schedule proactive maintenance on components like power amplifiers or antennas precisely when early signs of degradation are detected, maximizing operational efficiency and reducing unexpected downtime.

nodes.name: Spatial multiplexing
nodes.description: Spatial multiplexing A key Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) technique where independent, unique data streams are simultaneously transmitted over the same frequency channel using distinct transmit antennas. By exploiting the spatial dimension created by uncorrelated propagation paths (multipath), the receiver can separate the streams, thereby linearly increasing the spectral efficiency and capacity of the wireless link.

nodes.name: CSI
nodes.description: CSI Channel State Information is the knowledge describing how a transmitted RF signal propagates from the transmitter to the receiver, including the effects of fading, scattering, and power attenuation. Accurate CSI is fundamentally necessary for advanced wireless systems, enabling optimization techniques like adaptive modulation and coding, beamforming, and spatial multiplexing to maximize throughput and link reliability.

nodes.name: beamforming
nodes.description: beamforming A technique that focuses radiated or received RF energy in a specific spatial direction by applying precise phase and amplitude weights across elements of an antenna array. This results in significant array gain, enhancing the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) for the intended user while minimizing power radiated elsewhere, making it central to high-frequency and massive MIMO deployments.

nodes.name: TBD
nodes.description: TBD (To Be Determined) is a standard placeholder designation used in technical documentation, specifications, and requirements lists to explicitly indicate that a specific value, parameter, design feature, or piece of information has not yet been finalized, measured, or assigned and requires future action or resolution.

nodes.name: Channel emulation
nodes.description: Channel emulation The laboratory replication of real-world wireless propagation phenomena, such as fading, multipath delay spread, time variance (Doppler), and path loss, using specialized hardware called channel sounders or emulators. This controlled simulation environment allows engineers to rigorously test and validate the performance of complex communication algorithms, protocols, and hardware under repeatable, realistic RF conditions.

nodes.name: DSP
nodes.description: DSP Digital Signal Processing involves the application of mathematical algorithms to sampled and digitized signals to perform essential communication functions. In RF systems, DSP handles baseband operations including modulation, demodulation, filtering, equalization, error correction coding, and implementation of complex antenna array techniques, forming the computational core of Software Defined Radios (SDR).

nodes.name: hardware-in-loop
nodes.description: hardware-in-loop A simulation methodology where a physical hardware component, such as an ASIC or an RF front-end, is connected and integrated directly into a real-time, closed-loop simulation environment, often involving channel emulation or complex protocol stacks running on a simulator. This allows for the rigorous testing and validation of the hardware’s performance and interactions under realistic operational stresses before deployment.

nodes.name: LEO/GEO links
nodes.description: LEO/GEO links RF communication pathways involving satellites in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) or Geostationary Orbit (GEO). LEO links offer low latency due to shorter distances but require continuous beam handover and tracking, while GEO links provide continuous coverage over vast areas but suffer from high latency and significant path loss due to the 36,000 km distance.

nodes.name: Doppler
nodes.description: Doppler The apparent shift in the frequency of an RF carrier signal caused by the relative motion between the transmitter and the receiver, proportionally changing with relative velocity. High Doppler shifts are a critical challenge in high-mobility wireless scenarios (e.g., high-speed rail or LEO satellite links) as they necessitate precise estimation and compensation techniques in the receiver to maintain signal coherence and successful demodulation.

nodes.name: rain fade
nodes.description: rain fade The significant atmospheric attenuation of an RF signal, primarily impacting microwave and millimeter-wave frequencies (above 10 GHz), caused by the absorption and scattering of electromagnetic energy by heavy rain, snow, or wet ice. This effect drastically reduces the signal strength (SNR) and is a primary consideration in designing link budgets for high-frequency terrestrial and satellite backhaul systems.

nodes.name: 6G
nodes.description: 6G The anticipated sixth generation of mobile communication technology, currently under research, aiming to evolve beyond 5G by achieving unprecedented data rates (Terabit-per-second), extremely low latency (microsecond), and massive connectivity. Key technological pillars include the utilization of sub-Terahertz spectrum, pervasive integration of Artificial Intelligence, and the development of integrated sensing and communication capabilities.

nodes.name: short-range
nodes.description: short-range Pertains to wireless communication systems designed for localized coverage, typically spanning tens of meters or less, characterized by low power consumption and high data rates, commonly seen in technologies like Bluetooth, NFC, and specific WLAN deployments where proximity minimizes path loss and enhances link reliability.

nodes.name: spectroscopy
nodes.description: spectroscopy In an RF context, this involves analyzing the spectral content of signals to identify and characterize materials or chemical compositions based on their interaction, such as absorption or reflection, with specific radio frequencies, providing non-invasive sensing capabilities, often used in specialized sensing applications beyond typical communications.

nodes.name: Physical-layer security
nodes.description: Physical-layer security A security paradigm that leverages the intrinsic properties of the wireless propagation channel, such as noise, fading, and reciprocity, to secure communications against passive eavesdroppers without relying solely on higher-layer cryptographic protocols, often utilizing techniques like artificial noise injection or directional transmission.

nodes.name: LPI
nodes.description: LPI Refers to techniques used primarily in military or specialized communications designed to make signals difficult to detect and characterize by unauthorized recipients, typically achieved through spread spectrum methods like frequency hopping or direct sequence, combined with low transmit power and precise spatial beamforming.

nodes.name: QKD
nodes.description: QKD A method utilizing quantum mechanics principles to establish highly secure cryptographic keys between two parties, ensuring that any eavesdropping attempt fundamentally alters the transmitted quantum state, thereby immediately revealing the intrusion and making the key distribution provably secure against future computational advances.

nodes.name: RIS design
nodes.description: RIS design Involves engineering passive or semi-passive surfaces composed of numerous reflection elements, each capable of independently adjusting the phase and/or amplitude of incident electromagnetic waves, enabling programmable wireless environments to dynamically focus signal energy, mitigate deep fades, and enhance coverage efficiency.

nodes.name: beam steering
nodes.description: beam steering The process of electronically controlling the direction of the main lobe of an antenna's radiation pattern without physically moving the antenna, typically achieved using controllable phase shifters in a phased array system to focus radiated energy precisely toward a specific receiver, maximizing signal strength and minimizing inter-user interference.

nodes.name: Phase noise
nodes.description: Phase noise A form of noise that manifests as random fluctuations in the phase of a signal, particularly generated by non-ideal oscillators and synthesizers, which smears the spectral energy around the desired carrier frequency and degrades the achievable signal-to-noise ratio and bit error rate in high-order modulation schemes.

nodes.name: LO leakage
nodes.description: LO leakage Occurs in frequency converters, specifically mixers, where the signal from the Local Oscillator inadvertently couples into the RF port and radiates out of the transmitter antenna or contaminates the input of the receiver chain, often resulting in unwanted spurious emissions or significant DC offsets in direct-conversion architectures.

nodes.name: compensation
nodes.description: compensation In RF systems, this refers to techniques used to counteract or mitigate various impairments like non-linearity, phase noise, frequency offset, or channel fading, often implemented through digital signal processing algorithms such as pre-distortion or equalization to restore signal integrity and optimize system performance.

nodes.name: CQI
nodes.description: CQI A metric reported by the User Equipment back to the base station quantifying the quality of the downlink channel based on measurements like SINR, which allows the scheduler to dynamically select the optimal Modulation and Coding Scheme (MCS) for subsequent transmissions, maximizing throughput efficiency.

nodes.name: HARQ
nodes.description: HARQ A sophisticated error control method combining traditional retransmission requests (ARQ) with Forward Error Correction (FEC) coding, where received data is stored in a buffer and soft-combined with subsequent retransmitted packets to maximize the probability of successful decoding, significantly improving link reliability.

nodes.name: LDPC
nodes.description: LDPC A highly efficient linear block code characterized by a sparse parity-check matrix, known for achieving performance very close to the Shannon limit, which has been adopted as the primary data channel coding scheme in standards like 5G NR due to its excellent parallelism and high-throughput decoding capabilities.

nodes.name: Turbo
nodes.description: Turbo A powerful iterative parallel concatenated convolution code (PCCC) that achieves near-Shannon-limit performance, widely adopted in 3G and 4G wireless standards, notable for utilizing two constituent encoders separated by a proprietary interleaver and employing soft-input/soft-output decoding techniques.

nodes.name: Polar
nodes.description: Polar A channel coding scheme based on the principle of channel polarization, which optimally transforms a set of independent channels into a subset of either noise-free channels or purely noisy channels, making it highly efficient for error correction; it is specifically mandated for the control channels in 5G NR systems.

nodes.name: Modulation recognition
nodes.description: Modulation recognition The process, often automated using machine learning or statistical signal processing techniques, of identifying the specific modulation scheme used by an unknown incoming RF signal without explicit prior knowledge of the transmitter, crucial for signal intelligence, spectrum monitoring, and cognitive radio systems.

nodes.name: channel prediction
nodes.description: channel prediction In communication systems, this involves estimating the future state of the wireless channel, such as future Channel State Information (CSI), based on past measurements and known mobility models, enabling proactive resource allocation, precoding adjustments, and optimization of coding before deep fades occur.

nodes.name: Pulse
nodes.description: Pulse A radar technique characterized by transmitting short, high-power electromagnetic energy bursts, measuring the time delay of the reflected return signal to precisely determine the target range, generally utilizing a high peak power but maintaining a very low duty cycle to achieve long detection ranges.

nodes.name: FMCW
nodes.description: FMCW A radar technique where the transmitted signal is a continuous wave whose frequency is linearly varied over time, or chirped, allowing highly accurate determination of both target range and velocity simultaneously by mixing the received and transmitted signals to measure the resulting beat frequency.

nodes.name: MIMO radar
nodes.description: MIMO radar A system that employs multiple transmit antennas and multiple receive antennas to transmit orthogonal waveforms, creating multiple virtual apertures, which significantly enhances the achievable angular resolution and improves target detection and parameter estimation capabilities compared to traditional phased arrays by leveraging spatial diversity.

nodes.name: CFAR
nodes.description: CFAR Constant False Alarm Rate (CFAR) is a crucial signal processing algorithm used predominantly in radar systems to automatically adjust the detection threshold based on the measured local background noise, clutter, and interference power, ensuring that the probability of declaring a false target remains consistent and optimally low across various operating environments and clutter conditions.

nodes.name: ES
nodes.description: ES Electronic Support (ES) constitutes the passive element of Electronic Warfare (EW), involving actions taken to search for, intercept, identify, and locate sources of radiated electromagnetic energy, such as enemy radar or communications transmissions, primarily for the purposes of threat warning, target acquisition, and gathering operational intelligence without actively transmitting energy.

nodes.name: EA
nodes.description: EA Electronic Attack (EA) is the active component of EW that uses electromagnetic energy, directed energy, or anti-radiation weapons to intentionally degrade, neutralize, or destroy enemy combat capability, with the most common form being the deployment of jamming signals designed to overwhelm and mask friendly signals within a target receiver's bandwidth.

nodes.name: EP
nodes.description: EP Electronic Protection (EP) involves all defensive measures within EW intended to safeguard friendly electronic systems against any adverse effects of enemy or friendly electronic attack, encompassing techniques like frequency hopping, spread spectrum modulation, and advanced receiver designs (Electronic Counter-Countermeasures or ECCM) to ensure communication and sensor functionality is maintained.

nodes.name: jamming
nodes.description: jamming Jamming is the deliberate radiation of powerful electromagnetic noise or structured false signals intended to deny the effective use of a target communications link or radar system by overwhelming the receiver's signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), rendering the true incoming signal undetectable or unintelligible.

nodes.name: protection
nodes.description: protection In RF system design, protection refers to the implementation of passive and active defense mechanisms, including EP techniques, robust filtering, anti-aliasing measures, and physical shielding, all aimed at enhancing the resilience and operational availability of the RF equipment against both intentional interference (jamming) and unintentional electromagnetic interference (EMI).

nodes.name: Guard bands
nodes.description: Guard bands Guard bands are unoccupied frequency segments strategically placed between allocated communication channels within a spectrum to prevent spectral overlap, mitigate adjacent channel interference (ACI) caused by non-ideal filtering, and accommodate the spectral side-lobes and frequency drift inherent in real-world transmitters.

nodes.name: filtering
nodes.description: filtering Filtering is the process of using frequency-selective circuits (filters) to attenuate unwanted signals outside a desired frequency band while allowing the desired signal to pass with minimal loss, a critical function in both transmitters (for harmonic rejection) and receivers (for noise and interference rejection).

nodes.name: cancellation
nodes.description: cancellation Cancellation is an advanced signal processing technique, particularly important in full-duplex systems or cognitive radio, where a known unwanted signal—such as self-interference leakage from a local transmitter—is precisely estimated, inverted in phase, and dynamically subtracted from the received signal path to achieve high levels of isolation.

nodes.name: IQ imbalance
nodes.description: IQ imbalance IQ imbalance is a non-ideal condition in quadrature modulation and demodulation caused by either a mismatch in the gain (amplitude) between the In-phase (I) and Quadrature (Q) paths or a phase error where the components are not precisely 90 degrees apart, resulting in the generation of an unwanted image frequency component and degradation of overall system linearity and error vector magnitude (EVM).

nodes.name: DPD
nodes.description: DPD Digital Pre-Distortion (DPD) is a sophisticated linearization technique implemented in the digital domain to mitigate the non-linear distortion produced by power amplifiers (PAs), where the input signal is strategically distorted with the inverse characteristics of the PA prior to transmission, significantly improving spectral efficiency, reducing out-of-band emissions, and maximizing PA operating efficiency.

nodes.name: synchronization
nodes.description: synchronization Synchronization is the fundamental process in a receiver where the local timing parameters, including frequency offset, phase, and symbol timing, are precisely aligned with those of the incoming signal, enabling the receiver to accurately sample, track, and correctly demodulate the transmitted data symbols.

nodes.name: Microstrip
nodes.description: Microstrip Microstrip is a prevalent planar transmission line structure in microwave circuits, composed of a conductive trace separated from a continuous ground plane by a dielectric substrate, valued for its ease of fabrication and integration, though it is prone to radiation and dispersion, particularly at higher frequencies.

nodes.name: CPW
nodes.description: CPW Coplanar Waveguide (CPW) is a planar transmission line structure where the signal conductor and the return ground conductors are all located on the same side of the dielectric substrate, offering excellent isolation, low dispersion, and simplifying component mounting and integration, especially beneficial for use with probe stations.

nodes.name: grounding
nodes.description: grounding Grounding in RF circuits refers to establishing a robust, low-impedance electrical connection to a reference plane, which is essential for defining the signal return path of transmission lines, minimizing common-mode currents, managing electromagnetic compatibility (EMC), and ensuring system stability.

nodes.name: shielding
nodes.description: shielding Shielding involves using conductive barriers or enclosures to block the propagation of electromagnetic energy, preventing external interference from entering sensitive RF circuitry and, conversely, containing the emissions generated by the circuit, thereby ensuring signal integrity and compliance with regulatory emission standards.

nodes.name: MMICs
nodes.description: MMICs Monolithic Microwave Integrated Circuits (MMICs) are integrated circuits where all active and passive components required for RF functions, such as transistors, filters, and transmission lines, are fabricated onto a single semiconductor substrate, typically GaAs or GaN, providing highly integrated, miniature, and broadband performance from UHF up to millimeter-wave frequencies.

nodes.name: SiP
nodes.description: SiP System-in-Package (SiP) is an advanced packaging methodology where multiple semiconductor dies (chips) of different functionalities, sometimes including passive components and MEMS devices, are assembled and interconnected within a single standard integrated circuit package, offering high integration density without requiring complete redesign of the internal dies.

nodes.name: SoC
nodes.description: SoC System-on-Chip (SoC) is a highly integrated single silicon die that incorporates all or most of the necessary electronic systems components, including digital processing units, memory interfaces, and complex RF front-ends, aiming for maximal integration, minimum power consumption, and overall smaller physical size compared to multi-chip solutions.

nodes.name: thermal design
nodes.description: thermal design Thermal design is the critical engineering process focused on managing and dissipating the waste heat generated by active RF components, particularly power amplifiers, as uncontrolled temperature rise leads to reduced component efficiency, shifting of operational frequencies, device performance degradation, and ultimately limits component lifespan and reliability.

nodes.name: Error budgets
nodes.description: Error budgets are critical tools in RF system design and measurement, rigorously quantifying and summing all known or estimated sources of uncertainty (e.g., thermal noise, component tolerances, calibration drift) that contribute to the overall degradation or imprecision of a system's performance metric, such as gain, noise figure, or phase accuracy, ensuring the final calculated performance meets the required specifications with a defined margin.

nodes.name: repeatability
nodes.description: Repeatability, in the context of RF measurements, is the crucial metric defining the closeness of agreement between successive measurements of the same quantity, taken under identical conditions—using the same instrument, operator, location, and short time interval—and is fundamental for establishing the stability and intrinsic precision of a measurement setup or a DUT (Device Under Test).

nodes.name: statistical validation
nodes.description: Statistical validation applies rigorous mathematical and statistical techniques, such as hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, and regression analysis, to analyze large datasets of RF measurements or simulations, confirming whether the observed results are statistically significant, reliable, and representative of the system's true behavior under varying conditions, thereby mitigating the risk of relying on random or artifactual results.

nodes.name: A
nodes.description: Abbreviation for ampere, the unit of electrical current.

nodes.name: acceptor atoms
nodes.description: Trivalent atoms that accept free electrons from pentavalent atoms.

nodes.name: AC coupling
nodes.description: Circuit that passes an AC signal while blocking a DC voltage.

nodes.name: AC load line
nodes.description: A graph representing all possible combinations of AC output voltage and current for an amplifier.

nodes.name: active component
nodes.description: A component that changes the amplitude of a signal between input and output.

nodes.name: active filter
nodes.description: A filter that uses an amplifier in addition to reactive components to pass or reject selected frequencies.

nodes.name: active region
nodes.description: The region of BJT operation between saturation and cutoff used for linear amplification.

nodes.name: ADC
nodes.description: Abbreviation for Analog to Digital Converter.

nodes.name: Aliased signals
nodes.description: A signal (normally electrical) sampled below the Nyquist Rate (twice the maximum frequency content of the signal) so that the frequency content of signal is erroneously rearranged.

nodes.name: alpha
nodes.description: Ratio of collector current to emitter current in a bipolar junction transistor (BJT). Greek letter alpha “α” is the symbol used.

nodes.name: amplifier
nodes.description: A circuit that increases the voltage, current, or power of a signal.

nodes.name: amplitude
nodes.description: Magnitude or size of a signal voltage or current.

nodes.name: analog
nodes.description: Information represented as continuously varying voltage or current rather than in discrete levels as opposed to digital data varying between two discrete levels.

nodes.name: anode
nodes.description: The positive electrode or terminal of a device. The “P” material of a diode.

nodes.name: Astable
nodes.description: A circuit that cannot remain in one state. That is it will periodically switch between states or oscillate.

nodes.name: attenuate
nodes.description: To reduce the amplitude of an action or signal. The opposite of amplification.

nodes.name: average value
nodes.description: A value of voltage or current where the area of the wave above the value equals the area of the wave below the value.

nodes.name: AWG
nodes.description: Abbreviation for Arbitrary Waveform Generator. Abbreviation for American Wire Gauge. B

nodes.name: bandwidth
nodes.description: Width of the band of frequencies between the half power points.

nodes.name: barrier potential
nodes.description: The natural difference of potential that exists across a forward biased pn junction.

nodes.name: base
nodes.description: The region that lies between the emitter and collector of a bipolar junction transistor (BJT).

nodes.name: base biasing
nodes.description: A method of biasing a BJT in which the bias voltage is supplied to the base by means of a resistor.

nodes.name: beta
nodes.description: (β) The ratio of collector current to base current in a bipolar junction transistor (BJT).

nodes.name: bias
nodes.description: A DC voltage applied to a device to control its operation.

nodes.name: bipolar junction transistor
nodes.description: (BJT), A three terminal device in which emitter to collector current is controlled by base current.

nodes.name: bode plot
nodes.description: A graph of gain versus frequency.

nodes.name: branch current
nodes.description: The portion of total current flowing in one path of a parallel circuit.

nodes.name: breakdown voltage
nodes.description: Voltage at which the breakdown of a dielectric or insulator occurs.

nodes.name: bridge rectifier
nodes.description: A circuit using four diodes to provide full wave rectification. Converts an AC voltage to a pulsating DC voltage.

nodes.name: buffer
nodes.description: An amplifier used to isolate a load from a source.

nodes.name: bulk resistance
nodes.description: The natural resistance of a “P” type or “N” type semiconductor material.

nodes.name: BW
nodes.description: Abbreviation for bandwidth.

nodes.name: bypass capacitor
nodes.description: A capacitor used to provide an AC ground at some point in a circuit. C

nodes.name: CAD
nodes.description: Abbreviation for “computer aided design”

nodes.name: calibration
nodes.description: To adjust the correct value of a reading by comparison to a standard.

nodes.name: CAN
nodes.description: Controller Area Network, a robust serial communication bus standard popular in automotive and industrial applications.

nodes.name: capacitance
nodes.description: The ability of a capacitor to store an electrical charge. The basic unit of capacitance is the Farad.

nodes.name: capacitor
nodes.description: An electronic component having capacitive reactance.

nodes.name: cascaded amplifier
nodes.description: An amplifier with two or more stages arranged in a series configuration.

nodes.name: cascode amplifier
nodes.description: A high frequency amplifier made up of a common-source or common-emitter amplifier with a common-gate or common base amplifier in its drain/ collector network.

nodes.name: cathode
nodes.description: The negative terminal electrode of a device. The “N” material in a junction diode.

nodes.name: center tapped rectifier
nodes.description: Circuit that make use of a center tapped transformer and two diodes to provide full wave rectification.

nodes.name: center tapped transformer
nodes.description: A transformer with a connection at the electrical center of a winding.

nodes.name: charge
nodes.description: Quantity of electrical energy.

nodes.name: circuit
nodes.description: Interconnection of components to provide an electrical path between two or more components.

nodes.name: clamp
nodes.description: A diode circuit used to change the DC level of a waveform without distorting the waveform.

nodes.name: class A amplifier
nodes.description: A linear amplifier biased so the active device conducts through 360 degrees of the input waveform.

nodes.name: class B amplifier
nodes.description: An amplifier with two active devices. The active components are biased so that each conducts for approximately 180 degrees of the input waveform cycle.

nodes.name: class C amplifier
nodes.description: An amplifier in which the active device conducts for less than 180 degrees of the input waveform cycle.

nodes.name: clipper
nodes.description: A diode circuit used to eliminate part of a waveform above or below a limit.

nodes.name: closed circuit
nodes.description: Circuit having a complete path for current flow.

nodes.name: closed-loop gain
nodes.description: Gain of an amplifier when a feedback path is present.

nodes.name: collector
nodes.description: The semiconductor region in a bipolar junction transistor through which a flow of charge carriers leaves the base region.

nodes.name: collector characteristic curve
nodes.description: A graph of collector voltage over collector current for a given base current.

nodes.name: common base amplifier
nodes.description: A BJT circuit in which the base connection is common to both input and output.

nodes.name: common collector amplifier
nodes.description: A BJT circuit in which the collector connection is common to both input and output.

nodes.name: common drain amplifier
nodes.description: A FET circuit in which the drain connection is common to both input and output.

nodes.name: common emitter amplifier
nodes.description: A BJT circuit in which the emitter connection is common to both input and output.

nodes.name: common gate amplifier
nodes.description: A FET circuit in which the gate connection is common to both input and output.

nodes.name: common source amplifier
nodes.description: A FET circuit in which the source connection is common to both input and output.

nodes.name: common-mode rejection ratio
nodes.description: (CMRR) The ratio of op-amp differential gain to common-mode gain. A measure of an op-amp's ability to reject common-mode signals such as noise.

nodes.name: common-mode signals
nodes.description: Signals that appear simultaneously at two inputs of an operational amplifier (op-amp). Common mode signals are always equal in amplitude and phase.

nodes.name: CMOS - complimentary MOSFET logic.
nodes.description: CMOS logic dominates the digital industry because the power requirements and component density are significantly better than other technologies.

nodes.name: comparator
nodes.description: An op-amp circuit that compares two inputs and provides a DC output indicating the polarity relationship between the inputs.

nodes.name: complementary transistors
nodes.description: Two transistors, one NPN and one PNP having near identical characteristics. N-channel and P-channel FETs can also be complementary.

nodes.name: constant current circuit
nodes.description: Circuit used to maintain constant current to a load having resistance that changes.

nodes.name: conventional current flow
nodes.description: Concept of current produced by the movement of positive charges towards the negative terminal of a source.

nodes.name: coulomb
nodes.description: Unit of electric charge. A negative coulomb charge consists of 6.24 × 10^18 electrons.

nodes.name: coupling
nodes.description: To electronically connect two circuits so that signal will pass from one to the other.

nodes.name: current
nodes.description: Measured in amperes, it is the flow of electrons through a conductor. Also known as electron flow.

nodes.name: current amplifier
nodes.description: Amplifier to increase signal current.

nodes.name: current divider
nodes.description: Parallel network designed to divide the total current of a circuit.

nodes.name: current feedback
nodes.description: Feedback configuration where a portion of the output current is fed back to the amplifier input.

nodes.name: current mirror
nodes.description: Term used to describe the fact that DC current through the base circuit of a class B amplifier is approximately equal to the DC collector current.

nodes.name: cutoff
nodes.description: Condition when an active device is biased such that output current is near zero or beyond zero. D

nodes.name: DAC
nodes.description: Abbreviation for “digital to analog converter.”

nodes.name: Darlington pair
nodes.description: An amplifier consisting of two bipolar junction transistors with their collectors connected together and the emitter of one connected to the base of the other. Circuit has an extremely high current gain and input impedance.

nodes.name: DC
nodes.description: Abbreviation for “direct current”.

nodes.name: DC load line
nodes.description: A graph representing all possible combinations of voltage and current for a given load resistor in an amplifier.

nodes.name: DC offset
nodes.description: The change in input voltage required to produce a zero output voltage when no signal is applied to an amplifier.

nodes.name: DC power supply
nodes.description: Any source of DC power for electrical equipment.

nodes.name: decade
nodes.description: A frequency factor of ten.

nodes.name: decibel
nodes.description: (dB) a logarithmic representation of gain or loss.

nodes.name: degenerative feedback
nodes.description: Also called negative feedback. A portion of the output of an amplifier is inverted and connected back to the input. This controls the gain of the amplifier and reduces distortion and noise.

nodes.name: depletion layer or region
nodes.description: The area surrounding a PN junction that is depleted of carriers.

nodes.name: depletion mode
nodes.description: In a FET, an operating mode where reverse gate-source voltage is used to deplete the channel of free carriers. This reduces the size of the channel and increases its resistance.

nodes.name: depletion-mode MOSFET
nodes.description: A MOSFET designed to operate in either depletion mode or enhancement mode.

nodes.name: device
nodes.description: A component or part.

nodes.name: dielectric
nodes.description: Insulating material between two plates where an electrostatic field exists.

nodes.name: dielectric constant
nodes.description: Property of a material that determines how much electrostatic energy can be stored per unit volume when unit voltage is applied.

nodes.name: dielectric strength
nodes.description: The maximum voltage an insulating material can withstand without breaking down.

nodes.name: differential amplifier
nodes.description: An amplifier in which the output is in proportion to the differences between voltages applied to its two inputs.

nodes.name: differentiator
nodes.description: A circuit in which the output voltage is in proportion to the rate of change of the input voltage. A high pass RC circuit.

nodes.name: diffusion
nodes.description: Tendency of conduction band electrons to wander across a PN junction to combine with valence band holes.

nodes.name: digital
nodes.description: Relating to devices or circuits that have outputs of only two discrete levels. Examples: 0 or 1, high or low, on or off, true or false etc.

nodes.name: Digitizing oscilloscope
nodes.description: An oscilloscope that uses a high-speed analog-to-digital converter (ADC) to measure signals and then displays them on a screen (CRT or LCD) using standard computer graphics techniques.

nodes.name: diode
nodes.description: A two terminal device that conducts in only one direction.

nodes.name: direct coupling
nodes.description: Where the output of one amplifier stage is connected directly to the input of a second amplifier or to a load. Also known as DC coupling because DC signals are not blocked.

nodes.name: direct current (DC)
nodes.description: Current that flows in only one direction.

nodes.name: donor atoms
nodes.description: Pentavalent atoms that give up electrons to the conduction band in an N type semiconductor material.

nodes.name: doping
nodes.description: The process of adding impurity atoms to intrinsic (pure) silicon or germanium to improve the conductivity of the semiconductor material.

nodes.name: Duty cycle
nodes.description: Duty cycle is the fraction of one period in which a signal or system is active. Duty cycle is commonly expressed as a percentage or a ratio. A period is the time it takes for a signal to complete an on-and-off cycle. E

nodes.name: electric charge
nodes.description: Electric energy stored on the surface of a material. Also known as a static charge.

nodes.name: electric field
nodes.description: A field or force that exists in the space between two different potentials or voltages. Also known as an electrostatic field.

nodes.name: electromotive force
nodes.description: (emf) Force that causes the motion of electrons due to potential difference between two points. (voltage)

nodes.name: electron
nodes.description: Smallest sub atomic particle of negative charge that orbits the nucleus of an atom.

nodes.name: electron flow
nodes.description: Electrical current produced by the movement of free electrons towards a positive terminal.

nodes.name: electrostatic
nodes.description: Related to static electric charge.

nodes.name: emitter
nodes.description: The semiconductor region from which charge carriers are injected into the base of a bipolar junction transistor.

nodes.name: emitter feedback
nodes.description: Coupling from the emitter output to the base input of a bipolar junction transistor.

nodes.name: emitter follower
nodes.description: A common collector amplifier. Has a high current gain, high input impedance and low output impedance.

nodes.name: engineering notation
nodes.description: A floating point system in which numbers are expressed as products consisting of a number greater than one multiplied by an appropriate power of ten that is some multiple of three.

nodes.name: enhancement-mode MOSFET
nodes.description: A field effect transistor in which there are no charge carriers in the channel when the gate source voltage is zero.

nodes.name: equivalent resistance
nodes.description: Total resistance of all the individual resistances in a circuit. F

nodes.name: fall time
nodes.description: Time it takes the falling edge of a pulse to go from 90% of peak voltage to 10% of peak voltage.

nodes.name: farad
nodes.description: The basic unit of capacitance.

nodes.name: feedback
nodes.description: A portion of the output signal of an amplifier which is connected back to the input of the same amplifier.

nodes.name: feedback amplifier
nodes.description: An amplifier with an external signal path from its output back to its input.

nodes.name: field effect transistor (FET)
nodes.description: A voltage controlled transistor in which the source to drain conduction is controlled by gate to source voltage.

nodes.name: filter
nodes.description: Network consisting of capacitors, resistors and/or inductors used to pass certain frequencies and block others.

nodes.name: Flip Flop
nodes.description: A digital circuit that flips or toggles between two stable states (bistable). The Flip Flop inputs decide which of the two states its output will be.

nodes.name: forward bias
nodes.description: A PN junction bias which allows current to flow through the junction. Forward bias decreases the resistance of the depletion layer.

nodes.name: free electrons
nodes.description: Electrons that are not in any orbit around a nucleus.

nodes.name: frequency-domain analysis
nodes.description: A method of representing a waveform by plotting its amplitude against frequency.

nodes.name: frequency response
nodes.description: Indication of how well a circuit responds to different frequencies applied to it.

nodes.name: frequency response curve
nodes.description: A graph of amplitude over frequency indicating a circuit response to different frequencies.

nodes.name: full wave rectifier
nodes.description: Rectifier that makes use of the full AC wave in both the positive and negative half cycles.

nodes.name: function generator
nodes.description: Signal generator that can produce sine, square, triangle and sawtooth output waveforms.

nodes.name: fundamental frequency
nodes.description: Lowest frequency in a complex waveform. G

nodes.name: gain
nodes.description: Increase in voltage, current and/or power. Gain is expressed as a ratio of amplifier output value to the corresponding amplifier input value.

nodes.name: gain bandwidth product
nodes.description: A device parameter that indicates the maximum possible product of gain and bandwidth. The gain bandwidth product of a device is equal to the unity gain frequency (f_unity ) of the device.

nodes.name: GPIB
nodes.description: General-purpose instrument bus, also known as the IEEE-488 bus, widely used as an interface for connecting test instruments to computers and for providing programmable instrument control.

nodes.name: ground
nodes.description: An intentional or accidental conducting path between an electrical system or circuit and the earth or some conducting body acting in place of the earth. A ground is often used as the common wiring point or reference in a circuit. H

nodes.name: half power point
nodes.description: A frequency at which the power is 50% of maximum. This corresponds to 70.7% of maximum current or voltage.

nodes.name: h-parameters
nodes.description: (hybrid parameters) Transistor specifications that describe the component operating limits under specific circumstances.

nodes.name: half wave rectifier
nodes.description: A diode rectifier that converts AC to pulsating DC by eliminating either the negative or the positive alternation of each input AC cycle.

nodes.name: Sine wave that is smaller in amplitude and some multiple of a
nodes.description: fundamental frequency. Example: 880 Hz. is the second harmonic of 440 Hz., 880 Hz. is the third harmonic of 220 Hz.

nodes.name: Harmonics
nodes.description: A frequency component of a signal that is an integral multiple of the fundamental of that signal.

nodes.name: hole
nodes.description: A gap left in the covalent bond when a valence electron gains sufficient energy to jump to the conduction band. I

nodes.name: I^2 C
nodes.description: Inter integrated circuit bus, a short-distance serial communication bus standard consisting of two signals (clock and data), popular for talking between several integrated circuits on the same printed circuit board.

nodes.name: IC
nodes.description: Abbreviation for “integrated circuit”

nodes.name: IC voltage regulator
nodes.description: Three terminal device used to hold the output voltage of a power supply constant over a wide range of load variations.

nodes.name: IGFET
nodes.description: Insulated gate field effect transistor. Another name for a “MOSFET.”

nodes.name: impedance
nodes.description: (Z) Measured in ohms it is the total opposition to the flow of current offered by a circuit. Impedance consists of the vector sum of resistance and reactance.

nodes.name: Interleave
nodes.description: A technique used in digitizing oscilloscopes whereby ADCs of different rate or more memory depth when you are using fewer channels.

nodes.name: internal resistance
nodes.description: Every source has some resistance in series with the output current. When current is drawn from the source some power is lost due to the voltage drop across the internal resistance. Usually called output impedance or output resistance.

nodes.name: intrinsic material
nodes.description: A semiconductor material with electrical properties essentially characteristic of ideal pure crystal. Essentially silicon or germanium crystal with no measurable impurities.

nodes.name: inverting amplifier
nodes.description: An amplifier that has a 180° phase shift from input to output.

nodes.name: inverting input
nodes.description: In an operational amplifier (op amp) the input that is marked with a minus sign. A signal applied at the inverting input will be given 180° phase shift between input and output.

nodes.name: ion
nodes.description: An atom with fewer electrons in orbit than the number of protons in the nucleus is a positive ion. An atom with a greater number of electrons in orbit than the number of protons in the nucleus is a negative ion. J

nodes.name: junction
nodes.description: Contact or connection between two or more wires or cables. The area where the p-type material and n-type material meet in a semiconductor.

nodes.name: junction diode
nodes.description: Diode. A semiconductor diode in which the rectifying characteristics occur at a junction between the n-type and p-type semiconductor materials. K

nodes.name: kilo
nodes.description: Metric prefix for 1000. (10^3 )

nodes.name: Kirchhoff's current law
nodes.description: The sum of the currents flowing into a point in a circuit is equal to the sum of the currents flowing out of that same point.

nodes.name: Kirchhoff's voltage law
nodes.description: The algebraic sum of the voltage drops in a closed path circuit is equal to the algebraic sum of the source voltages applied.

nodes.name: knee voltage
nodes.description: The voltage at which a curve joins two relatively straight portions of a characteristic curve. For a PN junction diode, the point in the forward operating region of the characteristic curve where conduction starts to increase rapidly. For a zener diode, the term is often used in reference to the zener voltage rating. L

nodes.name: L-C tank circuit
nodes.description: A circuit consisting of inductance and capacitance, capable of storing electricity over a band of frequencies continuously distributed about a single frequency at which the circuit is said to be resonant or tuned.

nodes.name: light-emitting diode (LED)
nodes.description: A semiconductor diode that converts electric energy into electromagnetic radiation at a visible and near infrared frequencies when its pn junction is forward biased.

nodes.name: limiter
nodes.description: Circuit or device that prevents some portion of its input from reaching the output. See also clipper.

nodes.name: LIN
nodes.description: Local interconnect network, a short-distance serial communication standard that is often found in systems also containing the CAN bus. LIN is slower and less complex than the CAN bus.

nodes.name: linear
nodes.description: Relationship between input and output in which the output varies in direct proportion to the input.

nodes.name: linear scale
nodes.description: A scale in which the divisions are uniformly spaced.

nodes.name: line regulation
nodes.description: The ability of a voltage regulator to maintain a constant voltage when the regulator input voltage varies.

nodes.name: load
nodes.description: A source drives a load. Whatever component or piece of equipment is connected to a source and draws current from a source is a load on that source.

nodes.name: load current
nodes.description: Current drawn from a source by a load.

nodes.name: load impedance
nodes.description: Vector sum of reactance and resistance in a load.

nodes.name: loading effect
nodes.description: Large load impedance will draw a small load current and so loading of the source is small. (light load). A small load impedance will draw a large load current from the source. (heavy load).

nodes.name: load regulation
nodes.description: The ability of a voltage regulator to maintain a constant output voltage under varying load currents.

nodes.name: load resistance
nodes.description: Resistance of a load. M

nodes.name: majority carriers
nodes.description: The conduction band electrons in an n-type material and the valence band holes in a p-type material. Produced by pentavalent impurities in n-type material and trivalent impurities in p-type material.

nodes.name: metal oxide field effect transistor (MOSFET)
nodes.description: A field effect transistor in which the insulating layer between the gate electrode and the channel is a metal oxide layer.

nodes.name: mid-band gain
nodes.description: Gain of an amplifier operating within its bandwidth.

nodes.name: mid-point bias
nodes.description: An amplifier biased at the center of its DC load line.

nodes.name: mil
nodes.description: One thousandth of an inch (0.001 in.)

nodes.name: Miller's theorem
nodes.description: A theorem that allows you to represent a feedback capacitor as equivalent input and output shunt capacitors.

nodes.name: minority carriers
nodes.description: The conduction band holes in n-type material and valence band electrons in p-type material. Most minority carriers are produced by temperature rather than by doping with impurities.

nodes.name: Mixed-signal oscilloscopes (MSOs)
nodes.description: Digitizing oscilloscopes that have a larger number of channels than usual for looking at both analog and digital signals. MSOs typically have two or four analog channels and at least 8 bits of vertical resolution. There are usually 16 digital channels but they typically have only 1 bit of vertical resolution.

nodes.name: Monostable
nodes.description: A circuit that has one stable state. When perturbed, the circuit will

nodes.name: MOSFET
nodes.description: Abbreviation for “metal oxide field effect transistor” also known as an “insulated gate field effect transistor. A field effect transistor in which the insulating layer between the gate electrode and the channel is a metal oxide layer.

nodes.name: Multivibrator
nodes.description: A circuit used to implement a simple two-state system, which may be astable, monostable, or bistable. N

nodes.name: n-type semiconductor
nodes.description: A semiconductor compound formed by doping an intrinsic semiconductor with a pentavalent element. An n-type material contains an excess of conduction band electrons.

nodes.name: negative
nodes.description: Terminal that has an excess of electrons.

nodes.name: A charge that has more electrons than protons
negative feedback
nodes.description: A feedback signal 180° out of phase with an amplifier input signal. Used to increase amplifier stability, bandwidth and input impedance. Also reduces distortion.

nodes.name: negative ion
nodes.description: An atom having a greater number of electrons in orbit than there are protons in the nucleus.

nodes.name: negative resistance
nodes.description: A resistance such that when the current through it increases the voltage drop across the resistance decreases.

nodes.name: negative temperature coefficient
nodes.description: A term used to describe a component whose resistance or capacitance decreases when temperature increases.

nodes.name: node
nodes.description: Junction or branch point in a circuit.

nodes.name: noise
nodes.description: Unwanted electromagnetic radiation within an electrical or mechanical system.

nodes.name: non-inverting input
nodes.description: The terminal on an operational amplifier that is identified by a plus sign.

nodes.name: non-linear scale
nodes.description: A scale in which the divisions are not equally spaced, logarithmic.

nodes.name: Norton's theorem
nodes.description: Any network of voltage sources and resistors can be replaced by a single current source in parallel with a single resistor.

nodes.name: NPN transistor
nodes.description: A bipolar junction transistor in which a p-type base element is sandwiched between an n-type emitter and an n-type collector. O

nodes.name: One Shot
nodes.description: Monostable circuit that produces one pulse when triggered.

nodes.name: Open-loop gain
nodes.description: The open-loop gain of an operational amplifier is the gain obtained when no feedback is used in the circuit. Open loop gain is usually exceedingly high; in fact, an ideal operational amplifier has infinite open-loop gain. Typically an op-amp may have an open-loop gain of around 100,000. Normally, feedback is applied around the op-amp so that the gain of the overall circuit is defined and kept to a figure which is more usable. However the very high gain of the op-amp enables considerable levels of feedback to be applied to achieve required performance. The open-loop gain of an operational amplifier falls very rapidly with increasing frequency. Along with slew rate, this is one of the reasons why operational amplifiers have limited bandwidth. P

nodes.name: passive component
nodes.description: Component that does not amplify a signal. Resistors, capacitors and inductors are examples.

nodes.name: peak to peak
nodes.description: Difference between the maximum positive and maximum negative values of an AC waveform.

nodes.name: pentavalent element
nodes.description: Element whose atoms have five valence electrons. Used in doping intrinsic silicon or germanium to produce n-type semiconductor material. Most commonly used pentavalent materials are arsenic and phosphorus.

nodes.name: percent of regulation
nodes.description: The change in output voltage that occurs between no-load and full-load in a DC voltage source. Dividing this change by the full-load value and multiplying the result by 100 gives percent regulation.

nodes.name: percent of ripple
nodes.description: The ratio of the effective rms value of ripple voltage to the average value of the total voltage. Expressed as a percentage.

nodes.name: pinch-off region
nodes.description: A region on the characteristic curve of a FET in which the gate bias causes the depletion region to extend completely across the channel.

nodes.name: PNP transistor
nodes.description: A bipolar junction transistor with an n-type base and p-type emitter and collector.

nodes.name: positive feedback
nodes.description: A feedback signal that is in phase with an amplifier input signal. Positive feedback is necessary for oscillation to occur.

nodes.name: potential difference
nodes.description: Voltage difference between two points which will cause current to flow in a closed circuit.

nodes.name: potentiometer
nodes.description: A variable resistor with three terminals. Mechanical turning of a shaft can be used to produce variable resistance and potential. Example: A volume control is usually a potentiometer.

nodes.name: power supply rejection ratio (PSRR)
nodes.description: A measure of an op-amps ability to maintain a constant output when the supply voltage varies.

nodes.name: protoboard
nodes.description: Board with provision for attaching components without solder. Also called a breadboard. Primarily used for constructing experimental circuits. Q

nodes.name: quiescent point
nodes.description: (Q point) A point on the DC load line of a given amplifier that represents the quiescent (no signal) value of output voltage and current for the circuit. R

nodes.name: RC time constant
nodes.description: Product of resistance and capacitance in seconds.

nodes.name: recombination
nodes.description: Process by which a conduction band electron gives up energy (in the form of heat or light) and falls into a valence band hole.

nodes.name: rectification
nodes.description: Process that converts alternating current to direct current.

nodes.name: rectifier
nodes.description: Diode circuit that converts alternating current into pulsating direct current.

nodes.name: regenerative feedback
nodes.description: Positive feedback. Feedback from the output of an amplifier to the input such that the feedback signal is in phase with the input signal. Used to produce oscillation.

nodes.name: regulated power supply
nodes.description: Power supply that maintains a constant output voltage under changing load conditions.

nodes.name: regulator
nodes.description: Device or circuit that maintains a desired output under changing conditions.

nodes.name: resistance
nodes.description: Symbolized “R” and measured in ohms. Opposition to current flow and dissipation of energy in the form of heat.

nodes.name: resistor
nodes.description: Component made of material that opposes flow of current and therefore has some value of resistance.

nodes.name: reverse bias
nodes.description: Bias on a PN junction that allows only leakage current (minority carriers) to flow. Positive polarity on the n-type material and negative polarity to the p-type material.

nodes.name: reverse breakdown voltage
nodes.description: Amount of reverse bias that will cause a PN junction to break down and conduct in the reverse direction.

nodes.name: reverse current
nodes.description: Current through a diode when reverse biased. An extremely small current also referred to as leakage.

nodes.name: reverse saturation current
nodes.description: Reverse current through a diode caused by thermal activity. This current is not affected by the amount of reverse bias on the component, but does vary with temperature.

nodes.name: R-2R ladder
nodes.description: Network or circuit composed of a sequence of L networks connected in tandem. Circuit used in digital to analog converters. S

nodes.name: saturation
nodes.description: Condition in which a further increase in one variable produces no further increase in the resultant effect. In a bipolar junction transistor, the condition when the emitter to collector voltage is less than the emitter to base voltage. This condition puts forward bias on the base to collector junction.

nodes.name: schematic diagram
nodes.description: Illustration of an electrical or electronic circuit with the components represented by their symbols.

nodes.name: scientific notation
nodes.description: Numbers entered as a number from one to ten multiplied by a power of ten. Example: 8765 = 8.765 × 10^3 .

nodes.name: SDRAM
nodes.description: Synchronous dynamic random-access memory, the most popular form of digital memory today. It differs from previous-generation DRAM in that all signal timing is relative to one clock.

nodes.name: self biasing
nodes.description: Gate bias for a field effect transistor in which source current through a resistor produces the voltage for gate to source bias.

nodes.name: semiconductor
nodes.description: An element which is neither a good conductor or a good insulator, but rather lies somewhere between the two. Characterized by a valence shell containing four electrons. Silicon, germanium and carbon are the semiconductors most frequently used in electronics.

nodes.name: series circuit
nodes.description: Circuit in which the components are connected end to end so that current has only one path to follow through the circuit.

nodes.name: signal to noise ratio (SNR)
nodes.description: Ratio of the magnitude of the signal to the magnitude of noise usually expressed in decibels.

nodes.name: silicon
nodes.description: (Si) Non metallic element (atomic number 14) used in pure form as a semiconductor.

nodes.name: silicon dioxide
nodes.description: Glass like material used as the gate insulating material in a MOSFET.

nodes.name: silicon transistor
nodes.description: A bipolar junction transistor using silicon as the semi conducting material.

nodes.name: solid state
nodes.description: Pertaining to circuits where signals pass through solid semiconductor material such as transistors and diodes as opposed to vacuum tubes where signals pass through a vacuum.

nodes.name: source follower
nodes.description: FET amplifier in which signal is applied between gate and drain with output taken between source and drain. Also called “common drain.”

nodes.name: source impedance
nodes.description: Impedance through which output current is taken from a source.

nodes.name: spectrum analyzer
nodes.description: Instrument used to display the frequency domain of a waveform plotting amplitude against frequency.

nodes.name: SPI
nodes.description: Serial Peripheral Interface, a very simple short-distance serial communication bus standard consisting of either two (clock and data) or three (clock, data and strobe) signals, popular for reading data from microcontroller peripherals such as ADCs.

nodes.name: summing amplifier
nodes.description: An op-amp circuit whose output is proportional to the sum of its instantaneous voltages.

nodes.name: superposition theorem
nodes.description: Theorem designed to simplify networks containing two or more sources. It states that in a network containing more than one source, the current at any one point is equal to the algebraic sum of the currents produced by each source acting separately. T

nodes.name: Thévenin's theorem
nodes.description: Theorem that replaces any complex network with a single voltage source in series with a single resistance.

nodes.name: threshold voltage
nodes.description: For an enhancement MOSFET, the minimum gate source voltage required for conduction of source drain current.

nodes.name: transconductance
nodes.description: Also called mutual conductance. Ratio of a change in output current to the change in input voltage that caused it.

nodes.name: transistor
nodes.description: Term derived from “transfer resistor.” Semiconductor device that can be used as an amplifier or as an electronic switch.

nodes.name: trivalent element
nodes.description: One having three valence electrons. Used as an impurity in semiconductor material to produce p-type material. Most commonly used trivalent elements are: Aluminum, Gallium and Boron. U

nodes.name: unity gain frequency
nodes.description: Frequency of operation for a device where the gain of the component drops to unity.

nodes.name: USB
nodes.description: Universal Serial Bus, an interface for connecting peripherals, including test instruments, to computers. V

nodes.name: valence shell
nodes.description: The outermost electron shell for a given atom. The number of electrons in this shell determines the conductivity of the atom.

nodes.name: varactor diode
nodes.description: PN junction diode with a high junction capacitance when reverse biased. Most often used as a voltage controlled capacitor. The varactor is also called: varicap, tuning diode and epicap.

nodes.name: variable capacitor
nodes.description: Capacitor whose capacitance can be change by varying the effective area of the plates or the distance between the plates.

nodes.name: variable resistor
nodes.description: Resistor whose resistance can be changed by turning a shaft. See also “potentiometer and rheostat.”

nodes.name: virtual ground
nodes.description: Point in a circuit that is always at approximately ground potential. Often a ground for voltage, but not for current. The summing junction in an op-amp circuit.

nodes.name: volt
nodes.description: Unit of potential difference or electromotive force. One volt is the potential difference needed to produce one ampere of current through a resistance of one ohm.

nodes.name: voltage
nodes.description: (V) Term used to designate electrical pressure or force that causes current to flow.

nodes.name: voltage amplifier
nodes.description: Amplifier designed to build up signal voltage. By design amplifiers can have a large voltage gain or a large current gain or a large power gain. Voltage amplifiers are designed to maximize voltage gain often at the expense of current gain or power gain.

nodes.name: voltage divider
nodes.description: Fixed or variable series resistor network connected across a voltage to obtain a desired fraction of that voltage.

nodes.name: voltage divider biasing
nodes.description: Biasing method used with amplifiers in which two series resistors connected across a source. The junction of the two biasing resistors provides correct bias voltage for the amplifier.

nodes.name: voltage drop
nodes.description: Voltage or difference in potential developed across a component due to current flow.

nodes.name: voltage feedback
nodes.description: Feedback configuration where a portion of the output voltage is fed back to the input of an amplifier.

nodes.name: voltage follower
nodes.description: Operational amplifier circuit characterized by a high input impedance, low output impedance and unity voltage gain. Used as a buffer between a source and a low impedance load.

nodes.name: voltage gain
nodes.description: Also called voltage amplification. Ratio of amplifier output voltage to input voltage usually expressed in decibels.

nodes.name: voltage multiplier
nodes.description: Rectifier circuit using diodes and capacitors to produce a DC output voltage that is some multiple of the peak value of AC input voltage. Cost effective way of producing higher DC voltages. Voltage doublers and voltage triplers are examples.

nodes.name: voltage regulator
nodes.description: Device or circuit that maintains constant output voltage (within certain limits) in spite of changing line voltage and/or load current.

nodes.name: voltage source
nodes.description: Circuit or device that supplies voltage to a load. W

nodes.name: Watt
nodes.description: X Y Z

nodes.name: zener diode
nodes.description: Semiconductor diode in which reverse breakdown voltage current causes the diode to develop a constant voltage. Used as a clamp for voltage regulation. *Return to Previous Chapter <https://wiki.analog.com/university/courses/ electronics/text/chapter-20>*

nodes.name: 1.6-5.6 Connector
