nodes.description: A coaxial connector which is usable for frequencies at max of 12 GHz. They were designed to be stable, compact, and have high data rates.

nodes.name: 1.85mm and 2.4mm Connector
nodes.description: Both 1.85mm and 2.4mm connectors are physically compatible and require 5/16" wrench. They will not thread onto SMA, 3.5mm or 2.92mm connectors, and are commonly known as "V" connectors.

nodes.name: 1mm Connector
nodes.description: An RF connector that can perform up to 110 GHz. It performs at the highest frequency when compared to other millimeter wave connectors on the market.

nodes.name: 2.92mm Connector
nodes.description: Both 2.92mm and 3.5mm connector styles mate with SMA connectors, and with each other. These connectors offer higher maximum frequencies than SMA connectors. 2.92mm connectors usually work up to 46 GHz.

nodes.name: 3 dB Bandwidth
nodes.description: The bandwidth described by the width between the points at which the signal's strength is reduced by 3 db.

nodes.name: 3.5mm Connector
nodes.description: Both 3.5mm and 2.92mm connector styles mate with SMA connectors, and with each other. These connectors offer higher maximum frequencies than SMA connectors 3.5mm connectors usually work up to 34 GHz.

nodes.name: 4.1-9.5 Connector
nodes.description: 4.1-9.5 connectors are especially rugged and weatherproof due to their screw-lock mechanism. They are generally operable up to 10 GHz and offer low reflection ratios and low PIM performance.

nodes.name: 7/16 Connector
nodes.description: A coaxial connector that works with medium/high power low transmission up to 8.3 GHz that provides little attenuation. Usable in more harsh conditions (such as in the presence of moisture) and often employed for its low PIM characteristics.

nodes.name: 7mm Connector
nodes.description: These unique 7mm connectors, which perform at frequencies up to 18 GHz, are sexless. Every connector can be fitted to each other based on the direction of the coupling nut. They also have the lowest VSWR.

nodes.name: Ablation, RF and Microwave
nodes.description: The separation of radio and microwave frequencies.

nodes.name: Absorption
nodes.description: Loss of power in fiber optic cable, due to heat, which is also known as scattering.

nodes.name: Acceptance angle
nodes.description: The angle that is acceptable for signal transmission in fiber optic cable, which is measured from the centerline of the fiber optic core.

nodes.name: Acousto-optic modulator
nodes.description: A device the uses sound waves in order to vary the phase and amplitude of a light beam (i.e. a laser).

nodes.name: Active Device
nodes.description: A device that affects the magnitude of one or multiple responses caused by an external energy source.

nodes.name: Active port diameter
nodes.description: The diameter of the area in the particular part of a light source in which light is guided to or from an optical fiber.

nodes.name: Adapters
nodes.description: Connectors that allow the connection between two cables whose male- female types do not necessarily match. Adapters exist in male to male (a barrel), female to female (a bullet), and male to female (a connector saver) connectors.

nodes.name: AESA
nodes.description: Active Electronically Steered Antenna

nodes.name: Albaloy
nodes.description: Albaloy is a plating finish which has a high resistance to tarnish compared to silver. It's non-magnetic properties has exceptional passive intermodulation (PIM) performance similar to silver. It is a mixture of copper, tin, and zinc.

nodes.name: Alloy
nodes.description: A metallic compound that combines multiple types of metals to produce controllable select properties pertaining to tensile strength, shear strength ductility, malleability, and/or conductivity.

nodes.name: Alloy, Fusible
nodes.description: These alloys are in liquid state below room temperature (similar to mercury). These solders are not commonly used in microwave engineering

nodes.name: Alloys, Low Expansion
nodes.description: A material that has been experimented on by engineers for over 100 years because of their temperature expansion characteristic. Alloys that have low expansion are often used in glass feedthroughs and microwave housings.

nodes.name: Alumina
nodes.description: Alumina is a ceramic material used mostly in the Microwave Integrated Circuit industry. It is offered in 96% and 99.5% concentrations, each of which have different applications. For example, high-temperature circuits generally use 96%, while thin-film circuits use 99.5%.

nodes.name: Aluminum
nodes.description: Material used as either a conductor or packing material. Symbol: Al, Atomic number: 13.

nodes.name: Aluminum Nitride
nodes.description: A material classified in the ceramics family, AIN has high thermal conductivity and is often used in heat sinks, IC packages, and substrates in electronic packages. A safe substitute for Beo substrates.

nodes.name: Aluminum silicon carbide (AlSiC)
nodes.description: These housings that were net-shaped were very popular in the 1990's

nodes.name: Amplifier
nodes.description: A device whose purpose is to take an input signal and increase its amplitude by a certain amount.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Active Directivity of
nodes.description: Measurement of the potential effect of output impedance based on an amplifier's source match, or the effect on input impedance based on an amplifier's load match. Larger active directivity is better.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Balanced
nodes.description: A device that has two amplifiers run at 90 degrees difference in phase transmission. At the input, two signals are set 90 degrees apart, and at the output the difference is removed so that they are at the same phase.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Classes of
nodes.description: Types of Amplifiers, classified based on the bias point (quiescent point "Q"). In class A, the bias point divides the distance between the saturated current and pinch-off current in two. Examples include gain- block and linear amplifiers. Class B amplifiers only conduct half of a signal's cycle. Class AB amplifiers' bias point lie somewhere between class A and B, which provides a good balance between gain, efficiency, and power. In class C, a tuning circuit filters the signal for a single frequency, and behaves like a class B. Classes D, E, and F are switching amplifiers.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Conditionally Stable
nodes.description: An undesirable condition where the amplifier will oscillate under a specific load or source impedance.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Directivity of
nodes.description: A parameter used represent the amount that the input impedance is influenced by the load impedance and also how much the output impedance is affected by the source impedance.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Distributed (Traveling Wave Amplifiers)
nodes.description: Distributed Amplifiers are used as amplification solutions for up to 100 GHz, and down to DC applications. These amplifiers use the capacitive qualities of FETs as well as high-impedance lines to mimic a standard 50 Ohm line for impedance-matching.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Doherty
nodes.description: A type of amplifier that is often used in communications (radios), and performs more efficiently than balanced amplifiers.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Dynamic Range of
nodes.description: The range of power wherein the amplifier operates linearly.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Feedback of
nodes.description: Two types of feedback exists, series and parallel. They can be used to change the characteristics of an amplifier such as its gain vs. frequency, its K-factor, and its input matching characteristics.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Feed-forward
nodes.description: Feed-forward Amplifiers are used in applications where low distortion is key, such as in base station equipment.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Gain Block
nodes.description: Gain block amplifiers are simple and convenient and are used for general purpose applications. They offer a wide bandwidth, but usually at the cost of efficiency and noise.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Gain Flatness of
nodes.description: Gain Flatness refers to the variation in gain over the bandwidth, and is represented as a value ±dB. To calculate this value, subtract the highest gain in the band from the lowest and divide by two.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Gain of
nodes.description: A ratio of the output of an amplifier over its input. The equation for gain is in decibels and is define as follows: G = 10 log10 (Out/In).

nodes.name: Amplifier, Harmonic Distortion of
nodes.description: Harmonic distortion presents itself in the form of output frequencies at integer multiples of the input frequency. It is generally caused by non- linearity in the amplifier, and is described in terms of the relative level to input power.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Isolation of
nodes.description: The ratio of applied output power to measured input power.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Linearity of
nodes.description: Refers to how well the output of an amplifier can be described by a linear function of the amplifiers input. In other words, the output is scaled by a constant factor of the input without much distortion.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Log
nodes.description: An amplifier in which the output voltage is scaled by the log of the input.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Low Noise (LNA)
nodes.description: An amplifier that is used to take weak signals and amplify them so that they can be more easily used. The effect of noise is reduced by the gain of the LNA, while the noise of the LNA itself is injected directly into the received signal.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Maximum Signal Level of
nodes.description: A threshold for which the greatest CW or pulse RF signal can be used without permanent noise figure degradation, amplified distortion, amplification reduction, and/or overheating of the amplifier.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Noise Factor of
nodes.description: Noise Factor is the ratio of the relative amount of noise at the input signal compared to the relative amount of noise at the output signal

nodes.name: Amplifier, Nonlinearity of
nodes.description: Amplifiers can only magnify a signal so much. At small input signals, the gain in the signal appears to be linear, however at large input signals, the output will reach a maximum value and may no longer be the same gain as with the small signal, hence non-linear.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Power
nodes.description: Takes a small signal and increases it to make a large signal. Power is generally considered between 0.5 Watts up to 4 Watts. High Power amplifiers are designed for power above 4 Watts.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Pulsed
nodes.description: For an amplifier to be pulsed, it is electrically switched off when the signal is not being amplified. The majority of CW amplifiers are able to be used as pulsed amplifiers but not the other way around. The pulsing of an amplifier results in cooler operating temperatures by the reduction of DC power dissipation. In this way, pulse amplifiers can be run at higher power. Due to this design, continuously powered amp will cause damage from heat. Therefore, the magnitude of duty cycle will directly affect the temperature of the amp. These devices need special power supplies to provide DC bias point during its duty cycle. One feature of these power supplies often require large storage capacitors. The amp bandwidth should be taken into consideration for very short pulses.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Push-Pull
nodes.description: A device that uses two amplifiers which have 180 degrees difference in phase.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Return Loss (RL)
nodes.description: Return loss (RL) describes reflected-to-incident power ratio at an RF port of an amplifier. Expressed as RL = -20 log |?|, ? = voltage reflection coefficient and RL is in units of dB.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Reverse Gain of
nodes.description: The ratio of input over output when power is applied at the output amplifier, and the input power is measured.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Tube
nodes.description: Amplifiers that uses vacuum tubes to amplify a signal.

nodes.name: Amplifier, Wideband
nodes.description: Amplifiers that are capable of amplifying signals in a wide range of frequencies.

nodes.name: Amplitude
nodes.description: Amplitude refers to variation in value of a signal relative to some point, called its zero. Words such as "peak", "maximum" and "rms" are often used to describe the type of amplitude.

nodes.name: Amplitude Balance
nodes.description: The difference in peak-to-peak amplitude (measured in dB) between a power divider's output ports over a specific range of frequency.

nodes.name: Amplitude Match
nodes.description: A comparison between a reference filter and a filter being tested which analyzes the absolute difference of the amplitude response.

nodes.name: Amplitude Modulation Measurement
nodes.description: An accurate measurement of modulation levels which is acquired through a spectrum analyzer.

nodes.name: Amplitude tracking
nodes.description: Difference in amplitude between a test filter and a reference filter.

nodes.name: Analog
nodes.description: A continuously varying signal (such as sound waves). The bandwidth and frequency of an analog signal is measured in Hertz (Hz).

nodes.name: Angle of Arrival
nodes.description: Angle of arrival is the angle at which the radio wave collides with the antennas.

nodes.name: Angle of Incidence
nodes.description: Angle measured from the angle perpendicular to the surface and the angle of the ray of light that strikes the surface.

nodes.name: Angstrom ( Å )
nodes.description: Named after Anders Jonas Angstrom, the Angstrom is a length equal to one tenth of a nanometer

nodes.name: Angular Misalignment Loss
nodes.description: The energy that is lost in an optical signal because two optical components are not properly aligned.

nodes.name: Anode
nodes.description: The anode, generally paired with a cathode, is a positive terminal for a component. Being that it is positive, electron flow is directed toward the anode.

nodes.name: Antenna
nodes.description: A device which interprets electrical signals/radio waves and transforms it to the other form (signal to waves, waves to signal)

nodes.name: Antenna, Horn
nodes.description: A horn shaped directional antenna, designed by William T. Slayton in 1954.

nodes.name: Antenna, Microstrip Patch
nodes.description: A flat antenna which sits atop a microstrip, with a wide beam and a narrow bandwidth.

nodes.name: Antenna, Monopulse
nodes.description: An antenna capable of gathering angle data with only a single pulse

nodes.name: Antenna, Vivaldi
nodes.description: Vivaldi antennas, also known as "tapered slot antennas," are used for their surprisingly large bandwidth and ease of fabrication.

nodes.name: Antimonide-Based Compound Semiconductors
nodes.description: A semiconductor device that only requires 100 millivolts to operate. Has applications in low power systems

nodes.name: Anti-Reflection Coating
nodes.description: A material which is applied to a surface and is used to reduce the amount of reflection and increase light transmission

nodes.name: APC-7 Connector
nodes.description: APC is an acronym for Amphenol Precision Connectors. APC-7 describes a 7 millimeter connector. It is a coaxial connector used for microwave signals for 18 GHz frequencies maximum.

nodes.name: Arbitrary Waveform Generator
nodes.description: A piece of electrical equipment used to generate waveforms.

nodes.name: Arc Suppression Diodes
nodes.description: Diodes used for arc suppression. The goal of arc suppression is to minimize the amount of sparks created when two contacts that are passing current are separated.

nodes.name: Atmospheric Pressure
nodes.description: Atmospheric pressure is measured in various units such as mmHg (Torr), inches Hg, inches water, Pascals (Pa), and atm (atmosphere). Lower atmospheric pressure results in the breakdown of voltage at lower electric field strength. Some conversions include: 1atm = 760 Torr = 760mmHg = 14.69 PSI = 101325 Pa. SI unit for pressure is Pascals.

nodes.name: Attenuation
nodes.description: The loss of amplitude of a signal as it passes through a medium

nodes.name: Attenuation Accuracy
nodes.description: The magnitude of variation in attenuation from the expected value across the operating band.

nodes.name: Attenuation Coefficient
nodes.description: Also called linear attenuation coefficient, the attenuation coefficient is calculated by summing the absorption and scattering coefficients. A large attenuation coefficient means that a signal is quickly weakened as it passes through a medium.

nodes.name: Attenuation Constants
nodes.description: The reduction of amplitude in voltage and current. The reduction is an exponential function which changed with line length.

nodes.name: Attenuation-Limited Operation
nodes.description: When a fiber optic system's performance becomes limited due to the incoming signal amplitude as opposed to distortion. (Bandwidth-limited operation; Distortion-limited operation.)

nodes.name: Attenuator
nodes.description: Used in the extension of dynamic range of devices like power meters and amplifiers, this device transmits an input signal with minimal distortion by absorbing part of the signal itself. The attenuator is also used as a way to equalize signal levels in transmission lines.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Continuously Variable
nodes.description: An attenuator whose attenuation value can be changed along a series of continuous values.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Digital
nodes.description: A type of attenuator that can be controlled by digital signals. The number of attenuation states it has depends on the number of states the digital signals have.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Fixed
nodes.description: Fixed attenuators are available in many forms such as chip, coaxial, and waveguide forms. The frequency of operation and the power handling are the main points to consider when choosing a fixed attenuator.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Flatness of
nodes.description: The total variation in the attenuation of an attenuator over a specific range of frequency. Flatness typically worsens at higher frequencies.

nodes.name: Attenuator, In-control Isolation of Bi-phase
nodes.description: The electronic attenuator's insertion loss, which depends on the transformer used to give coupling from the RF input to the internal diodes, and is independent of the amount of control current. It is measured from the RF input to the control port.

nodes.name: Attenuator, In-out Isolation of Bi-phase
nodes.description: The insertion loss, when no current flows through the control port, from input to output

nodes.name: Attenuator, Insertion Loss of Bi-phase
nodes.description: The loss in power from input to output at a particular input current.

nodes.name: Attenuator, L-Pad
nodes.description: Used to match two impedances. This particular type of solution results in signal loss

nodes.name: Attenuator, Maximum RF Power of
nodes.description: The maximum power that can be supplied to the attenuator without overheating.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Reflection
nodes.description: Contains a four-port quadrature coupler, consisting of two matched terminations on the through and coupled ports. These terminations must show an impedance that is at least partially real in order for the device to work.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Return Loss of
nodes.description: Measure from one port while the other port is connected to a 50 or 75 ohm termination.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Return Loss of Bi-phase
nodes.description: The magnitude of power returned involving the input in relation to the incident power at the input for a given control current. A low control current level will result in small return loss while a high control current will result in very high return loss.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Step
nodes.description: Divisions in which the attenuator can be set to reduce the signal by specific amounts.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Switchable
nodes.description: Switchable attenuators consist of two general categories: switched network attenuators and switched element attenuators. They offer electrically or mechanically controllable attenuation states.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Switched-Element
nodes.description: Similar to a pi pad network using resistive elements capable of realizing multiple values. It uses field effect transistors for switching.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Switched-Network
nodes.description: Versatile attenuators that can that can support multiple values of attenuation.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Temperature Compensating Fixed
nodes.description: Used with amplifiers so as to counteract the gain vs. temperature effect amplifiers. In these types of attenuators, the loss of the attenuator decreases as the temperature increases.

nodes.name: Attenuator, Variable
nodes.description: Attenuators which can change the amount of attenuation via an applied voltage.

nodes.name: Attenuator, VSWR of
nodes.description: Voltage standing wave ratio is a representation of signal reflection in RF devices. In attenuators, VSWR is a metric describing the impedance mismatch between the input and the attenuator.

nodes.name: Avalanche Photodiode (APD)
nodes.description: A light sensor which is capable of detecting weak light signals and needs high voltage to operate.

nodes.name: Axial Ray
nodes.description: Light that travels along the same axis as the fiber.

nodes.name: Axis
nodes.description: A straight reference line which passes through the center of some object or body. This can be represented as a real or imaginary line.

nodes.name: Azimuth
nodes.description: The angle from a reference zero point along the horizontal axis. It is usually represented by the Greek letter phi (?) or abbreviated AZ.

nodes.name: Backscattering
nodes.description: Scattered light that travels in the opposite direction of the light,

nodes.name: Backside Processing
nodes.description: This term is comprised of three to four critical process steps lumped together. It takes place after final-front side, in which the wafer, which was previously thinned to the desired thickness of the RF designers, is flipped face-down and mounted onto a high-tech wax material.

nodes.name: Balun
nodes.description: Derived from the words BAL-ance and UN-balance. A balun is a device that changes an unbalanced signal to a balanced one or vice versa.

nodes.name: Band Reject Filter
nodes.description: A band reject filter passes all frequencies above and below a specific band of frequencies. The frequencies in this band are stopped from passing.

nodes.name: Band-gap
nodes.description: Band-gap represents a material's ability to resist breakdown under high voltage. The higher a material's band-gap, the higher its breakdown voltage, and the more power it can withstand.

nodes.name: Bandpass Filter
nodes.description: A filter that lets a specific range of frequencies pass, while rejecting higher and lower frequencies.

nodes.name: Bandwidth
nodes.description: The width of the frequencies between the two points where half the power of the signal is lost.

nodes.name: Barrel Adapter
nodes.description: A two ended, male-to-male adapter for various connector types.

nodes.name: Barrier Seal
nodes.description: A material which seals the gap between the insulator (dielectric) and the conductor (inner and outer), preventing gasses and moisture from permeating the connector it is mounted on.

nodes.name: Base Material
nodes.description: The underlying metal material used in the production of connectors, contacts, or other accessory parts. The base material may have one or more metals deposited onto it.

nodes.name: Base Station
nodes.description: A device from which a mobile radio transceiver establishes a connection. This fixed device allows the transceiver to gain access to the public switched telephone network.

nodes.name: Bayonet Coupling
nodes.description: A method of connection in which a rotating peg-and-slot mechanism secures the plug and receptacle together.

nodes.name: Beam Divergence
nodes.description: The widening of a beams diameter as a result of it traveling farther from the source.

nodes.name: Beam-splitter
nodes.description: Used to split an optical beam into several beams

nodes.name: Bending Radius
nodes.description: The minimum radius at which a cable is still able to successfully transmit a signal. If the radius of the cable becomes any less the signal will not be properly transferred.

nodes.name: Beryllium Oxide ()
nodes.description: A material with high thermal conductivity and low expansion properties. While it may seem like a optimal solution to prevent sumiconductor overheating, BeO is a toxic material.

nodes.name: Bessel Filter
nodes.description: A Bessel filter is an analog filter that displays constant time delay and preserves the wave shape of filtered signals in the pass-band.

nodes.name: Bias Networks
nodes.description: A network used to set the quiescent operating point of a FET in a device.

nodes.name: Bias Tee
nodes.description: A type of diplexer, used to supply DC voltage or current to RF devices.

nodes.name: Bi-directional Coupler
nodes.description: A single coupler that doesn't terminate internally, this 4-port coupler allows the forward and reflected signals to be sampled at the same time.

nodes.name: Birefringence
nodes.description: The phenomenon of when two diverging beams separate after passing through a doubly refracting object. These two beams are also known as ordinary and extraordinary beams.

nodes.name: Bit Error Rate (BER)
nodes.description: The number of errors divided by the overall number of bits.

nodes.name: Bluetooth
nodes.description: Uses radio waves of short wavelength in the ISM band from 2.4 to 2.485 GHz in order to send and/or receive data over short distances. Commonly used in personal electronic devices and in-home networks.

nodes.name: BMA
nodes.description: Blind-Mate A connector used in microwave applications to 18 GHz - 26.5 GHz . BMAs utilize a slide-on interface and are designed to allow minimal radial and axial misalignment.

nodes.name: BNC Connector (50 Ohms)
nodes.description: This is a type of coaxial connector that has a two stud bayonet coupling mechanism, and is used for telecom and data system applications that perform up to 4 GHz (maximum 10 GHz). BNC connectors make fast and easy connections, and are very reliable.

nodes.name: BNC Connector (75 Ohms)
nodes.description: A coaxial connector with a Bayonet fastening mechanism.

nodes.name: BNC Reverse Polarity Connector
nodes.description: The non-standardized versions of common BNC connectors, these coaxial connectors operate up to 4GHz. While being similar to standard BNC connectors, the center contacts are reversed and the dielectric may be reversed as well. For instance, a male polarity connector using a female center contact and dielectric and visa versa. The purpose and application of this type of connector is regulated by IEEE/FCC. The type with bayonet coupling mechanism have a max frequency up to 10GHz (optimum at 4GHz) with characteristic impedances of Z=50 Ohms. The bayonet design allows for quick and dependable connections and disconnections.

nodes.name: BNO
nodes.description: A connector appropriate for shielded twin-axial cables. The connector uses a bayonet coupling system.

nodes.name: BNT
nodes.description: Bayonet Coupling Mechanism is a connector designed to be used for triaxial cables.

nodes.name: Boltzmann Constant
nodes.description: A constant whose value is 1.38 x 10^-23 J/K.

nodes.name: Bonded Assembly
nodes.description: A method of assembling connectors in which an appropriate adhesive bonds components together, sealing them from the elements while not interfering with the connector's electrical properties.

nodes.name: Boresight
nodes.description: The direction that an antenna physically pointed to achieve maximum object illumination.

nodes.name: Boresight error (BSE)
nodes.description: Difference between the physical or optical boresight and the electromagnetic boresight.

nodes.name: Brazing
nodes.description: Similar to welding but uses lower temperatures and materials that melt at lower temperatures.

nodes.name: Bulkhead
nodes.description: Commonly used to refer to the connector mounting method. Bulkhead connectors are made to be inserted either from the front side or rear (component) side of a panel.

nodes.name: Bullet Adapter
nodes.description: A two ended, female-to-female adapter for various connector types.

nodes.name: Butted Contact
nodes.description: Conductors which connect on their axes without overlapping.

nodes.name: Butterworth (maximally flat amplitude)
nodes.description: A filter that has lower stop band attenuation, group delay flatness, and overshoot than Chebyshev. It also has best in-band amplitude flatness.

nodes.name: Butterworth Filter
nodes.description: This filter provides the flattest possible, monotonic response in its passband which rolls off consistently at 6dB per octave per pole.

nodes.name: C Connector
nodes.description: A coaxial connector capable of frequencies up to 11 GHz uses bayonet coupling for connection.

nodes.name: Cable
nodes.description: A material capable of passing some signal usually surrounded by strengthening strands and a protective jacket.

nodes.name: Cable Assembly
nodes.description: The cable itself along with the related hardware.

nodes.name: Capacitance
nodes.description: The primary electrical property of capacitor, measured in Farads. It is a measure of energy storage.

nodes.name: Capacitor, Charge-Storage
nodes.description: Capacitors are capable of storing a charge/voltage in their plates.

nodes.name: Capacitor, DC Blocks
nodes.description: Stops the flow of DC current through the use of capacitors.

nodes.name: Capacitor, Electrolytic
nodes.description: This kind of capacitor is usually made of tantalum, and provides the highest capacitance density. They are polarized, and often used for filtering power supply for microwave circuits. However, they are not microwave quality. At least two electrolytic capacitors are needed for linear regulators to remain stable (one on the input and one on the output).

nodes.name: Capacitor, Multi-Layer Ceramic
nodes.description: Capacitors with large capacitance to volume ratios utilizing a ceramic material as its dielectric. Because of their size, they are ideal for use as surface-mount devices on PCBs.

nodes.name: Capacitor, RF Bypass
nodes.description: An RF bypass parallel element that is meant to reflect RF signals by shorting them out. This filter uses microwave capacitors.

nodes.name: Capacitor, Single Layer
nodes.description: Capacitors using a single thin film as a dielectric, which are ideal for high frequency uses. They are often used in systems using frequencies higher than 110 GHz.

nodes.name: Captivated
nodes.description: A term for center conductors that are held in place by the body of the connector, degrades performance.

nodes.name: Cathode
nodes.description: A terminal on an electrical component where electrons flow into. The terminal in which the electrons leave is known as the anode.

nodes.name: Center Frequency
nodes.description: The mean (average) frequency of all of the frequencies in the bandwidth of a given filter. See Bandwidth.

nodes.name: Characteristic Angle
nodes.description: The angle in which a certain mode travels down an optical fiber. Also see: Mode.

nodes.name: Characteristic Impedance
nodes.description: The ratio of the current and voltage phase at any place along the transmission line, given that only one wave travels down a line.

nodes.name: Chebyshev (equal-ripple amplitude) Filter
nodes.description: A very popular filter configuration offering very high stop-band attenuation and overshoot, but at the expense of group delay.

nodes.name: Chebyshev Filter
nodes.description: A filter that more quickly attenuates signals which are beyond the cutoff frequency and that has a predetermined pass band ripple.

nodes.name: Circulator
nodes.description: A passive device whose purpose is to control the flow of the incident signal through one of its three ports.

nodes.name: Cladding
nodes.description: A transparent layer surrounding the light-carrying core of an optical fiber. The cladding has a lower refractive index compared to the core and coatings may be applied to it.

nodes.name: Cladding Mode
nodes.description: The cladding has a larger refractive index than the material surrounding it.

nodes.name: Clamp
nodes.description: A connector style that installs without crimp tools.

nodes.name: Closed Entry Contact
nodes.description: A female contact that is made to prevent an entry of a probing device or pin that has a diameter which is greater than the mating pin.

nodes.name: Coaxial Braid
nodes.description: Wires which are woven into flat braids that cover a conductor or cable. The purpose is for the protection of insulated wires and cables.

nodes.name: Coaxial Cable
nodes.description: Cable that is used for transmission of radio signals. The cable consists of a core which transmits the signal, a dielectric insulator, a metallic shield, and plastic jacket.

nodes.name: Coaxial Cavity Resonator
nodes.description: Transmission line sections of certain termination resistances and lengths that have similar resonance characteristics to oscillating circuits that contain resistance, inductance, and capacitance.

nodes.name: Coaxial Connector
nodes.description: This type of connector provides a connection between two lines that not only have the same characteristic impedance, but also are as reliable, reflection-free, and uniform as possible. It has good electrical transmission characteristics, offers a insensitivity of a high degree toward electromagnetic interference, and is simple to connect and disconnect. The characteristic impedance of the different cables can be well matched to the characteristic impedance of the coaxial connector.

nodes.name: Coherent
nodes.description: Light which not only has waves that are in phase with each other, but also have identical frequencies. This kind of light is only produced by lasers.

nodes.name: Collimated
nodes.description: To make rays of light or particles accurately parallel. Parallel light rays, like in a laser beam, are collimated.

nodes.name: Combiner
nodes.description: A common point in a single fiber collects optical power from several input fibers in this passive device. Also see: Coupler.

nodes.name: Conductivity
nodes.description: How well a material can conduct current. It is the inverse of resistance and has units of 1/Ohm

nodes.name: Conductors
nodes.description: A conductor is a material that, simply put, conducts electricity and allows current to flow. Technically speaking, the definition of a conductor dictates that the material be between 10^6 and 10^4 Ohm-cm. Outside of that range lie superconductors, semiconductors, and insulators.

nodes.name: Connector
nodes.description: A fitting that is installed at the ends of fiber optic cables, light sources, receivers or housings. The connector mates to corresponding devices that also have installed fittings. For example, a connector can join two fiber optic cables and extend the light transmission.

nodes.name: Connector Gender
nodes.description: The gender of a connector can be male or female. Male connectors have a protruding connection, while the female connector has a crevice where the male connector can sit. There do exists some "sexless" connectors when can connect to any other sexless connector of the same type.

nodes.name: Connector, Elbow
nodes.description: A connector that is bent so that it can connect two components that are not parallel to each other. These connectors exist in right angle connectors and swept connectors which are better at high frequencies than angle connectors.

nodes.name: Connector, Push-On
nodes.description: Connectors with a simple "push-on" mechanism. May be used when there are not threads on the components or simply for ease of use.

nodes.name: Connector, Reverse Polarity
nodes.description: For a connector to be considered "reverse polarity," its inner conductor's gender must be the opposite of the outer conductor or sheath. For example, a male reverse-polarity connector has a female inner conductor contact.

nodes.name: Contact
nodes.description: The part of the connector that physically touches the other connector through which a signal is passed.

nodes.name: Contact Alignment
nodes.description: This defines the degree of loose fit which contacts are restricted to within the insert cavity so that mated contacts can still self-align. Also called the contact float.

nodes.name: Contact Cavity
nodes.description: The area of a connector on which the contact must be fitted.

nodes.name: Contact Durability
nodes.description: A number defining the expected number of connections that a connector can withstand before performance dips below a certain standard.

nodes.name: Contact Engaging & Separating Force
nodes.description: The amount of force required to remove and insert pin-and-socket contact connectors. The required specification will vary based on product application.

nodes.name: Contact Plating
nodes.description: A plating used on contacts that provides protection for the contact.

nodes.name: Contact Pressure
nodes.description: The pressure between mating surfaces exerted on each other.

nodes.name: Contact Resistance
nodes.description: The electrical resistance of a connector under normal use, as measured at a particular testing current.

nodes.name: Contact Retention
nodes.description: The smallest axial force that a contact has to endure while it is connected in its appropriate position.

nodes.name: Continuous Wave
nodes.description: A wave which has a constant amplitude.

nodes.name: Convection
nodes.description: The process of transferring heat through the air.

nodes.name: Conversion Loss
nodes.description: A property of mixers referring to the total loss of signal power from input to output. It is measured by inputting a known control signal and LO, and measuring the output.

nodes.name: Coplanarity
nodes.description: The separation length of a connector when one a flat surface between the highest and lowest lead.

nodes.name: Core
nodes.description: The center of an optical fiber, often made out of glass, that is used to transfer light.

nodes.name: Coupler
nodes.description: A device used to take one signal at a single input and splits it among several outputs. It can also take several inputs and merge them into one output signal.

nodes.name: Couplers and Splitters
nodes.description: Components used to combine or split microwave/RF signals. Both components work in both directions, with splitters either dividing or combining power, and couplers either sampling or adding a signal to a main path.

nodes.name: Coupling efficiency
nodes.description: The fraction of light that exists at the source compared to the amount of light that passes into the optical fiber.

nodes.name: Coupling loss
nodes.description: The amount of power lost at discrete junctions (i.e. fiber-to-detector, fiber-to-fiber, source-to-fiber) in a fiber optic link.

nodes.name: Coverage
nodes.description: A percentage which indicates how much the shield or broad covers the component underneath.

nodes.name: Crimp
nodes.description: To deform a connector ferrule around a cable to make an electrical connection.

nodes.name: Crimping Dies
nodes.description: The part of a crimping tool that makes contact with the terminal.

nodes.name: Crimping Termination
nodes.description: A connection that is made by mechanically crimping a metal sleeve with crimp dies, presses, or pliers, in order to secure in to a conductor.

nodes.name: Crimping Tool
nodes.description: A hand-held tool used to crimp, but not sever, certain electrical components such as contacts, ferrules, or terminals. Crimping tools are most commonly used to secure connectors to a coaxial cable.

nodes.name: Critical Angle
nodes.description: The smallest angle, relative to the normal, that light may contact the outer edge of a medium so as to ensure total internal reflection.

nodes.name: Crosstalk
nodes.description: Crosstalk is mutual interference of signals in electrical systems or adjacent transmission lines, which is caused by magnetic, electromagnetic, and/or electrical coupling.

nodes.name: Crystal Oscillator
nodes.description: A circuit that uses a vibrating crystal to produce an electrical signal at a specific frequency.

nodes.name: Cutback technique
nodes.description: Used to measure the attenuation/distortion of a fiber by taking measurements with the full cable length and another when the cable has been cut at a point less than full length.

nodes.name: Cutoff Frequency
nodes.description: The largest frequency at which a signals is not attenuated much. Any frequencies beyond the cutoff frequency become greatly reduced.

nodes.name: Cycle
nodes.description: One complete sequence of periodically occurring values, measured from a relative zero to some maximum value and back.

nodes.name: DAS (Distributed Antenna System)
nodes.description: A network of separated antennas connected to a common source that provides wireless service within a geographic area or structure such as an office building or school campus.

nodes.name: dB – (Decibel)
nodes.description: The logarithmic unit measuring the ratio of input to output. It is generally used as the unit for gain and loss.

nodes.name: dBc
nodes.description: Power ratio for a signal carrier. Typically, this unit is used for measuring passive intermodulation distortion.

nodes.name: dBm
nodes.description: Decibels that are related to 1 mW. The microwave industry uses 1 mW as the standard unit to measure power level. Examples: 0 dBm = 1 mW, +10 dBm = 10 mW, +20 dBm = 100 mW, etc.

nodes.name: dBW
nodes.description: A decibel watt describes the power of a signal relative to a watt in decibels.

nodes.name: DC block
nodes.description: An electrical component, often a capacitor in series or a parallel coupled line, that separates DC voltages from an RF signal.

nodes.name: DC return
nodes.description: A DC ground is added to an RF line through DC return. For example, it can provide a path for the current of a series diode to return to in a PIN diode switch.

nodes.name: De-embedding
nodes.description: Calibration of ports in measuring or testing equipment.

nodes.name: Delay Line
nodes.description: A cable with the ability to delay electrical signals by a specific quantity of time.

nodes.name: Demodulator
nodes.description: A component used to split the desired data signal from the carrier signal.

nodes.name: Detector
nodes.description: A component used to convert light or infrared radiation to electrical signal, used in fiber optics.

nodes.name: Dewetting
nodes.description: When a wire, pad or lead becomes disconnected from its soldered connection. This could be due to prolonged exposure to temperature, inconsistencies or impurities.

nodes.name: Dielectric
nodes.description: A insulating material is dielectric if it can transmit an electrical force. In coaxial, the dielectric changes the cable's impedance, capacitance, and other characteristics.

nodes.name: Dielectric Constant (Permittivity)
nodes.description: A property that determines how a material is affected by an electric field.

nodes.name: Dielectric Loss
nodes.description: A loss in power due to heat dissipation in the dielectric material.

nodes.name: Dielectric Strength
nodes.description: The maximum voltage at which an insulating material can withstand before electrical breakdown.

nodes.name: Dielectric Withstanding Voltage
nodes.description: Also known as breakdown voltage, this is the potential at which dielectric material breakdown occurs.

nodes.name: Diffuse Reflection
nodes.description: The opposite of spectral reflection, diffuse reflection describes light which bounces in arbitrary directions after impacting a surface.

nodes.name: DIN
nodes.description: The German standards organization. A type of electrical connector used for various applications.

nodes.name: Diode
nodes.description: Diodes were first used in crystal radios about 100 years ago, and are now used in the switching, mixing, detection, and generating of microwave signals. Diodes are 2-terminal, nonlinear semiconductors.

nodes.name: Diode Laser
nodes.description: A diode laser is a solid state semiconductor device which has at least one p-n junction that, under specified conditions, can emit stimulated, coherent radiation.

nodes.name: Diodes, Gunn
nodes.description: A diode that is used as an electrical oscillator which produces microwaves.

nodes.name: Diodes, PIN
nodes.description: This type of diode can be made on silicon or GaAs. "PIN" is an acronym that stands for P-type, intrinsic, and N-type, which corresponds to a stack of semiconductor materials.

nodes.name: Diodes, Schottky
nodes.description: Diodes which are composed of a metal connected to a semiconductor. Schottky diodes can be accidentally created by using connectors with different metals.

nodes.name: Diodes, Tunnel
nodes.description: A semiconductor junction diode that has an I-V curve which has a portion of negative resistance. These diodes are heavily impregnated with impurities and are used in many microwave applications. The region of negative resistance can be used to create oscillators and efficient detectors.

nodes.name: Diodes, Zener
nodes.description: A diode similar to an ideal diode but also allows the flow of current in the opposite direction when the voltage has reached a certain level known as the breakdown voltage.

nodes.name: Dip Solder Terminal
nodes.description: Ends on connector that are place in the holes on a printed circuit board which are then soldered to keep them in place.

nodes.name: Diplexer
nodes.description: A circuit which takes an input and then output it to one of two output ports depending on the frequency of the signal. A signal in a certain bandwidth gets output to a specific port.

nodes.name: Direct Current (DC)
nodes.description: Current traveling in one direction as opposed to alternating current which changes directions.

nodes.name: Directional Coupler
nodes.description: A passive device used couple a defined amount of power in a transmission line to a single port, enabling the signal to be used in another circuit. Unlike bi-directional couplers, directional couplers only couple power signals flowing in one direction.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, Average Power of
nodes.description: The handling capability of the CW average power through the coupler's main line under matched load conditions with one-way transmission.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, Bandwidth of
nodes.description: The set of frequencies where the performance is lands between certain margins.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, Coupling Coefficient of
nodes.description: Coupling coefficient of directional couplers is the ratio of the incident power fed to the couple port through the main port when reflection-less terminations have terminated all ports. This is measured in dB.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, Coupling Flatness of
nodes.description: The max peak-to-peak difference at a range of frequencies in the coupling coefficient.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, Coupling Loss of
nodes.description: The power lost from the main line by sampling the signal with a coupler.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, Coupling Tolerance of
nodes.description: Tolerated variation in power from unit to unit conversion during nominal coupling.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, Directivity of
nodes.description: Defined as the ratio of the isolation (see Isolation) of the coupler to its coupling factor.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, Main-line Loss of
nodes.description: Main-line loss of directional couplers is the change in load power, which is caused by the insertion of the coupler into a transmission system, where ports of the coupler are connected with reflection-less terminations. This includes the effect of power moved to the coupled line.

nodes.name: Directional Couplers, VSWR of
nodes.description: VSWR quantifies the degree of match relative to a characteristic impedance. This is determined using a standing-wave ratio for any port of a coupler that is designated for reflection-less terminations.

nodes.name: Directivity
nodes.description: Directivity, a term generally associated with antennas, refers to the ratio of the measured power density at its peak point, versus the ideal power density.

nodes.name: Discrete
nodes.description: A discrete component is one that does not need other components to function such as resistors, LED's, etc.

nodes.name: Dispersion
nodes.description: The distortion of electromagnetic signals by varying the propagation speed of a signal. For example, dispersion in an optical fiber causes the pulses to spread out.

nodes.name: Dissipation
nodes.description: Dissipation is energy that is either lost or unusable. Electrical energy is lost (dissipated) in dielectric materials, usually in the form of heat.

nodes.name: Distortion
nodes.description: The deviation from input of the output wave form. One example of this phenomenon is clipping.

nodes.name: Distributed Antenna System (DAS)
nodes.description: A network of separated antennas connected to a common source that provides wireless service within a geographic area or structure such as an office building or school campus.

nodes.name: Dog Bone
nodes.description: An adapter that has two males on both ends and is in a straight configuration.

nodes.name: Dual Directional Coupler
nodes.description: The combination of two 3-port couplers wherein the mainline is shared, and the terminating ports are connected. This allows for bi-directional use of the couplers.

nodes.name: Dummy Load
nodes.description: A Passive device that terminates an open RF connection to prevent leakage.

nodes.name: Duplex
nodes.description: An optical cable containing two fibers.

nodes.name: Dust Cap
nodes.description: A device that caps the end of an RF connector to seal out dust. RF connection remains open.

nodes.name: DWV
nodes.description: The lowest voltage level that a conducting material can withstand.

nodes.name: Dynamic Range
nodes.description: A range for which if a given signal is in that a electrical component can amplify the signal without distortion.

nodes.name: Efficiency, Antenna
nodes.description: A measure of resistive loss in an antenna, calculated by dividing the actual emitted power from an antenna by its theoretical value.

nodes.name: Electromagnetic Compatibility (EMC)
nodes.description: The capability of a system to not be affected by electromagnetic interference.

nodes.name: Electromagnetic Interference (EMI)
nodes.description: Electrical/Electromagnetic energy that can interfere with other desirable signals or equipment and cause problems.

nodes.name: Electromagnetic Spectrum
nodes.description: The range of all possible frequencies of electromagnetic radiation usually considered between ELF (3 Hz) up to Gamma Rays (300 EHz).

nodes.name: Electron
nodes.description: An elementary particle with what is known as the fundamental charge: 1.6 x 10^-19 Coulombs. The movement of electrons conductive materials generates current and voltage, and causes the phenomenon we study in the RF field.

nodes.name: Electronically Steered Array
nodes.description: A smart antenna system that utilizes beam forming rather than physically moving the azimuth to direct the signal.

nodes.name: Electro-optic Effect
nodes.description: A change in the properties of a material as a result of an electric field. This also encompasses a change of absorption and a change in the refractive index as well as the permittivity.

nodes.name: Electroplating
nodes.description: Process of placing metallic layers of varying thickness on a base metal to obtain some electrical property.

nodes.name: Elevation
nodes.description: The angle between +90 degrees (up) and -90 degrees (down), starting from 0 degrees horizontal. It is usually represented by the Greek letter theta (?).

nodes.name: Elliptic Filter
nodes.description: A signal processing filter that has equalized ripple behavior to stabilize a signal. The amount of ripple can be adjusted.

nodes.name: Elliptic Function
nodes.description: A function used in finding the amplitude filter for a particular circuit. However, this filter has a worse transient and phase response compared to classical transfer functions.

nodes.name: EMI Filter
nodes.description: Electromagnetic Interference Filter. Also known as "feedthroughs", EMI filters prevent stray signals from creating noise in your design by using a low-pass filter in combination with shunt capacitance and series inductance.

nodes.name: End Launch
nodes.description: Refers to attaching a connector on the end of a printed circuit board.

nodes.name: End Separation Loss
nodes.description: The optical power loss between the source and destination of an optical fiber. This is caused by increasing the distance between source and destination.

nodes.name: Envelope Delay
nodes.description: Time delay caused by a filter, as noticed by the envelope in an AM signal. It is linearly proportional to the phase-shift versus frequency curve for the filter.

nodes.name: Equilibrium Length
nodes.description: In order to achieve a stable distribution of optical power for different propagating modes, the equilibrium length is used. This is the length of a multimode optical wave guide for specific excitation conditions.

nodes.name: Equilibrium Mode Distribution (EMD)
nodes.description: EMD is the condition in which the distribution of relative power among the propagating modes is independent of length in a multimode optical fiber.

nodes.name: Equivalent Line Circuit
nodes.description: Equivalent line circuit is calculated by line parameters per unit length of the section of line that is being considered. This represents the line circuit through circuit elements that are locally concentrated.

nodes.name: Eutectic
nodes.description: A word describing metal alloys that melt and solidify at the temperature. This is a possible property of soldering material.

nodes.name: Eutectic Bonding
nodes.description: Eutectic bonding is a process in which an alloy can be melted from solid to completely liquid at a very fast rate, bonding two contacts together. This alloy has properties such as low melting point and excellent heat transfer capabilities.

nodes.name: Eutectic Solder
nodes.description: A solder alloy with 63% Tin and 37% Lead in composition. It is most common because of its low melting point.

nodes.name: Failsafe
nodes.description: A feature for relays that prevents other component damage on the same system.

nodes.name: Fall Time
nodes.description: The time it takes a signals to drop from 90% of its maximum to 10% of its maximum. Fall times may also be measured using the 80%, 20% points.

nodes.name: Feed-through
nodes.description: A feed-through is a terminal block or connector which permits bussing and simple distribution of electrical circuits by using double-ended terminals. This term is also used to describe a bushing inside a wall or bulkhead that separates compartments at varying levels or pressure, that has terminations on each side.

nodes.name: FEP (Fluorinated Ethylene Propylene)
nodes.description: A copolymer of hexafluoropropylene and tetrafluoroethylene that is commonly used as a jacketing material on coaxial cables.

nodes.name: Ferrule (Coaxial)
nodes.description: A short, hollow metal tube generally used for joining or reinforcing two pieces of wire or cable or to make a termination on the end of a cable.

nodes.name: Ferrule (Fiber Optic)
nodes.description: Holds a fiber optic cable in place to help align its connection.

nodes.name: FET
nodes.description: FET, or field effect transistor, has three terminals known as the gate, drain, and the source. It has uses in microwave amplifying and switching.

nodes.name: Fiber
nodes.description: A conductor or core that carries light; an optical wave guide. In general, the cluster of cladding and optical core.

nodes.name: Fiber Amplifier
nodes.description: Amplifies an optical signal which passes through it.

nodes.name: Fiber Bandwidth
nodes.description: A frequency at which a specified fraction of the optical power at DC (0 frequency) is achieved. Typically, 0.5 is used as this value.

nodes.name: Fiber Buffer
nodes.description: A material that provides mechanical isolation between external influences and optical fibers in order to protect the fibers from physical damage.

nodes.name: Fiber Bundle
nodes.description: A bundle of unimpeded fiber optic cables used as a single transmission channel.

nodes.name: Fiber Optics
nodes.description: The technology of transmission of radiant energy through an optical medium made of glass or plastic.

nodes.name: Filter
nodes.description: A network of capacitors, inductors, and/ or resistors that is selective as to which frequencies can pass through and which frequencies cannot.

nodes.name: Flange
nodes.description: An extension of a connector which allows the mounting to a panel or the mating to another connector. This extension is usually located at the edge around the connector.

nodes.name: FMC Connector
nodes.description: FMC is an acronym for Flexible Microstrip Connector. This type of connector is very small and uses repeatable electrical characteristics to compensate misalignments. It is also used on the tightest spaces of PCB applications.

nodes.name: FME Connector
nodes.description: A connector designed specifically for use in cellular applications in vehicles, due to their compact size and convenient connection properties. They operate at frequencies up to 3 GHz.

nodes.name: Footprint
nodes.description: The layout of the circuits on a board which is used in order properly connect components

nodes.name: Fourier Analysis
nodes.description: The process in which the equation of a complex wave is separated into parts of component wave, each having a certain phase displacement, amplitude, and frequency.

nodes.name: Free Space Impedance
nodes.description: In a vacuum, free space impedance represents the ratio of electrical to magnetic field strength for a plane wave. Mathematically, it is the relationship two-wire lines equation.

nodes.name: Frequency
nodes.description: The number of cycles of a periodic activity per unit time. The typical measurement is Hz (Hertz), which is cycles per second.

nodes.name: Frequency Doubler
nodes.description: As the name implies, this non-linear device produces an output frequency that is twice the input.

nodes.name: Frequency Modulation (FM)
nodes.description: A method in which the amplitude of a signal remains the same while the frequency of the signal is modulated. Higher frequencies represent higher amplitudes in the original signal.

nodes.name: Frequency Range
nodes.description: The range of frequencies in which a component will function properly to its specification.

nodes.name: Frequency Sensitivity
nodes.description: Also known as "flatness", frequency sensitivity describes the maximum peak-to-peak variation of a directional or hybrid coupler across a specified frequency range.

nodes.name: Fresnel Reflection
nodes.description: Loss due to reflection caused by the difference in refractive indexes between the output face and the receiving optical material.

nodes.name: Gain Compression Point
nodes.description: The point in amplifier power at which gain is no longer linear.

nodes.name: Gallium Arsenide (GaAs)
nodes.description: A compound of the elements gallium and arsenic. It is often used to make devices such as laser diodes, solar cells, and microwave frequency integrated circuits.

nodes.name: Gallium Nitride (GaN)
nodes.description: A compound commonly used in light emitting diodes (LEDs)

nodes.name: Gaussian Filter
nodes.description: Filters that have no overshoot when the input is a step function and minimizes rise/fall time.

nodes.name: GHz
nodes.description: A unit of measurement denoting the number of cycles in one second. One GHz is one billion cycles every second.

nodes.name: Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM)
nodes.description: The standard that describes protocols for 2G cellular networks. This was created by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI).

nodes.name: Graded-index Fiber
nodes.description: A type of optical fiber that contains a refractive index, which gradually changes from the edge to the center. Compared to step-index fiber, graded-index fiber has much less dispersion.

nodes.name: Ground
nodes.description: Voltages in a circuit are measured in relation to a reference point, called ground.

nodes.name: Group Delay
nodes.description: The time delay for a signal to pass through a device.

nodes.name: Group Delay Deviation
nodes.description: The deviation in delay between two points within the passband. Increased delay deviation produces modulated signal distortion.

nodes.name: Guide Pin
nodes.description: A protruding pin whose purpose is to guide two connectors in order to facilitate proper mating of the two halves.

nodes.name: Heat Shock
nodes.description: A test in which a sudden, high temperature change takes place on a material for a short period of time in order to determine its stability.

nodes.name: Heat Shrink
nodes.description: A plastic tube that is typically made of polyolefin or nylon, that is used as a booting on a cable assembly. When heat is applied to the heat shrink material, it 'shrinks' in size to provide a snug jacket at the base of the coaxial connector and cable termination. Heat shrink provides added durability and ruggedness to the cable assembly.

nodes.name: Heat Treating
nodes.description: A set of methods using specific heat and tools whose goal is to change the properties of metals so as to improve certain characteristics.

nodes.name: Helical
nodes.description: A type of coax cable that is spirally corrugated.

nodes.name: Henry
nodes.description: The standard unit for electrical inductance.

nodes.name: Hermaphroditic Connector
nodes.description: A connector which has identical mating faces. There are no gender- specific members.

nodes.name: Hermaphroditic Contacts
nodes.description: When contacts contain mating components that are exactly the same at their mating face, they are known as hermaphroditic contacts.

nodes.name: Hermetic Seal
nodes.description: An airtight seal commonly found on critically sensitive electronic components. This seal protects against the flow of gasses, liquids and other foreign matter.

nodes.name: Hertz (Hz)
nodes.description: A frequency unit equal to one cycle per second. 1 Hz = 1/sec. The name Hertz comes from Heinrich Hertz, the German physicist that discovered the existence of electromagnetic waves in the 19th century.

nodes.name: High-Pass Filter
nodes.description: A HPF allows higher frequencies to pass, while rejecting lower frequencies; the opposite of a lower-pass filter.

nodes.name: Hi-Pot Testing
nodes.description: It tests the maximum voltage and current of a cable.

nodes.name: HN (High Voltage N) Connector
nodes.description: A high-voltage application version of the popular N connector. A high- strength dielectric is used, as well as structural properties that ensure the outer conductor connects before the inner connector.

nodes.name: Hot Switching
nodes.description: Having the ability to "switch" the status of a relay without having to shut off the power / signal.

nodes.name: HV 4-10 (High Voltage C) Connector
nodes.description: A type of coaxial connector contains a bayonet coupling mechanism. Although similar to a C connector, an HV 4-10 connector cannot mate with a C connector. It has fast and reliable connection and disconnection due to its 2 pin bayonet locking system, and has high dielectric strength because of a layout of overlapped dielectric in the connection area. The inner contacts are always closed after the outer contacts. HV 4-10 (High Voltage C) connectors are typically used for high-voltage applications, such as Geiger-Muller counter tubes.

nodes.name: Hybrid Coupler
nodes.description: A 4 port coupler that splits the input signal equally, and as a result, shifts the signal 90 degrees between output signals. It is also capable of combining signals while preserving high isolation between them.

nodes.name: IEEE
nodes.description: An acronym for Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. IEEE sets many of the standards in the fields of electronics.

nodes.name: IEEE 802.11
nodes.description: The set of standards used for the design and implementation of wireless LAN

nodes.name: Impedance
nodes.description: A ratio of the current and voltage phases of a component. Impedance changes with frequency. When selecting which type of connector to use, the connectors impedance must match the impedance of the system being used.

nodes.name: Impedance Matching
nodes.description: A condition in which the internal impedance of a source or the surge impedance of a transmission line is the same as the impedance of a component or circuit, which gives minimum reflection and distortion, as well as maximum energy transfer from the source to the load.

nodes.name: Inclusion
nodes.description: The property of glass bodies referring to impurities.

nodes.name: Incoherent Light
nodes.description: Light rays that are not emitted with the same phase angle.

nodes.name: Indicators
nodes.description: Indicators are used to monitor the state of switches in an RF system.

nodes.name: Infrared
nodes.description: Wavelengths are shorter than 1 mm and longer than 700 nm. They can be felt as heat, but cannot be seen by the human eye.

nodes.name: Injection Laser Diode
nodes.description: See: Diode Laser

nodes.name: Insert Coax 0.8-2.7 (75 Ohms)
nodes.description: Inserts designed for DIN-Hybrid connections. They have a maximum operating frequency of about 1.5 GHz, and offer great mechanical and electrical stability, as well as a small profile for applications where space is limited.

nodes.name: Insert Coax 1.0-2.3 DIN
nodes.description: A smaller version of a coaxial insert for DIN-Hybrid connectors, typically used with mixed card edge connectors. They have very good electrical stability and have a maximum operating frequency of about 2 GHz.

nodes.name: Insert Coax D-Sub
nodes.description: Small coaxial inserts for D-sub Hybrid Connections that have high electrical and mechanical stability. With a maximum operating frequency of 2 GHz, their small size are ideal for cramped layouts in various electronic devices and have applications in rack/plug-in chassis technology along with PCB.

nodes.name: Insert High Voltage DIN
nodes.description: Miniature connector inserts for DIN hybrid connections. This type of insert is very small, thus requiring very low space, and allowing applications in tight layouts in all types of electronic devices. They also have electrical and mechanical stability, and are made for use in mixed card edge connections. Female contacts are made from high quality beryllium copper, while male connectors are made with a plastic body.

nodes.name: Insert Mini Coax
nodes.description: A smaller version of a coax connector for hybrid connections for use in limited-space applications, with a maximum operating frequency of about 6 GHz.

nodes.name: Insertion Loss
nodes.description: Insertion loss is the loss of power caused by having a switch located between two connectors in the transmission. It is measured in decibels (dB). All RF/Microwave devices have insertion loss > 0.

nodes.name: Insulation
nodes.description: Material used to prevent or impede the flow of current, also known as dielectric in certain applications.

nodes.name: Insulation Resistance
nodes.description: The electrical resistance of a material which insulates in specific conditions between any pair of conductors, contacts, or grounding device in different combinations.

nodes.name: Insulators
nodes.description: Materials with very high resistance, insulators includes glass, plastic, rubber etc…

nodes.name: Interconnection
nodes.description: A connection between two components which joins and completes electric circuits.

nodes.name: Interface
nodes.description: A multiple-contact connector has two surfaces on the contact side of both of its halves, which face each other during the assembly of the connector. These two surfaces are called the interface.

nodes.name: Interference
nodes.description: The process in which the amplitudes of multiple waves are systematically weakened and reinforced. Also, the process in which one wave is divided into two or more waves, then joined again back into a single wave.

nodes.name: Intermediate Frequency
nodes.description: The frequency in which a carrier frequency is converted to during the process of transmission.

nodes.name: Intermodulation
nodes.description: Usually undesirable in radio or audio processing, this is a process that modulates the amplitude of a signal containing two or more frequencies that have a non-linear relationship.

nodes.name: ISO
nodes.description: Known as the International Standards Organization. This organization develops standardized methodologies which are used worldwide.

nodes.name: Isolation
nodes.description: A metric describing the quality of separation between signals at adjacent ports. The higher the isolation value, in dB, the less interference exists.

nodes.name: Isolator
nodes.description: A ferromagnetic passive device containing two ports which utilizes an internal resistor and controls the direction of signal flow. Other RF components are protected from excessive signal reflection by the isolator.

nodes.name: Isotropic Radiator
nodes.description: Theoretically, this radiator emits electromagnetic radiation uniformly in every direction without loss of energy. In reality, a no-loss radiator does not exist as proved by the "hairy ball theorem".

nodes.name: Joule
nodes.description: The SI unit for measuring energy.

nodes.name: Jumper Cable
nodes.description: A cable consisting of a male to female connector of the same style.

nodes.name: Ka band
nodes.description: An IEEE standard concerning frequencies from 27 to 40 GHz

nodes.name: Kilo
nodes.description: SI unit prefix meaning 1000 times the unit it is attached to. Example: 1 kilogram = 1000 grams.

nodes.name: Ku band
nodes.description: Frequencies between 12 and 18 GHz as specifies by IEEE Standard 521-1984

nodes.name: LAN
nodes.description: Local Area Network. A data communications network that exists only in a local area up to 6 miles or about 10 kilometers.

nodes.name: Land mobile radio (LMR)
nodes.description: Vehicle mounted or human-portable wireless communication systems for land transportation.

nodes.name: Laser
nodes.description: May refer to either a narrow band of coherent light, or the source of that light. The name is derived from an acronym, "Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation."

nodes.name: Launch Angle
nodes.description: The difference in angle between an optical fiber's axis and the light ray's angle.

nodes.name: LED
nodes.description: Light Emitting Diode

nodes.name: Limiter
nodes.description: A device whose goal is to reduce the input power so that certain components are not damaged.

nodes.name: Limiting Level
nodes.description: Input power level at which gain is no longer linear. See "Gain Compression Point."

nodes.name: Line Impedance
nodes.description: The impedance of a transmission line as measured via the its terminals.

nodes.name: Line Transformer
nodes.description: Transformation properties owned by transmission lines which depend on the length of the line.

nodes.name: Linear and Non-Linear Analysis
nodes.description: Testing devices in a simulation where the outcome is not dependent on whether power and voltage levels are linear. When power amplifiers and frequency conversion devices are tested, the simulation will require nonlinear analysis.

nodes.name: Linear Phase Filter
nodes.description: Simply put, a phase filter whose curve is linear, and whose time delay is constant.

nodes.name: Linear Phase Response
nodes.description: A linear relationship between change in phase angle per unit of frequency.

nodes.name: Liquidus
nodes.description: The temperature at which a solder melts.

nodes.name: Loaded Q (Working Q)
nodes.description: The ratio of the center frequency to the 3 dB bandwidth of a bandpass filter.

nodes.name: Low Loss
nodes.description: Refers to a style of cable that has lower loss of signal compared to a regular coax.

nodes.name: Low Noise Block (LNB)
nodes.description: A low noise block takes the small signals it receives from the dish and amplifies the signal to a usable level and converts the signals.

nodes.name: Low Noise Cable
nodes.description: Mechanical movements can cause spurious electrical disturbances. A low noise cable is designed to prevent these disturbances.

nodes.name: Low-Pass Filter
nodes.description: This type of filter lets lower frequencies pass while rejecting higher frequencies. It is the opposite of a high-pass filter.

nodes.name: LSOH
nodes.description: An acronym for Low Smoke Zero Halogen.

nodes.name: Magnetron
nodes.description: Invented by Albert Wallace Hull, the magnetron is a high-powered vacuum tube that works as microwave oscillator. The strong magnetic fields produced by the magnetron produce the high-power output required in radar equipment. It enabled airborne radar at microwave frequencies during WWII.

nodes.name: MCX Connector
nodes.description: Micro-miniature Coaxial Connectors are made to be very reliable, easy to mount, and very small, containing a snap-on connecting system and used for frequencies up to 6 GHz.

nodes.name: Measurement Line
nodes.description: In RF, this refers to the transmission line whose field distribution is sampled.

nodes.name: Mega
nodes.description: In the SI system, a prefix that means one million (1 x 10^6). Its abbreviation is M. 1 MHz = 1 x 10^6 Hz.

nodes.name: Megahertz (MHz)
nodes.description: Equal to 1 million Hz. Uses the SI Prefix Mega, meaning 10^6.

nodes.name: Meridional Ray
nodes.description: Ray passing through the axis of an optical fiber.

nodes.name: MHV Connector
nodes.description: Coaxial connector that uses bayonet coupling mechanism with a working voltage of 2.2kV DC.

nodes.name: Micro
nodes.description: The SI prefix meaning 10^-6. Abbreviated by the Greek letter "mu" (?).

nodes.name: Microbending Loss
nodes.description: In an optical fiber, sharp curvatures that involve spatial wavelengths of a few millimeters and local axial displacements of a few micrometers may cause light loss, or micro bending loss. These bends may be caused by packaging, installation, fiber coating, and cables. Micro bending can cause mode coupling and significant radiation losses.

nodes.name: Microdot
nodes.description: Connectors with high contact quality and screw-lock system for high stability and shielding. For use with low noise cables.

nodes.name: Micrometer
nodes.description: A micrometer (?m) is a unit of length in the SI system. 1 ?m = 1 x 10^-6 meters.

nodes.name: Microstrip
nodes.description: This type of transmission line configuration is separated by a dielectric and uses a conductor over a parallel ground plane

nodes.name: Microstripline
nodes.description: Microstripline is a type of transmission line that has a solid ground plane metallization and a metalized strip, which is separated by a solid, thin dielectric. It is commonly used on PC board and ceramic substrates in the range of 400 MHz to 6 GHz since it allows transmission lines to be manufactured accurately. Stripline technology is often used for broadband devices or higher frequencies.

nodes.name: Microwave
nodes.description: A section of the electromagnetic spectrum extending between 1 and 300 GHz. The microwave spectrum is between the RF and infrared spectrums, and is used in many applications, including communications.

nodes.name: MIL
nodes.description: An abbreviation for the word "military." Often appears as "MIL-SPEC," implying that a part meets military specifications.

nodes.name: Milli
nodes.description: Milli (m) is a prefix in the SI system, which means one thousandth (1 x 10^-3). For example, 1 mm = 1 x 10^-3 m.

nodes.name: Mini SMP Connector
nodes.description: The smallest connector on the market, with operating frequencies up to 65 GHz and an impedance of 50 Ohms.

nodes.name: Mini UHF Connector
nodes.description: A type of miniature coaxial connector with an impedance of 50 Ohms and improved electrical performance compared to normal UHF series connectors. It is fitted with notched edges for adjustment and the typical UHF screw-locking system. Also, this connector has a high vibration security and torsional protection, which are provided by lugs located on the plug, corresponding to the notched edges on the jack. Mini UHF connectors are commonly used in mobile devices that perform up to 2.5 GHz.

nodes.name: Mismatch (Connector Impedance or Line Impedance)
nodes.description: The event when the load and the source do not have the same impedance. This results in reflection and loss of power.

nodes.name: Mismatching
nodes.description: A line is mismatched if its characteristic impedance is different from its termination resistance. This often causes reflections, which lead to undesirable losses.

nodes.name: MMBX Connector
nodes.description: A Micro-Miniature Board connector is used for "sandwich" and vertical direct Board-to-board interconnection. It is typically used for applications from DC to 6 GHz, and has an impedance of 50 Ohms.

nodes.name: MMCX Connector
nodes.description: Stands for Micro Miniature Coaxial connector which have snap on connection and can have frequencies from DC up to 6 GHz.

nodes.name: Modal Noise
nodes.description: When a coherent light source is used, there is noise generated at the wave guide's exit aperture. This effect, called modal noise, is caused by modal interference in the wave guide. Also see: Mode, Interference.

nodes.name: Mode
nodes.description: An electromagnetic field distribution that satisfies boundary conditions as well as Maxwell's equations in a transmission line or cavity. Dependencies of a mode's field pattern include wave guide geometry, refractive index, cavity, and wavelength. Also see: Equilibrium Mode Distribution.

nodes.name: Mode Coupling
nodes.description: Describes the exchange of signal power in an optical fiber among modes, which eventually approaches some equilibrium.

nodes.name: Modulation
nodes.description: Modification of a signal created by super imposing the data signal onto a carrier frequency.

nodes.name: Modulator
nodes.description: An electronic device the takes in a baseband signal as input and converts it to a modulated RF signal.

nodes.name: Moisture Resistance
nodes.description: A materials ability to not absorb or resist the absorption of water.

nodes.name: Mono Mode Range for Coaxial Cables
nodes.description: When a coaxial cable operates at a certain frequency range, in which only the Lecher wave is capable of propagation and therefore also controls the propagation parameters.

nodes.name: MTBF – (Mean Time Between Failure)
nodes.description: The average time between the occurrence of failures in a component.

nodes.name: Multi-fiber Cable
nodes.description: This type of optical cable consists of two or more fibers that carry separate information channels.

nodes.name: Multimode Fiber
