nodes.description: A type of fiber that allows more than one mode to propagate. The number of modes in a fiber is determined by Maxwell's equations and boundary conditions. The multimode fiber's core diameter can range from 25-2,000 microns.

nodes.name: Multiple Reflections
nodes.description: Multiple reflection waves are caused by continuous new reflections which are the result of propagated waves that are repeatedly reflected both at the input and the output ends of a transmission line. These reflected waves superimpose themselves on the primary waves.

nodes.name: Multiplexer
nodes.description: A network or device that receives multiple signals through its input, and outputs the signals separately, according to their frequency.

nodes.name: Multiplier Nonlinearity
nodes.description: A frequency multiplier has an output power that is proportional to the squared input power. This condition is called a "square-law" curve. Its power transfer characteristic is very different from an amplifier, limiter, or mixer.

nodes.name: N (75 Ohms) Connector
nodes.description: There are two versions of the N connectors: one with 50 Ohms and another with 75 Ohms impedance that cannot be mated. N connectors have a high degree of protection from weather with a screw locking system in medium dimension. They are robust, reliable and provide excellent intermodulation.

nodes.name: Nanometer
nodes.description: A length equal to one billionth of a meter.

nodes.name: Noise
nodes.description: Random fluctuations of electrical signals caused by natural disturbances or circuit components.

nodes.name: Noise Currents
nodes.description: Refers to any noise that inhibits the ability to take accurate measurements.

nodes.name: Noise Equivalent Power (NEP)
nodes.description: The point at which the rms of the optical power compared to the rms noise results in a signal to noise ration of 1.

nodes.name: Noise Figure / Noise Factor (Transducer)
nodes.description: The noise factor is described as the ratio of a/b where a is the available signal to noise(SNR) ratio. The ratio, a, is taken at the signal generator terminals when the temperature of the input is 290K and the bandwidth is restricted by a transducer. The b is the available SNR per unit bandwidth at the output terminals of the transducer.

nodes.name: Noise Floor
nodes.description: Noise floor refers to the lowest input power that produces a detectable output.

nodes.name: Noise Temperature
nodes.description: Noise temperature is the amount of thermal noise found in components. In electronics, it is a way of expressing the total level of available noise power introduced by a component or power source.

nodes.name: No-load Impedance
nodes.description: Input impedance when no load is present.

nodes.name: Non-unilateral Device
nodes.description: A non-unilateral devise is active component such as an amplifier with poor directivity.

nodes.name: Normally Open
nodes.description: A term for relays in which the conductors are normally open.

nodes.name: Numerical Aperture (NA)
nodes.description: The value that describe the ability of a fiber to accept light. Generally speaking, a higher value is more desirable.

nodes.name: Operating Mode
nodes.description: When the actuating voltage is removed, the characteristic that decides the operation of the switch is called the operating mode.

nodes.name: Operating Mode-Failsafe
nodes.description: A mode which is standard on RLC switches. When actuating voltage is applied, the switch will move to the closed position. The switch returns to open position only when the voltage is removed.

nodes.name: Operating Mode-Latching
nodes.description: In latching mode, the RLC switch will remain in any switched position when the actuating voltage is removed. This mode is optional on my RLC switches. In many standard RLC latching switches, the actuating current is automatically cut after the switch has changed position due to its "Cutthroat" solid state circuit.

nodes.name: Optical Waveguide
nodes.description: Any structure capable of carrying the radiant energy along a path along its axis.

nodes.name: Optoelectronics
nodes.description: A branch of study whose focus is light in the context of electronics. This includes LEDs, Lasers, photo sensors or any devices the utilize optics/light.

nodes.name: Oscillator
nodes.description: Provides an electrical signal that oscillates in voltage magnitude depending on the voltage input.

nodes.name: Oscilloscope
nodes.description: An electronic testing equipment use in the analysis of waveforms. From an oscilloscope, one can gather data about the shape of the waveform, it's frequency, distortion, rise-time, etc.

nodes.name: Passband
nodes.description: The frequency range for a filter that does not get rejected.

nodes.name: Passband Ripple
nodes.description: Attenuation of the signal within the passband that varies with frequency.

nodes.name: Passivated
nodes.description: A type of finish for Stainless Steel parts.

nodes.name: Passivation
nodes.description: Creating an insulated layer over bare metal by treating it with a chemical. This layer protects the metal from contaminants, moisture, and particles.

nodes.name: Passive Device,
nodes.description: A device with no power source. A passive device cannot add energy to a signal

nodes.name: Passive Intermodulation (PIM)
nodes.description: Occurs in passive devices such as cables or antennas that are subjected to two or more high power tones. PIM is the result of multiple tones mixing. The higher the signal amplitudes, the more pronounced the effect of PIM.

nodes.name: PCB Connector
nodes.description: A connector mounted on printed circuit boards (PCB).

nodes.name: Peak Sidelobe Ratio
nodes.description: Ratio between the highest side lobe intensity to the intensity of the beam parallel the azimuth of an antenna.

nodes.name: Permeability (magnetic)
nodes.description: The measure that compares how magnetic force lines travel through a material compared to air. Air is designated with a permeability of 1.

nodes.name: Permittivity
nodes.description: A measure of the amount of resistance that results when creating an electric field throughout a medium. It describes how an electrical field affects a medium.

nodes.name: Phase
nodes.description: In electronic signals, phase is defined as the position of a point in time on a waveform cycle. A complete cycle is defined as 360 degrees of phase.

nodes.name: Phase Balance
nodes.description: Given a frequency range, it is the max peak-to-peak difference in phases of power divider output ports.

nodes.name: Phase Constant
nodes.description: Designated as ?, this is the imaginary component of propagation which gives evidence to the gradient of the current and voltage phases as a function with respect to transmission line length.

nodes.name: Phase Detector
nodes.description: A device that outputs a DC voltage proportional to the phase difference between two RF input signals.

nodes.name: Phase Distortion
nodes.description: A distortion caused by non-linearity in the phase-response.

nodes.name: Phase Jitter
nodes.description: The undesired variation in the phase from its desired level

nodes.name: Phase Modulation
nodes.description: A method of encoding data onto an AC waveform by varying the instantaneous phase of the wave.

nodes.name: Phase Noise
nodes.description: The representation of random fluctuations in a waveform's phase as a frequency domain.

nodes.name: Phase Shift
nodes.description: After a current or voltage passes through a cable or circuit, any change in its phase is called the phase shift.

nodes.name: Phase Shifter
nodes.description: Device used to shift the phase of a signal, ideally with very low insertion loss and amplitude output that is equal on all phase states.

nodes.name: Phase Speed
nodes.description: Speed of a voltage-phase relationship that is propagated on a transmission line. Measured in vph.

nodes.name: Phase Stability
nodes.description: Change in electrical length in a cable based on changes in temperature and other parameters.

nodes.name: Phase-locked Loop (PLL)
nodes.description: A process that keeps the phase of the input and output in step with each other.

nodes.name: Pig Tail
nodes.description: A cable assembly with only one connector attached. The opposite side of the assembly is unterminated or open-ended.

nodes.name: PIM (Passive Intermodulation)
nodes.description: A nonlinear response from a passive device caused by inconsistencies or impurities in the materials or connections. This is seen when there are two or more signals in the device.

nodes.name: Pin Contact
nodes.description: A type of male contact designed to mate with a socket or female contact.

nodes.name: PIN Diode
nodes.description: A diode that has properties similar to a variable resistor that varies based on the DC bias. This diode is designed with a thin layer that is present between the P and N sections.

nodes.name: Planck's Constant
nodes.description: Denoted by h, this is the universal constant that represents the ratio of a quantum of radiant energy to the frequency of the source, or E/f. Its value is 6.62606957 × 10^-34.

nodes.name: Plastic clad silica (PCS) fiber
nodes.description: High quality fiber optic cable with high light transmission, made with a glass core and plastic cladding.

nodes.name: Plated Through-Hole
nodes.description: A hole into which components can be soldered into place in order to connect them to other circuit components.

nodes.name: Polarization
nodes.description: A property of electromagnetic waves which describes its orientation in space. Polarization is dependent on the type of wave, the type of source, and the source's orientation.

nodes.name: Power (Average)
nodes.description: The average power rating limits high-frequency operation, while the peak power rating usually specifies the low frequency.

nodes.name: Power (Peak)
nodes.description: Peak power rating usually specifies the low frequency or pulse energy of a signal, while the average power rating limits high-frequency operation.

nodes.name: Power Splitter
nodes.description: Delivers multiple output signals with phase and amplitude specifications. This is a passive device that takes in one input signal. Bidirectional splitters can combine signals as well. Also called power divder.

nodes.name: Precision
nodes.description: A term used to identify higher quality / performance products.

nodes.name: Press-Fit Contact
nodes.description: An electrical contact that can be installed into a hole in a printed board, insulator, or metal plate using an interference fit.

nodes.name: Primary Attenuation Step
nodes.description: The port of the step attenuator that is activated, or in the "high" state.

nodes.name: Printed Circuit Board (PCB)
nodes.description: A PCB, or PC Board, is a composite of multiple materials like metal, epoxy glass, silicon, copper and non-conductive substrate. Hardware such as passive and active components can be attached to transmit signals and data. Circuits are also etched onto the PCB.

nodes.name: Propagating
nodes.description: Moving or transmitting energy along some path.

nodes.name: Propagation Constant
nodes.description: The longitudinal wave propagation along a conductor is represented by the propagation constant. Along with the characteristic impedance, it enables the calculation of the transformation characteristics of the current and voltage on the conductor, as well as their distribution.

nodes.name: Propagation Delay
nodes.description: A transmission network or digital device requires an amount of time to transfer information from its input to its output. This is known as propagation delay.

nodes.name: Prototype
nodes.description: A pre-production model of a product that exhibits full or partial functionality of the final product.

nodes.name: PTFE (Polytetrafluoroethylene)
nodes.description: PTFE has a stable and low dielectric constant and loss factor over a broad frequency and temperature range. Therefore, it is used as an insulator in microwave and RF coaxial connectors.

nodes.name: Pulse
nodes.description: A brief change in value, usually voltage in the positive direction, that returns to the steady state.

nodes.name: Pulse Width
nodes.description: The amount of time wherein an electrical pulse is transient.

nodes.name: Pushing
nodes.description: Relationship between the change in frequency per unit voltage changed.

nodes.name: QLA
nodes.description: A subminiature connector using a quick latch coupling connection and whose resistance is 50 ohms.

nodes.name: QMA Connector
nodes.description: A QMA connector is based on the dimensions of an SMA connector, however, it contains a snap-lock mechanism rather than a threaded coupling mechanism. It has frequency range DC - 18 GHz.

nodes.name: QN Connector
nodes.description: Connector with a snap-lock mating mechanism based on N dimension

nodes.name: Quantum Efficiency
nodes.description: A factor of efficiency calculated using the conversion between photon/ second and electrons/second for a light sources and detectors.

nodes.name: QUICK-FIT
nodes.description: Internationally approved N and 7/16 connectors used for copper tube cables with foam dielectric.

nodes.name: Quick-Lock
nodes.description: A connector that allows for quick connecting/disconnecting.

nodes.name: QUICK-MATE
nodes.description: A type of adapter that is used for test applications since it enables quick connection and disconnection. It can be plugged without the need of a coupling nut.

nodes.name: Radio Frequency (RF)
nodes.description: Electromagnetic energy emitted between 50 MHz to 1 GHz.

nodes.name: Rated Voltage
nodes.description: Maximum voltage that can be constantly applied to a cable, connector, or any electrical component without destroying the component or causing any permanent alterations to its technical parameters.

nodes.name: Ray
nodes.description: Pictorial representation of the path which a light wave travels.

nodes.name: Rayleigh Scattering
nodes.description: Scattering by index fluctuations that are both refractive and small in relation to wavelength. The fourth power of the wavelength is inversely proportional to the scattered field.

nodes.name: Reactive Splitter
nodes.description: A device that divides power equally on the input onto several output ports. This is done without much change in the phase relationship and causes little distortion.

nodes.name: Receiver
nodes.description: Any device that receives and interprets an optical signal into an electrical or digital one for use by other devices.

nodes.name: Receptacle
nodes.description: A two-piece multiple contact connector's stationary half. It also commonly has socket contacts and is mounted on a panel.

nodes.name: Reciprocity
nodes.description: An antenna works in exactly the same manner in receiving the signal as it does when sending a signal.

nodes.name: Reentrant Modes
nodes.description: Reentrant modes occur when a band-pass filter is designed for one frequency, but it also passes RF at integer multiples of the intended frequency.

nodes.name: Reflection
nodes.description: The return of waveform after bouncing on an object. This is sometimes used as a metric of inefficiency for cables and other devices when referring to internal reflection.

nodes.name: Reflection Coefficient
nodes.description: Measured at the terminating resistance, the complex reflection coefficient is the ratio of the voltage returning from the load to the voltage supplied by the generator. From this, return loss and VSWR can be calculated.

nodes.name: Reflection Loss
nodes.description: When power is reflected at a line discontinuity, part of a signal is lost. This is known as reflection loss.

nodes.name: Reflow Soldering
nodes.description: A process that wets the leads and pads with solder by screen printing and then heating to cause the solder to melt.

nodes.name: Refraction
nodes.description: When oblique incident rays pass a medium that has a certain refractive index into another medium with a different refractive index, the rays will bend. This is known as refraction.

nodes.name: Refractive index
nodes.description: A number that indicates how much light will bend when it enters a medium. It a ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum over the speed of light in the given medium.

nodes.name: Relative Attenuation
nodes.description: Attenuation relative to the minimum.

nodes.name: Repeater
nodes.description: A module that receives an optical signal and converts it to an electronic signal while amplifying it and then re-transmitting in optical form.

nodes.name: Responsivity
nodes.description: The ratio of output to input (gain) of a detector system. Standard units of measurement are amps per watt.

nodes.name: Return Loss
nodes.description: The measure of the amount of reflected power when it is connected to any active or passive device or terminated on a transmission line. Return loss can be used to calculate VSWR and the Reflection Coefficient Expressed in dB.

nodes.name: Return Loss (from Reflection Coefficient)
nodes.description: Loss from reflection due to scattering, measured in dB, measured by taking the logarithm of the reflection coefficient and multiplying by -20.

nodes.name: Reverse Polarity
nodes.description: Has opposite contact from normal connector.

nodes.name: RF (Radio Frequency)
nodes.description: Frequencies typically ranging between 50 - 999 MHz where radiation of electromagnetic energy is possible. Microwave frequency is considered to be 1,000 MHz (1 GHz) and up.

nodes.name: RF Choke
nodes.description: A component that allows low frequency or DC to pass through, but blocks RF signals.

nodes.name: RF Leakage
nodes.description: An amount of a signal that is lost in (or radiated by) a connector.

nodes.name: RF Mixer
nodes.description: A device that translates frequency from the input signal to the output signal. When a mixer is used for up-conversion, the input is an IF signal and the output is an RF signal. It is the opposite for down- conversion.

nodes.name: RF Shielding
nodes.description: The process of blocking an electromagnetic field with magnetic or conductive barriers in order to suppress it.

nodes.name: RG/U
nodes.description: Denotes certain coaxial cables that are manufactured to Government Specification. For example, RG-58U: R represents radio frequency, G represents government, 58 is the number assigned to the government approval, and U represents universal specification.

nodes.name: Right Angle
nodes.description: The connector or adapter looks like the letter "L" due to the 90 degree body.

nodes.name: Ringing
nodes.description: When a transient waveform is applied to a filter, it may tend to oscillate for a period of time. This is known as ringing.

nodes.name: Ripple
nodes.description: Sinusoidal changes in the amplitude response of a particular filter.

nodes.name: Rise Time
nodes.description: The amount of time a signal takes to get from its steady state to some peak value. It is the opposite of fall time.

nodes.name: RoHS
nodes.description: Restriction of Hazardous Substances discusses the amount of particular materials that may be used in electronic devices.

nodes.name: Root Mean Square
nodes.description: A mathematical operation done to a set of values. Specifically, it means "the square-root of the mean of the squared values." This has many applications in electrical engineering, including the calculation of average power.

nodes.name: Rubber Duck Antenna
nodes.description: An electrically short monopole antenna that is protected by a plastic or rubber jacket. Its function is similar to a base-loaded whip antenna.

nodes.name: Scattering
nodes.description: While there are no changes in the wavelengths of radiation, scattering causes changes in the direction of light within the optical fiber core, often due to core and cladding imperfections.

nodes.name: Screening Effectiveness
nodes.description: The ratio of the input power to a coaxial cable to the power transmitted by it and outputted by the outer conductor.

nodes.name: Screw Machine Contact
nodes.description: Solid bar stock is used to machine this type of contact.

nodes.name: Self Alignment
nodes.description: A phenomenon caused by surface tension of liquid solder, which occurs when leads align themselves on solder pads.

nodes.name: Semiconductor
nodes.description: A substance that has resistance between that of a metal conductor and an insulator. Silicon is an example of a highly used semiconductor.

nodes.name: Semi-Insulators
nodes.description: Made from GaAs wafers, they possess resistivities between 103 and 1010 Ohm-centimeters.

nodes.name: Semi-Rigid
nodes.description: Cables whose outer insulators are relatively rigid, while the inner conductor are more flexible. This allows the cable to be more rigid but still be marginally flexible.

nodes.name: Sensitivity
nodes.description: The input power level which is required for the system to operate as intended.

nodes.name: Shape Factor
nodes.description: The ratio of Attenuation Bandwidth to 3 dB. bandwidth for a bandpass filter, 3 dB Bandwidth to Attenuation Bandwidth for a band-stop filter, Attenuation Frequency to Fco for a low pass filter and Fco to Attenuation Frequency for high pass filter.

nodes.name: Shape Factor (Bandwidth Ratio)
nodes.description: The ratio between High and low attenuation level bandwidth or between 3 dB Bandwidth to the stop band bandwidth

nodes.name: SHF
nodes.description: SHF = Super High Frequency, Range: 3 GHz to 30 GHz

nodes.name: Shield
nodes.description: A conducting screen or housing that greatly reduces the effect of magnetic or electric fields coming from one side onto any circuits or devices on the other side. Cable shields can be taped, braided, or solid. Also, the metallic layer in a cable that prevents electromagnetic or electrostatic interference between the external fields and enclosed wires. This metallic layer is placed around a conductor, or group of conductors.

nodes.name: Shielding
nodes.description: A metallic coating used to prevent signal interference or current leakage in a circuit or coaxial cable.

nodes.name: Short Circuit Impedance
nodes.description: The very small to non-existent impedance in a short circuit.

nodes.name: Shot Noise
nodes.description: Noise produced from the process of single electrons passing through the p-n junction. The mean square shot noise current is related to the diode's average current and bandwidth. RMS shot noise = square root (2*q*I*B), where q is the elementary charge, I is current, and B is the bandwidth.

nodes.name: SHV (Save High Voltage) Connector
nodes.description: While similar to the design of BNC connectors, SHV (Safe High Voltage) connectors are not compatible with BNC connectors. They are used in applications for frequencies up to 50 MHz. The locking system allows for quick engagement and disengagement. Center contacts for each mating pair are in deep recesses so that it avoids shorting at the center when not connected. To connect, the outer couplings must be engaged first before the center can be shorted.

nodes.name: Sidelobes
nodes.description: Undesirable gain response of an antenna in a direction not with the main beam.

nodes.name: Signal Generator
nodes.description: Can generate repeating and non-repeating signals based on a given setting. A signal generator can provide adjustable wavelength, frequency, waveform, load, and magnitude.

nodes.name: Signal-to-noise ratio (SNR)
nodes.description: Signal power to noise power ratio which is related to bit error rate performance.

nodes.name: Sine Wave
nodes.description: The classic example of a "wave." A sine wave is a function whose value oscillates about some zero value equally in both the positive and negative directions with respect to time.

nodes.name: Single-mode Fiber
nodes.description: An optical fiber whose diameter is so small that light can only travel on one path. This dimension must be under 10 microns.

nodes.name: Skin Effect
nodes.description: The tendency for an AC signal to be present at the surface of a conductor rather than in the interior. This property is due to the natural gathering of charge at the edges of a conductor.

nodes.name: SMA Connector
nodes.description: Uses a 4.2mm diameter outer coax filled with PTFE dielectric. The upper frequency limit is between 18 to 26 GHz depending on the quality of manufacturing. Similar to many other coax connectors, a 5/16 inch wrench can be used to tighten the screw-coupling mechanism. These connectors are compatible with 3.5mm and 2.92mm connectors. There should be a careful inspection before mixing of SMA connectors that are more expensive.

nodes.name: SMA Reverse Polarity
nodes.description: Sub-Miniature coaxial connector with a center contact with reversed gender. They perform up to 18 GHz and are often used for connections between W-LAN components, and have optimum electrical properties, such as low VSWR, high durability, long life, and high mechanical stability.

nodes.name: SMB (Subminiature B) Connector
nodes.description: A coaxial connector capable of frequencies from DC to 4 GHz. Uses snap on coupling.

nodes.name: SMB Connector
nodes.description: A subminiature connector with a simple snap-on mechanism, and a maximum operating frequency of up to 4 GHz.

nodes.name: SMC Connector
nodes.description: A connector with a screw-on attachment, usable up to 10 GHz. These connectors can be coupled with a shared nut.

nodes.name: Smith Chart
nodes.description: Used to calculate resistance transformations on transmission lines, as well as the corresponding matching circuits. A Smith Chart represents the reflection coefficient as a complex plane within the restrictions of the unit circle. It contains lines of complex resistances that are normalized respectively to the characteristic impedance, consisting of constant real components and constant imaginary components.

nodes.name: SMP Connector
nodes.description: A micro-miniature connector most commonly used in board-to-board applications. They operate up to 40 GHz and are available in a variety of mounting styles.

nodes.name: SMS Connector
nodes.description: A subminiature connector with a slide-on coupling mechanism and has a frequency range of DC - 4 GHz

nodes.name: Snap N Connector
nodes.description: A quick-lock connector that can be mated with an N connector. It can be connected very quickly and in tight places without the need of any tools.

nodes.name: Snap-on
nodes.description: The ability to easily assemble or remove one part to or from another

nodes.name: Solder Contact
nodes.description: A contact terminal that accepts a wire for soldering ends by using a cup, hollow cylinder, eyelet or hook.

nodes.name: Solder Paste
nodes.description: A combination of several components including, solder powder, flux, solvent, and binder. It is printed onto PCB's and used to form solder joints.

nodes.name: Soldering
nodes.description: The process of connecting many components by melting a metal which holds them together.

nodes.name: Spectrum Analyzer
nodes.description: An instrument that measures the amplitude of a signal along a range of frequencies.

nodes.name: Splice
nodes.description: A splice is a permanent junction, either applied mechanically or fused thermally, located between optical fibers.

nodes.name: Spread Spectrum
nodes.description: Spread-spectrum techniques give a signal a wider bandwidth by spreading its original bandwidth in the frequency domain.

nodes.name: Spring-Finger Action
nodes.description: A contact locking mechanism that uses a small protrusion, angled away from the direction of connection, to lock a connector into place.

nodes.name: Spurious Free Dynamic Range
nodes.description: The ratio between the RMS power of the fundamental signal and the RMS power of the resulting noise or distortion.

nodes.name: SSMB Connector
nodes.description: Micro-miniature coaxial connector with snap-on coupling mechanism uses a tongue and groove design to hold the plugged connectors together. The design permits fast engagement/disengagement in small and hard to access locations.

nodes.name: SSMC Connector
nodes.description: A micro miniature coaxial connector capable of 6 GHz frequencies and has low voltage standing wave ratios. The connector uses screw on coupling.

nodes.name: Standing-Wave
nodes.description: When two sets of waves travel in opposite directions, the resulting distribution of voltage and current on a transmission line is called standing-wave.

nodes.name: Star Coupler
nodes.description: A passive electrical component which takes multiple optical inputs and spreads their power along multiple outputs.

nodes.name: Step Function
nodes.description: A signal with instantaneous change in amplitude, shaped like a step. Typically, step functions are used to test transient responses for systems.

nodes.name: Step-index Fiber
nodes.description: A fiber designed with an uniform refractive index core. This profile allows the abrupt changes at boundaries between core and cladding.

nodes.name: Stimulated Emission
nodes.description: Radiation that is emitted due to the internal energy of a quantum mechanical system which drops from an excited to lower level. This drop is induced by the presence of radiant energy at the same frequency. See also: Spontaneous emission; Injection Laser Diode.

nodes.name: Stopband
nodes.description: A range of frequencies that are rejected - typically by a filter.

nodes.name: Stripline
nodes.description: A type of transmission line with a conducting strip either on top of or between two conducting surfaces (typically, stripline refers to the latter). It is generally favored in higher frequencies and broadband applications.

nodes.name: SUCOPLATE®
nodes.description: Plating made out of copper, tin, and zinc. Provides good corrosion and abrasion resistance and is not magnetic. Registered mark of HUBER+SUHNER AG.

nodes.name: SUCOPRO®
nodes.description: It is a plating material with Nickel-Phosphorus-Alloy under a layer of gold. Provides protection from wear and excellent solder-ability.

nodes.name: SUCOREX®
nodes.description: Plating with an inner material made from SUCOPLATE and a thin outer layer of gold. Provides good corrosion and wear resistance. Easy to solder due to the gold layer.

nodes.name: Super Conductor
nodes.description: Has a bulk resistivity of zero.

nodes.name: Surface Mount Device (SMD)
nodes.description: A passive or active device that is made to be soldered onto a PCB surface.

nodes.name: Surface Mount Technology (SMT)
nodes.description: A way of mounting components to the surface of a printed surface board as opposed to plated through-holes.

nodes.name: Switch
nodes.description: A device that works like a light switch. It either turns on or off the signal or redirects it to an adjacent port.

nodes.name: TDU
nodes.description: Time Delay Unit. This is a structure similar to a phase shifter and allows specific or programmable time delay using a multi-path structure. Unlike a phase shifter, TDUs do not provide a fixed insertion phase difference between two states. A TDU can provide a large number of wavelengths of phase shift which is exactly proportional to frequency such that the difference between group delays is flat over required bandwidth.

nodes.name: TEM Wave
nodes.description: TEM waves, or Transverse Electro-Magnetic waves have magnetic and electrical field parts that lie on a plane that is vertical to the direction of propagation. These waves can propagate on coaxial lines.

nodes.name: Temperature
nodes.description: A temperature range (minimum through maximum) at which a component can function while still meeting all its required specifications.

nodes.name: Termination (RF Load)
nodes.description: A component that absorbs the remainder of a signal, ideally with little to no reflection.

nodes.name: Test Voltage
nodes.description: The maximum voltage in which a circuit component can be used for a specific amount of time, and under specific environmental conditions, without getting damaged.

nodes.name: Thermal Shock
nodes.description: A drastic change in temperature causing non-uniform expansion or contractor within a material or a combination of materials that can cause internal parts to separate from each other.

nodes.name: Time Delay
nodes.description: For a signal to pass through a filter, it will take a certain amount of time. This is known as time delay.

nodes.name: TNC (50 Ohms) Connector
nodes.description: Coaxial connectors with electrical properties and dimensions similar to a BMC connector, but with a screw-on mating mechanism for quick connections. It generally usable up to 4 GHz.

nodes.name: TNC Reverse Polarity Connector
nodes.description: A type of threaded coaxial connector that contains the opposite sex center contact. This is know as reverse center contact. Optimum results are achieved up to 4 GHz, and is often used for connections between W- LAN components, much like SMA reverse polarity connectors.

nodes.name: Torque
nodes.description: Torque is defined as the tendency of an object to twist around an axis due to a force. Although the actual calculation of torque is a vector cross-product, it can generally be thought of as the amount of force applied times the distance from the axis of rotation. Because of the sensitivity of building materials, industry standards for the tightness of connectors are established. Examples: 1. SMA - 7 to 10 in-lbs; 2. Type-N – 12 to 15 in-lbs; 3. TNC – 12 to 15 in-lbs; 4. 7/16 DIN – 220 to 300 in-lbs.

nodes.name: Total Internal Reflection
nodes.description: The confinement of light by means of reflection within a substance. This is the property that allows optical fibers to transmit light with no loss.

nodes.name: TPX® (Polymethylpentene)
nodes.description: A 4-methylpentene-1 based polyolefin manufactured by Mitsui Chemicals, Inc. TPX is is used as a jacketing material on coaxial cables.

nodes.name: Transceiver
nodes.description: A component capable of both transmitting and receiving signals. In the RF sphere, it's implementation is used to tighten the gap between digital signals and antennas.

nodes.name: Transducer
nodes.description: Converts energy from one form to another. For example, electrical energy (audio-frequency) into sound.

nodes.name: Transfer Impedance
nodes.description: A value relating the current in the outer conductor of a coaxial cable to the voltage drop between the outer and inner sides of that conductor. The impermeability of the outer conductor of coaxial cables is represented by the transfer impedance.

nodes.name: Transformer
nodes.description: Used to achieve maximum power transfer by matching impedance, as well as for separating DC from two circuits while keeping AC continuous, and voltage step-down or step-up. These processes take place in low-power electronic circuits.

nodes.name: Transition Band
nodes.description: The frequency range between the passband and the stopband. This could be thought of as the "downward slope" between these two areas.

nodes.name: Transmission Coefficient
nodes.description: The measurement of the degree of a signal's transmission that goes through a network with two ports. In other words, it is the ratio of the amplitude of the transmitted wave to the wave at the two port network input.

nodes.name: Transmission Line
nodes.description: Refers to the group signal carrying components, like a waveguide, a stripline, or a coax, in a circuit.

nodes.name: Transmission Line Constants
nodes.description: The characteristic parameters of a transmission line

nodes.name: Transmission Loss
nodes.description: The loss of power from on point to another during propagation.

nodes.name: Transmittance
nodes.description: The ratio of the radiant power let through to the total radiant power.

nodes.name: Transmitter
nodes.description: A device that transmits an electrical signal over a fiber cable by first converting it into an optical wave.

nodes.name: Triaxial Cable
nodes.description: A type of cable similar to the coaxial cable, but has two outer concentric conductors, an insulating layer between them, and a center conductor.

nodes.name: Triplexer
nodes.description: A passive device that will split a complex signal into three pre-defined frequency bands.

nodes.name: TTL Control Circuit
nodes.description: A Transistor-Transistor Logic Control Circuit allows the user to control switch operations with a 5 volt control circuit.

nodes.name: Twinax BNC
nodes.description: Di-Pole symmetrical connectors with a bayonet coupling mechanism, applicable for shielded twin-wire cables with different characteristic impedance. It is not mateable with standard BNC connectors.

nodes.name: Twinaxial Cable
nodes.description: A twinaxial cable (Twinax) has two-pole symmetrical connectors which are polarized and locked. It also has a screw-locking system and gaskets that make it weatherproof. Twinaxial cable has impedances between 75 and 95 Ohms.

nodes.name: Twinaxial Connector
nodes.description: A connector with 2 center conductors.

nodes.name: Twist-On
nodes.description: A method use to attach the connector to the coax by twisting them together.

nodes.name: Two-Wire Line
nodes.description: A two-wire line has two separate conductors that are mutually insulated. It is the most common type of electrical cable.

nodes.name: UGA
nodes.description: An arrangement of antennas in a grid pattern, where they are spaced equally apart in both dimensions

nodes.name: UHF
nodes.description: Ultra High Frequency. Contains the range of 300 to 3000 MHz.

nodes.name: ULA
nodes.description: A Uniform Linear Array is a collection of transmitters aligned with equal spacing in a linear fashion.

nodes.name: Ultra Wideband (UWB)
nodes.description: Useful at low energy levels and short ranges for high bandwidth communications. This technology uses a large frequency range.

nodes.name: Ultraviolet
nodes.description: A spectrum of light that is outside the visible spectrum that ranges from 20 to 380nm and is damaging to human eyes and skin.

nodes.name: Unilateral Device
nodes.description: Unilateral devices usually refer to ideal amplifiers and other active devices where the parameter S12 = 0. This is an idyllic concept.

nodes.name: Vapor Phase Soldering
nodes.description: A soldering process, during which the heating method uses of latent heat of vaporized liquid.

nodes.name: Vector Network Analyzer (VNA)
nodes.description: An instrument that measures an electrical network's parameters, such as S, Y, Z, and H parameters.

nodes.name: Vector Signal Analyzer
nodes.description: A electromagnetic analysis device which measures of the magnitude and phase of an input signal to produce data such as spectral flatness and error vector magnitude.

nodes.name: Velocity of light
nodes.description: In a vacuum, the speed of light is approximately 300,000 km/s (186,000 miles/sec)

nodes.name: Velocity of propagation (VoP)
nodes.description: The possible speed of an electrical signal in a medium relative to it's speed in free space. Velocity of Propagation is usually expressed as a percentage.

nodes.name: VHF
nodes.description: An acronym for Very High Frequency, which is from 30-300 MHz

nodes.name: Viterbi Algorithm
nodes.description: A dynamic programming algorithm that is used in decoding convolution codes.

nodes.name: Voltage Controlled Oscillator (VCO)
nodes.description: An oscillator that can change the frequency by supplying a voltage to it.

nodes.name: Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR)
nodes.description: The measurement of how efficiently radio frequency is transmitted from a power source to a load through a transmission line. A VSWR of 1 is ideal. From VSWR, Return Loss and Reflection Coefficient can be calculated.

nodes.name: VoP (Velocity of propagation)
nodes.description: The speed of an electrical signal, expressed as a percentage, when it travels through a cable in comparison to speed in free space.

nodes.name: VSWR (Voltage Standing Wave Ratio)
nodes.description: VSWR is a measurement of signal reflection in devices, with a VSWR of 1 being ideal (no signal reflected. VSWR can be converted to return loss or the reflection coefficient.

nodes.name: Wave Soldering
nodes.description: A largely used process for through -hole boards, solder is applied to the bottom of the board and connects the metal surfaces.

nodes.name: Waveguide
nodes.description: Hollow tubes with conductive walls which transmit signals along its axis. Waveguides can be rectangular, circular, or elliptical, and the operating frequencies are dependent on its shape and dimensions.

nodes.name: Wavelength
nodes.description: The distance from the beginning of an electromagnetic wave's complete cycle to the end of the cycle. The distance over which the wave's shape repeats.

nodes.name: Welding
nodes.description: The process of joining to metals through a very high temperature procedure.

nodes.name: Wetting
nodes.description: The mechanical bonds formed when liquid solder is attached to other metallic surfaces.

nodes.name: Wetting and sweating
nodes.description: Wetting is the wet-like appearance of a well soldered joint that was brought up to proper temperature levels. Sweating is slang for soldering.

nodes.name: Wilkinson Power Divider
nodes.description: A passive device that either combines input signals to a common port or divides an input signal between its outputs. However, power dissipation limits the power divider when it is used as a combiner. Power dissipation occurs when signals are non-coherent, out of phase, or have amplitude imbalance.
